cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Prima facie intentional torts share common elements and a special doctrine: 1. Common elements of intentional torts 1.1 Act by D: some volitional movement. 1.2 Intent: either specific intent (to bring about a specific harm) or general intent (knowledge with substantial certainty that the tortious result will occur). 1.3 Causation: D's conduct must be a substantial factor in bringing about the resulting harm. 1.4 Damages: compensatory damages are generally available, and punitive damages may be awarded for malicious conduct. 2. Transferred intent doctrine (special rule) 2.1 When D intends one classic intentional tort (assault, battery, false imprisonment, or trespass) but ends up harming a different person and/or committing a different one of those torts, D's original intent transfers to the actual victim and tort. These shared elements and the transferred intent doctrine form the backbone of the classic intentional torts.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the shared elements of a prima facie case for an intentional tort, and what special role does the transferred intent doctrine play in intentional torts?

cards.easyContent: Intentional torts share common elements—volitional act, intent (specific or general), causation, and damages—and are subject to the special transferred intent doctrine for the classic intentional torts.
cards.mediumContent: All classic intentional torts share core elements: (1) an act by D involving a volitional movement; (2) intent, either specific (to bring about a particular result) or general (knowledge with substantial certainty that the result will occur); (3) causation, meaning D's conduct is a substantial factor in producing the harm; and (4) damages, usually compensatory, with possible punitive damages if D acted with malice. They also share the transferred intent doctrine, which allows D's intent for one classic intentional tort to transfer to the actual victim and tort when D hits the wrong person or commits a different intentional tort within the classic group.
cards.hardContent: The classic intentional torts share a common prima facie structure and a special shared doctrine. A prima facie case requires: (1) an act by D, meaning some volitional movement; (2) intent, which can be specific (an intent to bring about a specific harm) or general (D knows with substantial certainty that a tortious result will occur); (3) causation, requiring that D's conduct be a substantial factor in bringing about the resulting harm; and (4) damages, typically compensatory (monetary) damages, with punitive damages available when the tort is committed with malice. Overlaying these elements is the transferred intent doctrine, which applies to the classic intentional torts of assault, battery, false imprisonment, and trespass, and allows D's intent to commit one of these torts against one person to transfer when a different person and/or a different one of these torts is actually committed.
cards.mnemonic: AIC-D plus T: Act, Intent, Causation, Damages, Transferred intent.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into two children: (1) elements of intentional torts (act, intent, causation, damages), and (2) transferred intent doctrine (operation and covered torts). Parent now gives a high-level overview.
cards.clozeLite: All classic intentional torts require {{c1::a volitional act}}, {{c2::intent (specific or general)}}, {{c3::causation}}, and {{c4::damages}}, plus {{c5::transferred intent}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 Assault is an intentional act by D creating P's reasonable apprehension of immediate harmful or offensive contact to P's person, or something closely attached to P's person (e.g., hat, cane). It is also considered an attempted battery. 2. Elements 2.1 Act by D that creates a reasonable apprehension in P. 2.1.1 P has awareness of D's act and has a reasonable expectation that it will result in immediate harmful or offensive contact to P's person. 2.1.2 Apparent ability is sufficient, as long as D's conduct could reasonably create P's apprehension, even if D appears incapable of accomplishing the threatened harm. 2.2 Of immediate harmful or offensive contact to P's person. 2.2.1 P must apprehend an immediate or imminent battery. 2.2.2 Words or threats alone are usually insufficient, unless coupled with some overt act (e.g., picking up a weapon, clenching fists). 2.2.3 Threats of future battery are insufficient. 2.3 Causation.

cards.easyContent: Assault is an intentional act that causes the plaintiff's reasonable apprehension of immediate harmful or offensive contact, based on D’s apparent ability to carry it out.
cards.mediumContent: Assault is an intentional act by D that creates P's reasonable apprehension of immediate harmful or offensive contact to P's person or something closely attached to it. P must be aware of D's act and reasonably expect an imminent battery. Apparent ability is enough, and words alone or threats of future harm are usually insufficient unless coupled with an overt act. Causation requires that D's conduct actually cause P's apprehension.
cards.hardContent: Assault is an intentional act by D that creates P's reasonable apprehension of immediate harmful or offensive contact to P's person or something closely attached to P's person (such as a hat or cane), and is often described as an attempted battery. The elements are: (1) an act by D that creates a reasonable apprehension in P; P must be aware of D's act and reasonably expect that it will result in immediate harmful or offensive contact, and D's apparent ability to carry out the threat is sufficient even if D is in fact incapable; (2) the apprehension must be of immediate or imminent battery—mere words or threats alone are usually insufficient unless accompanied by an overt act (e.g., picking up a weapon, clenching fists), and threats of future battery are insufficient; and (3) causation, meaning D's conduct actually causes P's apprehension.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 Battery is an intentional harmful or offensive contact to P's person by D. 2. Elements 2.1 Harmful or offensive contact by D. 2.1.1 Harmful contact is contact that causes pain, injury, or similar harm. 2.1.2 Contact is offensive if it would be considered offensive by a reasonable person and P has not consented. 2.2 Contact to P's person. 2.2.1 Includes anything closely connected to P's person (e.g., P's hat). 2.3 Intent. 2.4 Causation. 2.4.1 Indirect contact is sufficient, i.e., causing the force that gives rise to harmful or offensive contact. 2.4.2 For example: greasing a floor so that P will slip and fall.

cards.easyContent: Battery is an intentional harmful or offensive contact with the plaintiff’s person, including objects closely connected to them, and can be direct or indirect.
cards.mediumContent: Battery requires: (1) an intentional harmful or offensive contact by D; (2) contact with P's person, which includes items closely connected to P like clothing or objects in hand; (3) intent; and (4) causation. Harmful contact causes pain or injury, while offensive contact is that which a reasonable person would find offensive and to which P has not consented. Indirect contact, such as setting in motion a force that causes the contact, is sufficient.
cards.hardContent: Battery is an intentional harmful or offensive contact to P's person by D. The elements are: (1) harmful or offensive contact by D—harmful contact causes pain, injury, or similar harm, while offensive contact is that which would be considered offensive by a reasonable person and to which P has not consented; (2) contact with P's person, which includes anything closely connected to P's body, such as clothing, a cane, or a hat; (3) intent to cause the contact or substantial certainty that such contact will result; and (4) causation, which may be satisfied by direct or indirect contact, including causing a force that results in the harmful or offensive contact (for example, greasing a floor so that P slips and falls).

cards.clozeLite: Battery is {{c1::intentional harmful or offensive contact}} with {{c2::P's person (including connected objects)}}, and {{c3::direct or indirect contact}} is sufficient.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 False imprisonment is an intentional act by D resulting in P's restraint or confinement to a bounded area. 2. Elements 2.1 Act (or omission) resulting in P's restraint or confinement. 2.1.1 Restraint or confinement does not have to be physical. 2.1.2 For example: can be threats of force or invalid use of legal authority. 2.1.3 Duration is not important; brief confinement will suffice. 2.2 P is confined to a bounded area. 2.2.1 P must be aware of or harmed by the confinement. 2.2.2 P's freedom of movement must be limited. 2.2.3 P must not be aware of any reasonable means of escape. 2.2.4 If a reasonable person could get out (e.g., by opening an unlocked door), there is no false imprisonment. 2.3 Causation. 3. Shopkeeper's privilege 3.1 A store may detain a suspected thief if: 3.1.1 The store has reasonable cause to believe a theft occurred. 3.1.2 The store detains the suspect in a reasonable manner (only nondeadly force is permitted) for purposes of investigation. 3.1.3 The detention is reasonable in length and scope. 3.2 The shopkeeper may be held liable for any harm caused by acts exceeding the privilege.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of false imprisonment, including what counts as a bounded area, and what is the shopkeeper’s privilege?

cards.easyContent: False imprisonment is an intentional act that restrains or confines the plaintiff to a bounded area, with no reasonable means of escape known to P, and includes a limited shopkeeper’s privilege to detain suspected thieves reasonably.
cards.mediumContent: False imprisonment requires: (1) an intentional act or omission by D that results in P's restraint or confinement; (2) confinement to a bounded area, where P is aware of or harmed by the confinement, P's freedom of movement is limited, and P is unaware of any reasonable means of escape; and (3) causation. Restraint need not be physical and can include threats of force or misuse of legal authority, and even brief confinement is enough. Under the shopkeeper's privilege, a store may detain a suspected thief if it has reasonable cause, uses only nondeadly force in a reasonable manner for purposes of investigation, and the detention is reasonable in length and scope; exceeding these limits can create liability.
cards.hardContent: False imprisonment is an intentional act by D resulting in P's restraint or confinement to a bounded area. The elements are: (1) an act or omission that results in P's restraint or confinement, which need not be physical and may include threats of force or invalid use of legal authority; duration is not important and brief confinement suffices; (2) P is confined to a bounded area—P must be aware of or harmed by the confinement, P's freedom of movement must be limited, and P must not be aware of any reasonable means of escape; if a reasonable person could get out, such as by opening an unlocked door, there is no false imprisonment; and (3) causation. The shopkeeper's privilege allows a store to detain a suspected thief if it has reasonable cause to believe a theft occurred, detains the suspect in a reasonable manner using only nondeadly force, and limits the detention to a reasonable length and scope for purposes of investigation. A shopkeeper may be liable for any harm caused by acts exceeding this privilege.
cards.mnemonic: RAB: Restraint, Apparent Bounded area. Shopkeepers’ 3Rs: Reasonable cause, Reasonable manner, Reasonable time.
cards.clozeLite: False imprisonment requires {{c1::intentional confinement}} of P to a {{c2::bounded area}} with {{c3::no reasonable escape known to P}}. {{c4::Shopkeeper’s privilege}} allows {{c5::reasonable detention of suspected thieves}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 005. Intentional Inflection of Emotional Distress
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 Intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED) is extreme and outrageous conduct by D causing P's severe emotional distress. 2. Elements 2.1 Extreme and outrageous conduct by D. 2.1.1 Conduct that exceeds the bounds of decency in a civilized society. 2.1.2 Mere insults alone are insufficient. 2.1.3 Conduct must be outrageous to a reasonable person unless one of the following applies: 2.1.3.1 D targets P's known sensitivity or weakness. 2.1.3.2 D's conduct is continuous or repetitive. 2.1.3.3 D targets a P who is a member of a protected or vulnerable class (e.g., elderly, children, pregnant women). 2.1.3.4 D is a common carrier or innkeeper. 2.2 Severe emotional distress in P. 2.2.1 P must suffer severe emotional distress from D's conduct. 2.2.2 Physical symptoms are not necessary. Note: watch for facts indicating extreme, outrageous conduct but P does not suffer severe emotional harm—this is not IIED. 2.3 Intent or recklessness. 2.3.1 Intent includes purpose or knowledge with substantial certainty; recklessness is when D disregards the likely consequences of his acts. 2.4 Causation.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED), including what counts as extreme and outrageous conduct and the requirement of severe emotional distress?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 {{c2::Intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED)}} is {{c3::extreme and outrageous conduct}} by D causing P's {{c4::severe emotional distress}}. 2. {{c5::Elements}} 2.1 {{c6::Extreme and outrageous conduct}} by D. 2.1.1 Conduct that {{c7::exceeds the bounds of decency}} in a civilized society. 2.1.2 {{c8::Mere insults alone}} are insufficient. 2.1.3 Conduct must be outrageous to a reasonable person unless one of the following applies: 2.1.3.1 D targets P's {{c9::known sensitivity or weakness}}. 2.1.3.2 D's conduct is {{c10::continuous or repetitive}}. 2.1.3.3 D targets a P who is a member of a {{c11::protected or vulnerable class}} (e.g., elderly, children, pregnant women). 2.1.3.4 D is a {{c12::common carrier or innkeeper}}. 2.2 {{c13::Severe emotional distress}} in P. 2.2.1 P must suffer severe emotional distress from D's conduct. 2.2.2 {{c14::Physical symptoms are not necessary}}. Note: if P does not suffer severe emotional harm, there is no IIED even if D's conduct is extreme and outrageous. 2.3 {{c15::Intent or recklessness}}. 2.3.1 Intent includes purpose or knowledge with substantial certainty; {{c16::recklessness}} is when D disregards the likely consequences of his acts. 2.4 {{c17::Causation}}.
cards.easyContent: IIED requires extreme and outrageous conduct by D that intentionally or recklessly causes the plaintiff severe emotional distress; mere insults are not enough, but physical symptoms are not required.
cards.mediumContent: Intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED) occurs when D engages in extreme and outrageous conduct—conduct exceeding all bounds of decency—which intentionally or recklessly causes P severe emotional distress. Conduct must be outrageous to a reasonable person, though it is easier to find when D targets P's known sensitivities, repeatedly engages in the conduct, targets vulnerable groups (like children, elderly, or pregnant women), or is a common carrier or innkeeper. P must suffer severe emotional distress, but physical symptoms are not required, and there is no IIED if P's distress is not severe. D must act with intent or recklessness and D's conduct must cause P's distress.
cards.hardContent: Intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED) is defined as extreme and outrageous conduct by D causing P's severe emotional distress. The elements are: (1) extreme and outrageous conduct, meaning conduct that exceeds the bounds of decency in a civilized society; mere insults alone are insufficient, and the conduct must be outrageous to a reasonable person, though courts more readily find outrageousness where D targets P's known sensitivity or weakness, where D's conduct is continuous or repetitive, where D targets a member of a protected or vulnerable class (such as the elderly, children, or pregnant women), or where D is a common carrier or innkeeper; (2) severe emotional distress in P—P must actually suffer severe emotional distress as a result of D's conduct, though physical symptoms are not necessary, and if P does not suffer severe distress there is no IIED even if D's conduct is extreme and outrageous; (3) intent or recklessness, where intent includes purpose or knowledge with substantial certainty and recklessness means D consciously disregards the likely consequences of his acts; and (4) causation, meaning D's conduct actually causes P's severe emotional distress.
cards.mnemonic: IIED is E-ISIC: Extreme, Intent/Reckless, Severe distress, Insults not enough, Causation.
cards.clozeLite: IIED requires {{c1::extreme and outrageous conduct}} that {{c2::intentionally or recklessly}} causes {{c3::severe emotional distress}}; {{c4::mere insults are not enough}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Bystander Claims for Emotional Distress: 1. General rule: When D's conduct is directed at a third person and P (the bystander) suffers severe emotional distress, P must prove the same IIED elements with additional intent and causation requirements. 2. Elements (IIED): 2.1 Extreme and outrageous conduct by D. 2.2 Severe emotional distress in P. 2.3 Intent or recklessness. 2.4 Causation. 3. Additional bystander requirements: 3.1 P was present at the time of D's conduct. 3.2 P was a close relative of the third person, or P's distress resulted in bodily harm. 3.3 D knew these facts. 4. Note: P does not need to establish the additional bystander requirements if P proves D had a design or purpose to cause severe distress to P.

cards.easyContent: A bystander can recover for IIED when D harms a third person if the bystander meets the normal IIED elements and special bystander rules.
cards.mediumContent: For bystander IIED, P must show extreme and outrageous conduct by D, intent or recklessness, causation, and severe emotional distress, plus that P was present, was a close relative or suffered bodily harm, and D knew these facts—unless D specifically intended to cause severe distress to P.
cards.hardContent: For bystander claims for intentional infliction of emotional distress, when D's conduct is directed at a third person and P suffers severe emotional distress, P must prove the ordinary IIED elements—extreme and outrageous conduct by D, intent or recklessness, causation, and severe emotional distress—plus the bystander requirements that P was present at the time of D's conduct, P was a close relative of the third person or P's distress resulted in bodily harm, and D knew these facts. P need not prove the additional bystander requirements if P can show D acted with a design or purpose to cause severe distress to P.
cards.mnemonic: Bystander IIED is P.C.K.: Present, Close relative/bodily harm, Known by D.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Trespass to land is a physical entry of P's real property by D without consent. 2. Elements: 2.1 Physical entry of P's real property by D. 2.1.1 D enters P's property or propels an object onto it. 2.1.2 Examples: D walks on P's property, throws a ball onto P's property, or chases someone onto P's property. 2.1.3 P need only have lawful possession of the property; ownership is not required. 2.1.4 There must be a physical invasion; invasions by light, sound, or smell are not trespass. 2.1.5 P's real property includes the surface, immediate airspace, and subterranean space to a reasonable distance. 2.2 Intent. 2.2.1 Intent to enter the land will suffice, even if D acts under a reasonable mistake. 2.2.2 D does not need to know the land belongs to another. 2.3 Causation. 3. Note: Actual damages are not required; compare to trespass to chattel and conversion.

cards.easyContent: Trespass to land is any physical, intentional entry onto another's real property without consent; no actual damages are required.
cards.mediumContent: Trespass to land requires an intentional physical entry onto P's real property (including surface, immediate airspace, and reasonable subterranean space) without consent, where P has lawful possession. Intent to enter suffices even if D reasonably mistakes ownership, and no actual damages are needed.
cards.hardContent: Trespass to land occurs when D makes a physical entry onto P's real property without consent. The elements are: (1) physical entry of P's real property by D, either by entering himself or propelling an object onto it; (2) intent—intent to enter the land is sufficient, even if D reasonably mistakes who owns it, and D need not know the land belongs to another; and (3) causation. P need only have lawful possession, not ownership. The entry must be a physical invasion; invasions by light, sound, or smell are not trespass. P's real property includes the surface, immediate airspace, and subterranean space to a reasonable distance. Actual damages are not required, unlike trespass to chattel and conversion.
cards.mnemonic: T-EA: Trespass = physical Entry onto Another's land with intent, no damages.
cards.clozeLite: Trespass to land requires {{c1::intentional physical entry}} onto {{c2::P's real property}} {{c3::without consent}}, and {{c4::no actual damages}} are required.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Trespass to chattel and conversion are two separate but similar torts; the difference is the level of interference with P's property and the damages P can recover. 2. Elements: 2.1 D intentionally interferes with P's right of possession in tangible personal property (chattel). 2.1.1 Interference usually occurs through dispossession (depriving P of possessory rights in the chattel) or damaging P's chattel. 2.1.2 Trespass to chattel: minor interference or damage. 2.1.3 Conversion: significant interference or damage that justifies D paying the chattel's full value. 2.1.4 A longer and/or more damaging use of P's chattel gives rise to conversion. 2.2 Intent. 2.3 Causation. 2.4 Damages: P must have some loss of use. 2.4.1 Trespass to chattel: P can recover cost of repair or rental value of the chattel. 2.4.2 Conversion: P can recover full market value at the time of conversion or repossess the chattel (replevin).
cards.frontPrompt: What are trespass to chattel and conversion, and how do their elements and remedies differ based on the level of interference?

Elements: 2.1 D {{c5::intentionally interferes with P's right of possession}} in {{c6::tangible personal property (chattel)}}. 2.1.1 Interference usually occurs through {{c7::dispossession}} (depriving P of possessory rights in the chattel) or {{c8::damaging P's chattel}}. 2.1.2 {{c9::Trespass to chattel}}: {{c10::minor interference or damage}}. 2.1.3 {{c11::Conversion}}: {{c12::significant interference or damage}} that justifies D paying the chattel's {{c13::full value}}. 2.1.4 A {{c14::longer and/or more damaging use}} of P's chattel gives rise to conversion. 2.2 {{c15::Intent}}. 2.3 {{c16::Causation}}. 2.4 {{c17::Damages}}: P must have {{c18::some loss of use}}. 2.4.1 Trespass to chattel: P can recover {{c19::cost of repair}} or {{c20::rental value}} of the chattel. 2.4.2 Conversion: P can recover {{c21::full market value at the time of conversion}} or {{c22::repossess the chattel (replevin)}}.
cards.easyContent: Trespass to chattel is minor, intentional interference with another's chattel causing loss of use; conversion is major interference justifying payment of the chattel's full value or return of the item.
cards.mediumContent: Both trespass to chattel and conversion require intentional interference with P's possessory rights in tangible personal property, causation, and some loss of use. Trespass to chattel covers minor interference or damage, with recovery for repair or rental value, while conversion involves significant interference or prolonged use, allowing recovery of full market value or replevin.
cards.hardContent: Trespass to chattel and conversion are similar torts differentiated by the degree of interference and the remedy. D is liable when he intentionally interferes with P's right of possession in tangible personal property (chattel), usually by dispossessing P or damaging the chattel, with intent and causation. Trespass to chattel applies to minor interference or damage, and P can recover the cost of repair or the rental value of the chattel, but must show some loss of use. Conversion applies where there is significant interference, longer and/or more damaging use, or destruction, such that it is just for D to pay the chattel's full value; P may recover the full market value at the time of conversion or seek return of the item via replevin.
cards.mnemonic: TIC: Trespass = Interference small; Conversion = Interference colossal.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Consent: 1. General rule: Consent is a defense to all intentional torts—if P consents to D's otherwise tortious conduct, D is not liable for that act. 1.1 Capacity required: P must be capable of consenting. 1.2 Examples: Drunks, mentally impaired persons, and young children are generally incapable of consenting to tortious conduct. 2. Express consent: P gives D verbal or written consent; this is nullified by duress, fraud, or certain mistakes. 3. Implied consent: D can reasonably infer P's consent based on custom or P's observable conduct. 3.1 Implied consent often arises if P participates in an activity or goes to a place where torts are common. 3.2 Example: If P plays tackle football, P has given implied consent to certain forms of battery. 3.3 Consent is usually implied for ordinary contacts of daily life (e.g., brushing against someone on a crowded sidewalk or public transportation). 3.4 Facts must indicate that, based on P's objective conduct, D was reasonable in interpreting P's consent. 4. Scope of consent: D can be held liable for conduct that exceeds the scope of P's valid consent (express or implied).

cards.easyContent: Consent is a complete defense to intentional torts if P has capacity and validly consents, and D stays within the scope of that consent.
cards.mediumContent: Consent, express or implied, is a defense to all intentional torts if P has capacity. Express consent is given verbally or in writing but is invalid if obtained by duress, fraud, or certain mistakes. cards.hardContent: Consent operates as a defense to all intentional torts where P validly agrees to conduct that would otherwise be tortious. P must have capacity to consent; drunks, mentally impaired persons, and young children are generally deemed incapable. Consent may be express, via verbal or written agreement, but is nullified if procured by duress, fraud, or certain mistakes. Consent may also be implied when D can reasonably infer consent from custom or P's observable, objective conduct, such as participating in activities or entering places where torts are common (e.g., contact sports) or through ordinary social contact in crowded settings. The facts must show that D was reasonable in interpreting P's conduct as consent. Even where consent exists, D becomes liable if his conduct exceeds the scope of P's valid consent, whether express or implied.

cards.rawHeader: Torts 010. Self Defense, Defense of Others, and Defense of Property
cards.front: Self Defense, Defense of Others, and Defense of Property – Overview
cards.backPlain: Protective defenses to intentional torts—self-defense, defense of others, and defense of property—share common requirements: 1. Common requirements for protective defenses: 1.1 Reasonable belief: D must reasonably believe a tort is being committed or is about to be committed. 1.2 Proper timing: The tort must be in progress or imminent. 1.3 Reasonable force: The force used must be proportionate to the threat of harm. 1.3.1 Deadly force is allowed only if D reasonably believes a life is in danger; it is never permitted to protect property alone. 2. Specific doctrines: 2.1 Self-defense: No duty to retreat in most jurisdictions; minority requires safe retreat before deadly force. Initial aggressors have limited access to self-defense. 2.2 Defense of others: D steps into the shoes of the person aided and must reasonably believe that person has a right to self-defense. 2.3 Defense of property: Only reasonable, non-deadly force to prevent torts against property; not available against privileged entrants, and mistakes are limited.
cards.frontPrompt: What core requirements apply to self-defense, defense of others, and defense of property as protective defenses, and how do these doctrines differ at a high level?
cards.cloze: Protective defenses to intentional torts—{{c1::self-defense}}, {{c2::defense of others}}, and {{c3::defense of property}}—share common requirements: 1. {{c4::Reasonable belief}} that a tort is being committed or is about to be committed. 2. {{c5::Proper timing}}: the threat must be {{c6::in progress or imminent}}. 3. {{c7::Reasonable, proportionate force}}. - {{c8::Deadly force}} is allowed only if D reasonably believes a {{c9::life is in danger}} and is {{c10::never permitted to protect property alone}}. Self-defense governs threats to oneself (with retreat and initial-aggressor rules), defense of others applies when aiding someone who would have self-defense, and defense of property allows only reasonable, non-deadly force and is limited by privileges and mistake rules.
cards.easyContent: Self-defense, defense of others, and defense of property all require a reasonable belief in an imminent tort and proportionate force. Deadly force is allowed only to protect life, never property alone. Each doctrine then has its own specific rules (self-defense: retreat and initial aggressor limits; defense of others: stepping into the aided person’s shoes; defense of property: only non-deadly force and limits based on privilege and mistakes).
cards.mediumContent: All three protective defenses require: (1) a reasonable belief that a tort is occurring or imminent; (2) proper timing (in progress or imminent); and (3) proportionate force. Deadly force is permitted only when D reasonably believes a life is in danger and is never allowed solely to protect property. Self-defense adds rules about retreat (no duty in most jurisdictions, minority retreat rule for deadly force) and about when an initial aggressor can reclaim self-defense. Defense of others requires that D reasonably believe the person aided has a right to self-defense. Defense of property allows only reasonable, non-deadly force to prevent torts against property, is unavailable against privileged entrants, and narrowly permits mistakes only about whether an intrusion occurred.
cards.hardContent: Protective defenses—self-defense, defense of others, and defense of property—share core elements: D must reasonably believe a tort is being or is about to be committed; the threat must be in progress or imminent; and the force used must be proportionate to the threat of harm. Deadly force is strictly limited: it is allowed only if D reasonably believes a life is in danger and is never permitted solely to protect property. Self-defense additionally includes jurisdictional rules on retreat (no duty in most jurisdictions, with a minority requiring safe retreat before deadly force) and restrictions on initial aggressors (who can claim self-defense only after the initial threat has ended or if the other party escalates from non-deadly to deadly force). Defense of others requires D to reasonably believe that the person aided would have a valid claim of self-defense and allows D to use as much force as if the threat were to himself. Defense of property applies only to torts against property and is limited to reasonable, non-deadly force; it does not apply against entrants with a privilege to be on the property, and reasonable mistakes are allowed only as to whether an intrusion occurred, not as to whether a privilege existed.
cards.mnemonic: R-T-F, Life not Things: Reasonable belief, proper Timing, proportionate Force, deadly force only for lives.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) common elements of protective defenses and deadly-force limits; (2) self-defense (including retreat and initial aggressor rules); (3) defense of others; (4) defense of property (including mistake and privilege limits).
cards.clozeLite: All three {{c1::protective defenses}} require a {{c2::reasonable belief in an imminent tort}} and {{c3::proportionate force}}; {{c4::deadly force}} is only to {{c5::protect life, never property alone}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule 1.1 Necessity is a defense to torts against property (trespass to land, trespass to chattels, conversion) when the defendant damages the plaintiff's property in an effort to avoid a greater danger. 1.2 Requirements: 1.2.1 The defendant's interference with the plaintiff's property must be reasonably necessary to avoid an immediate threatened injury. 1.2.2 The threatened injury must be more serious than the interference undertaken to avert it. 2. Public Necessity 2.1 Public necessity is an absolute defense. 2.2 The defendant's invasion of the plaintiff's property must be reasonably necessary to protect the community or a large group of people. 2.3 Because it is an absolute defense, the plaintiff cannot recover any damages. 3. Private Necessity 3.1 Private necessity is a limited defense. 3.2 The defendant invades the plaintiff's property to protect the defendant's own property, self, or a small group. 3.3 Because it is a limited defense, the plaintiff can recover damages for actual harm to the plaintiff's property, unless the defendant trespassed for the plaintiff's benefit. 4. Property Owner Liability 4.1 If a property owner repels or expels a trespasser who interfered with or invaded the owner's property out of a valid necessity (for example, the trespasser seeks shelter from a terrible storm), 4.2 The owner will be liable for any damage caused to the trespasser.

cards.easyContent: Necessity is a defense to property torts when a defendant interferes with property to avoid a greater, immediate danger. Public necessity is an absolute defense with no liability, while private necessity is limited and requires payment for actual damage.
cards.mediumContent: Necessity applies when a defendant reasonably interferes with another's property to avoid an immediate threatened injury that is more serious than the interference. Public necessity, used to protect the community or a large group, is an absolute defense with no damages. Private necessity, used to protect the defendant’s own interests or a small group, is a limited defense: the defendant is not a trespasser but must pay for actual harm, and a property owner who uses force against a validly necessitous trespasser is liable for resulting injuries.
cards.hardContent: Necessity is a defense to torts against property (trespass to land, trespass to chattels, conversion) when the defendant damages the plaintiff's property in an effort to avoid a greater danger. The interference must be reasonably necessary to avoid an immediate threatened injury, and the threatened injury must be more serious than the interference. Public necessity is an absolute defense where the defendant's invasion is reasonably necessary to protect the community or a large group; the plaintiff cannot recover damages. Private necessity is a limited defense where the defendant invades property to protect the defendant's own property, self, or a small group; the plaintiff may recover damages for actual harm to the property, unless the trespass was for the plaintiff’s benefit. If a property owner repels or expels someone who entered under a valid necessity (e.g., seeking shelter from a storm), the owner is liable for any damage caused to that person.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule 1.1 The defendant has a legal privilege to use peaceful means to recover possession of chattel taken unlawfully, and may use reasonable, non-deadly force if in fresh pursuit of the chattel-taker. 1.2 Recapture of chattels is also a defense to assault, battery, and false imprisonment. 2. Limitations and Requirements 2.1 The defendant-owner must make a timely demand for return of the chattel. 2.2 Exception to demand requirement: 2.2.1 A demand is not required if making the demand would be futile or dangerous. 2.2.2 The defendant-owner may recapture from the original wrongdoer or a third person who knows the chattel was wrongfully obtained. 2.2.3 Recapture is not available if the chattel is in the hands of an innocent party. 3. Use of Force 3.1 Reasonable force may be used to recapture the chattel only if the defendant is in fresh pursuit of one who has wrongfully obtained possession. 3.2 No deadly force or force likely to cause serious bodily harm is permitted.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Defamation is a false statement of fact about the plaintiff, published to at least one third person, that harms the plaintiff’s reputation. At common law, the core elements are: (1) a false and defamatory statement of fact; (2) that concerns the plaintiff; (3) publication to at least one third person; and (4) harm to reputation. Falsity and fault are always part of the analysis, though constitutional law determines who must prove falsity or truth and what level of fault is required. Liability extends to those who republish defamatory statements, subject to special federal protection for internet service providers. Damages, and the plaintiff’s burden to prove them, vary based on the type of plaintiff, whether the matter is of public concern, and whether the defamation is libel, slander, or slander per se. Truth is a complete defense.

cards.mediumContent: Defamation requires a false and defamatory statement of fact about the plaintiff, publication to at least one third person, and harm to reputation. Liability generally extends to those who republish defamation, though federal law shields ISPs from liability for user content. cards.hardContent: Defamation is a false statement of fact concerning the plaintiff, made by the defendant to at least one person other than the plaintiff, that is harmful to the plaintiff's reputation. At common law, the elements are: (1) a false and defamatory statement of fact that adversely affects the plaintiff’s reputation and is based on specific facts; (2) that is reasonably understood to concern a living plaintiff or a very small group of plaintiffs; (3) publication, meaning intentional or negligent communication to at least one third person; and (4) harm to reputation. Falsity and fault are always part of the defamation analysis, but constitutional doctrine allocates who must prove falsity or truth and imposes fault standards in many cases. Liability generally extends to republishers to the same extent as original publishers, though federal statute protects internet service providers from liability for content posted by others. The plaintiff’s damages burden varies with the type of plaintiff, whether the matter is of public concern, and whether the defamation is libel, slander, or slander per se. Truth is a complete defense.

cards.backPlain: Constitutional Considerations 1. General Rule 1.1 First Amendment considerations arise when defamation involves a public figure, public official, and/or a matter of public concern. 2. Public Figures and Public Officials 2.1 Public figure: A person who has pervasive fame or notoriety, or who voluntarily assumes a central role in a public matter. 2.2 Public official: A public office holder. 3. Additional Elements: Fault 3.1 The plaintiff must prove that the defendant was at fault, with standards differing for public versus private figures. 3.2 Public official or public figure: The plaintiff must prove "actual malice," meaning knowledge of the statement's falsity or reckless disregard as to whether it was false. 3.3 Private figure: The minimum constitutional standard is negligence with respect to truth or falsity. 4. Falsity 4.1 Public officials and public figures must prove falsity. 4.2 Private figures must prove falsity only if the speech pertains to a matter of public concern. 4.3 If the plaintiff is a private figure and the speech is a matter of purely private concern, states may place the burden on the defendant to prove truth.

cards.easyContent: When defamation involves public officials, public figures, or matters of public concern, the First Amendment requires the plaintiff to prove fault and often falsity. cards.mediumContent: Constitutional defamation rules apply when the plaintiff is a public official or public figure, or when the speech involves a matter of public concern. cards.hardContent: First Amendment constraints modify defamation law when the case involves a public figure, public official, or a matter of public concern. cards.backPlain: Damages Considerations 1. In General 1.1 Damages depend on the type of plaintiff, the content of the statement, and whether the defamatory statement constitutes libel, slander, or slander per se. 2. Libel 2.1 Libel is a written or otherwise recorded (including TV and radio broadcasts) defamatory statement. 2.2 Public figures and public officials who prove the constitutional requirements (falsity and actual malice) may recover presumed and punitive damages for reputational harm without any proof of actual damages. 2.3 Private figures who prove only negligence may recover presumed or punitive damages only if the speech relates to a matter of private concern. 2.4 If the speech involves a matter of public concern and the plaintiff is a private figure, the plaintiff may recover only proved actual damages unless actual malice is also shown. 2.5 Note: TV and radio broadcasts are treated as libel. 3. Slander 3.1 Slander is a spoken defamatory statement. 3.2 The plaintiff must generally prove special damages (a specific economic loss) unless the statement constitutes slander per se. 4. Slander Per Se 4.1 Slander per se is slander that falls into certain categories where damages are presumed. It includes statements that: 4.1.1 Adversely reflect on the plaintiff's business or professional reputation; 4.1.2 Claim that the plaintiff has a loathsome disease; 4.1.3 Claim that the plaintiff committed a crime of moral turpitude; or 4.1.4 Impute a woman's lack of chastity (often modernized as serious sexual misconduct).

cards.easyContent: Libel is written or recorded defamation, and damages are generally easier to obtain, especially for public plaintiffs who prove actual malice. Slander is spoken defamation, usually requiring special damages, except in slander per se categories where damages are presumed.
cards.mediumContent: Damages in defamation depend on whether the statement is libel, slander, or slander per se, plus the plaintiff’s status and whether the matter is of public or private concern. Libel covers written or recorded statements (including TV and radio) and allows public officials and figures who prove falsity and actual malice to recover presumed and punitive damages without proving actual loss. Private figures who show only negligence may get presumed or punitive damages only for speech on private concerns; for matters of public concern, they are limited to proved actual damages unless they show actual malice. Slander is spoken defamation and generally requires proof of special damages, but in slander per se categories—business/profession, loathsome disease, crime of moral turpitude, or unchastity—damages are presumed.
cards.hardContent: Damages in defamation actions vary with the plaintiff’s status, the nature of the speech, and whether the defamation is libel, slander, or slander per se. Libel is written or otherwise recorded defamation, including TV and radio broadcasts. Public officials and public figures who satisfy constitutional requirements—proving falsity and actual malice—may recover presumed and punitive damages for reputational harm without showing actual damages. Private figures who prove only negligence may recover presumed or punitive damages only if the speech involves a matter of private concern; if it involves a matter of public concern, they are limited to proved actual damages unless they also show actual malice. Slander is spoken defamation, and plaintiffs ordinarily must prove special damages (specific economic loss). However, in slander per se, where the slander falls into recognized categories—statements adversely reflecting on the plaintiff’s business or professional reputation, alleging a loathsome disease, accusing a crime of moral turpitude, or imputing a woman’s lack of chastity—damages are presumed.
cards.mnemonic: "Libel lasts, slander spends"; plus BDCC for slander per se.
cards.clozeLite: In defamation, {{c1::libel}} generally allows {{c2::presumed damages}}, while {{c3::slander}} needs {{c4::special damages}} unless it is {{c5::slander per se}}.

cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 Consent, truth, and privilege are valid defenses to defamation. 2. Consent 2.1 P consents to one or more required elements of defamation. 2.2 For example, P may consent to an organization investigating her and sharing its findings with potential employers. 3. Truth 3.1 The allegedly defamatory statement is true. 3.2 Truth is a complete defense to a defamation claim. 4. Privilege 4.1 Certain types of statements are privileged. 4.2 Absolute privilege protects statements by government officials in their official capacity. 4.3 Qualified privilege limits D's liability for defamatory statements where: 4.3.1 D is invited to make the statement and/or the recipient has an interest in the information (for example, an employment reference, credit report, or letter of recommendation); or 4.3.2 The statement is in the public interest (for example, book reviews or a statement to a parole board).

cards.easyContent: Defamation defendants can avoid liability through consent, truth, and privilege. Truth is a complete defense, and some statements are protected by absolute or qualified privilege.
cards.mediumContent: Defenses to defamation include: (1) consent—P agrees to one or more elements of defamation, such as an investigation and sharing of results; (2) truth—the statement is true, which is a complete defense; and (3) privilege—absolute privilege for statements by government officials acting in their official capacity and qualified privilege where the statement is invited or the recipient has an interest, or where the statement is in the public interest.
cards.hardContent: Defenses to defamation are consent, truth, and privilege. Consent applies when P consents to one or more elements of defamation, such as consenting to an organization's investigation and dissemination of findings to potential employers. Truth is a complete defense if the allegedly defamatory statement is true. Privilege protects certain statements: absolute privilege shields statements made by government officials in their official capacity, and qualified privilege limits D's liability for statements made in situations where D is invited to speak or the recipient has an interest in the information (e.g., employment references, credit reports, letters of recommendation), or where the statement is in the public interest (e.g., book reviews, statements to a parole board).
cards.mnemonic: Defamation defenses are CTP: Consent, Truth, Privilege.
cards.clozeLite: Defamation defenses are {{c1::consent}}, {{c2::truth (a complete defense)}}, and {{c3::privilege (absolute or qualified)}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. Appropriation 1.1 Definition: Use of P's name or likeness for commercial purposes (for example, promotion or advertisement) without P's consent. 1.2 Newsworthiness exception: No liability for use of P's name or likeness for the purpose of reporting news. 2. False light 2.1 Definition: Widespread publication of a falsehood or material misrepresentation about P that would be highly offensive to a reasonable person. 2.2 Includes mischaracterization of P's views or conduct. 2.3 Matters of public concern: D must have actual malice or reckless disregard for the truth of the matter publicized. 2.4 Note: This mirrors the constitutional considerations for defamation. 2.5 No newsworthiness exception. 3. Defenses to false light 3.1 Consent: A valid defense, although D may be liable if his actions exceed the consent given. Mistake as to whether consent was given is not a valid defense. 3.2 Privilege: May be available as a defense to false light if D has an absolute or qualified privilege to publication. 3.3 Truth is not a valid defense to invasion of privacy claims, including false light.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of the privacy torts of appropriation and false light, including any newsworthiness rules and defenses?

Appropriation 1.1 Definition: Use of P's {{c1::name or likeness}} for {{c2::commercial purposes}} (for example, promotion or advertisement) without {{c3::P's consent}}. 1.2 {{c4::Newsworthiness exception}}: No liability for use of P's name or likeness for the purpose of {{c5::reporting news}}. 2. False light 2.1 Definition: {{c6::Widespread publication}} of a {{c7::falsehood or material misrepresentation}} about P that would be {{c8::highly offensive to a reasonable person}}. 2.2 Includes {{c9::mischaracterization of P's views or conduct}}. 2.3 Matters of public concern: D must have {{c10::actual malice or reckless disregard for the truth}} of the matter publicized. 2.4 Note: This mirrors the {{c11::constitutional considerations for defamation}}. 2.5 {{c12::No newsworthiness exception}} for false light. 3. Defenses to false light 3.1 {{c13::Consent}}: A valid defense, although D may be liable if his actions {{c14::exceed the consent given}}. {{c15::Mistake as to whether consent was given}} is not a valid defense. 3.2 {{c16::Privilege}}: May be available as a defense to false light if D has an {{c17::absolute or qualified privilege}} to publication. 3.3 {{c18::Truth is not a valid defense}} to invasion of privacy claims, including false light.
cards.easyContent: Appropriation is using someone's name or likeness for commercial purposes without consent, with a newsworthiness exception. False light is widely publishing false or misleading material about P that is highly offensive, with constitutional actual-malice requirements for matters of public concern.
cards.mediumContent: Appropriation requires use of P's name or likeness for commercial purposes, without consent, but there is no liability when the use is for reporting news. False light requires widespread publication of a falsehood or material misrepresentation about P that would be highly offensive to a reasonable person and may mischaracterize P's views or conduct. For matters of public concern, D must act with actual malice or reckless disregard for truth, paralleling defamation doctrine, and there is no newsworthiness exception. Defenses to false light include consent (though exceeding its scope or relying on a mistaken belief in consent defeats the defense) and privilege; truth is not a defense to privacy torts.
cards.hardContent: Appropriation is the use of P's name or likeness for commercial purposes, such as promotion or advertisement, without P's consent. There is a newsworthiness exception: there is no liability for using P's name or likeness to report the news. False light involves widespread publication of a falsehood or material misrepresentation about P that would be highly offensive to a reasonable person, including mischaracterizing P's views or conduct. When the matter is of public concern, D must have actual malice or reckless disregard for the truth, tracking the constitutional standards applied in defamation. Unlike appropriation, there is no newsworthiness exception for false light. Defenses to false light include consent (though D remains liable if he exceeds the scope of consent and cannot rely on a mistaken belief that consent was given) and privilege, where D has an absolute or qualified privilege to publish. Truth, however, is not a defense to invasion of privacy claims, including false light.
cards.mnemonic: Privacy pair: "APP Ad" (appropriation = ad use) vs. "FLARE" (false light, malice for public concern).
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Appropriation}} is using P's name or likeness for {{c2::commercial purposes without consent}}, with a {{c3::newsworthiness exception}}. {{c4::False light}} is widespread publication of {{c5::highly offensive false or misleading material}} about P, requiring {{c6::actual malice for matters of public concern}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 018. Intrusion Upon Seclusion and Disclosure
cards.backPlain: 1. Intrusion upon seclusion 1.1 Definition: Intrusion upon P's private affairs in a manner that would be highly offensive to a reasonable person. 1.2 Requirements 1.2.1 P must have a reasonable expectation of privacy. 1.2.1.1 There is no reasonable expectation of privacy in public. 1.2.2 The intrusion must be highly offensive. 1.2.2.1 For example, peeping, eavesdropping, or using hidden cameras in P's domain. 1.3 No newsworthiness exception. 2. Disclosure (public disclosure of private facts) 2.1 Definition: Public disclosure of P's private information. 2.2 Requirements (the disclosure must be): 2.2.1 Highly offensive to a reasonable person. 2.2.1.1 Public activities are not objectionable. 2.2.1.2 For example, D announces that the mayor frequents strip clubs—no liability because the acts occur in public. 2.2.2 Publicized: Made available to a public audience. 2.2.3 Subject to a newsworthiness exception: No liability if otherwise private facts are newsworthy. 3. Defenses 3.1 Consent is a valid defense. 3.2 Privilege is a valid defense to disclosure.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of the privacy torts of intrusion upon seclusion and public disclosure of private facts, including expectations of privacy, offensiveness, publicity, and newsworthiness?
cards.cloze: 1. Intrusion upon seclusion 1.1 Definition: Intrusion upon P's {{c1::private affairs}} in a manner that would be {{c2::highly offensive to a reasonable person}}. 1.2 Requirements 1.2.1 P must have a {{c3::reasonable expectation of privacy}}. 1.2.1.1 There is {{c4::no reasonable expectation of privacy in public}}. 1.2.2 The intrusion must be {{c5::highly offensive}}. 1.2.2.1 For example, {{c6::peeping, eavesdropping, or using hidden cameras}} in P's domain. 1.3 {{c7::No newsworthiness exception}} for intrusion. 2. Disclosure (public disclosure of private facts) 2.1 Definition: {{c8::Public disclosure}} of P's {{c9::private information}}. 2.2 Requirements (the disclosure must be): 2.2.1 {{c10::Highly offensive to a reasonable person}}. 2.2.1.1 {{c11::Public activities are not objectionable}}. 2.2.1.2 For example, D announces that the mayor frequents strip clubs—no liability because the acts occur {{c12::in public}}. 2.2.2 {{c13::Publicized}}: Made available to a public audience. 2.2.3 Subject to a {{c14::newsworthiness exception}}: No liability if otherwise private facts are {{c15::newsworthy}}. 3. Defenses 3.1 {{c16::Consent}} is a valid defense. 3.2 {{c17::Privilege}} is a valid defense to disclosure.
cards.easyContent: Intrusion upon seclusion is an offensive invasion into someone's private affairs where they reasonably expect privacy, with no newsworthiness exception. Public disclosure of private facts is highly offensive publicity of private information, but there is a newsworthiness exception.
cards.mediumContent: Intrusion upon seclusion requires an intentional intrusion into P's private affairs that would be highly offensive to a reasonable person, where P has a reasonable expectation of privacy (no such expectation in public). Classic examples include peeping, eavesdropping, or hidden cameras; there is no newsworthiness exception. Disclosure of private facts requires public disclosure of P's private information that is highly offensive to a reasonable person, made available to a public audience; public activities are not objectionable, and liability is avoided if the disclosed facts are newsworthy. Consent and privilege are defenses, particularly to disclosure.
cards.hardContent: Intrusion upon seclusion consists of an intrusion into P's private affairs in a manner that would be highly offensive to a reasonable person. P must have a reasonable expectation of privacy, and there is no such expectation in public. The intrusion itself must be highly offensive, as with peeping, eavesdropping, or the use of hidden cameras in P's domain. There is no newsworthiness exception for intrusion. Public disclosure of private facts involves the public disclosure of P's private information. The disclosure must be highly offensive to a reasonable person, and merely public activities are not actionable (for example, D announces that the mayor frequents strip clubs, which occur in public). The information must be publicized, meaning made available to a public audience, but there is a newsworthiness exception: no liability if the private facts disclosed are newsworthy. Consent and privilege operate as defenses, especially to disclosure claims.
cards.mnemonic: Intrusion is PEEP in private; disclosure is HOT facts made public unless newsworthy.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Intrusion upon seclusion}} is an offensive invasion into {{c2::private affairs with a reasonable expectation of privacy}} and {{c3::no newsworthiness exception}}. {{c4::Disclosure of private facts}} requires {{c5::highly offensive publicity of private, non-newsworthy information}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Malicious Prosecution and Abuse of Process
cards.rawHeader: Torts 019. Malicious Prosecution and Abuse of Process
cards.front: Malicious Prosecution and Abuse of Process
cards.backPlain: 1. Malicious prosecution 1.1 Definition: D initiates a frivolous charge or claim against P with an improper purpose (for example, filing a false police report). 1.2 Elements 1.2.1 D commenced a prior criminal or civil legal proceeding against P. (Note: Prosecutors are immune.) 1.2.2 The prior proceeding terminated in P's favor. 1.2.3 There was no probable cause for the original proceeding (for example, D knew P was not guilty in a criminal case or not liable in a civil case, or D had insufficient facts to reasonably believe in P's guilt or fault). 1.2.4 D had an improper purpose in initiating the proceeding. 1.2.5 P suffered damages. 2. Abuse of process 2.1 Definition: D uses the legal system for an ulterior purpose to threaten or act against P. 2.2 Elements 2.2.1 Wrongful use of process for an ulterior purpose. 2.2.2 A definite act or threat against P to accomplish that ulterior purpose.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of the torts of malicious prosecution and abuse of process, and how do they differ?
cards.cloze: 1. Malicious prosecution 1.1 Definition: D initiates a {{c1::frivolous charge or claim}} against P with an {{c2::improper purpose}} (for example, filing a false police report). 1.2 Elements 1.2.1 D {{c3::commenced a prior criminal or civil legal proceeding}} against P. (Note: {{c4::Prosecutors are immune}}.) 1.2.2 The prior proceeding {{c5::terminated in P's favor}}. 1.2.3 There was {{c6::no probable cause}} for the original proceeding (for example, D knew P was not guilty in a criminal case or not liable in a civil case, or D had {{c7::insufficient facts to reasonably believe}} in P's guilt or fault). 1.2.4 D had an {{c8::improper purpose}} in initiating the proceeding. 1.2.5 P suffered {{c9::damages}}. 2. Abuse of process 2.1 Definition: D {{c10::uses the legal system}} for an {{c11::ulterior purpose}} to threaten or act against P. 2.2 Elements 2.2.1 {{c12::Wrongful use of process}} for an ulterior purpose. 2.2.2 A {{c13::definite act or threat}} against P to accomplish that ulterior purpose.
cards.easyContent: Malicious prosecution is bringing a prior case against P without probable cause and for an improper purpose, which ends in P's favor and causes damages. Abuse of process is using legal process for an ulterior purpose, with a definite act or threat to achieve that purpose.
cards.mediumContent: For malicious prosecution, D must have commenced a prior criminal or civil proceeding against P, the prior case must terminate in P's favor, there must have been no probable cause (i.e., D lacked a reasonable basis for believing P was guilty or liable), D acted with an improper purpose, and P suffered damages; prosecutors are immune. Abuse of process occurs when D wrongfully uses legal process for an ulterior purpose and commits a definite act or threat against P to accomplish that improper aim.
cards.hardContent: Malicious prosecution requires that D initiate a prior criminal or civil legal proceeding against P, that the prior proceeding terminate in P's favor, that there be no probable cause for the original proceeding—such as when D knew P was not guilty or liable or lacked sufficient facts to reasonably believe in P's guilt or fault—that D act with an improper purpose in initiating the proceeding, and that P suffer damages. Prosecutors are immune from liability for this tort. Abuse of process is distinct: it focuses on D's wrongful use of legal process for an ulterior purpose, coupled with a definite act or threat against P to accomplish that ulterior purpose, even if the case itself was properly brought initially.
cards.mnemonic: MP: Bad Case Start; AP: Bad Process Use.
cards.clozeLite: Malicious prosecution requires {{c1::a prior proceeding against P}}, {{c2::termination in P's favor}}, {{c3::no probable cause}}, {{c4::improper purpose}}, and {{c5::damages}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. Intentional misrepresentation (fraud, deceit) 1.1 Elements 1.1.1 D misrepresents a past or present material fact. 1.1.2 D knows or believes the misrepresentation is false. 1.1.3 D intends to induce P to act or refrain from acting in reliance on the misrepresentation. 1.1.4 Actual reliance by P (causation: P must actually rely on the misrepresentation). 1.1.5 Justifiable reliance by P (P must be justified in relying on the misrepresentation). 1.1.6 Damages: P must suffer monetary loss. 2. Negligent misrepresentation 2.1 Elements 2.1.1 D misrepresents a past or present material fact in a business or professional setting. 2.1.2 Breach of a duty of care owed to a particular P (that is, D knew P could rely on the misrepresentation). 2.1.3 Actual and justifiable reliance by P. 2.1.4 Damages: P must suffer monetary loss.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of intentional misrepresentation (fraud) and negligent misrepresentation in tort?
cards.cloze: 1. Intentional misrepresentation ({{c1::fraud, deceit}}) 1.1 Elements 1.1.1 D {{c2::misrepresents a past or present material fact}}. 1.1.2 D {{c3::knows or believes the misrepresentation is false}}. 1.1.3 D {{c4::intends to induce P to act or refrain from acting}} in reliance on the misrepresentation. 1.1.4 {{c5::Actual reliance}} by P (causation: P must actually rely on the misrepresentation). 1.1.5 {{c6::Justifiable reliance}} by P (P must be justified in relying on the misrepresentation). 1.1.6 {{c7::Damages}}: P must suffer {{c8::monetary loss}}. 2. Negligent misrepresentation 2.1 Elements 2.1.1 D misrepresents a past or present material fact in a {{c9::business or professional setting}}. 2.1.2 {{c10::Breach of a duty of care}} owed to a particular P (that is, D knew P could rely on the misrepresentation). 2.1.3 {{c11::Actual and justifiable reliance}} by P. 2.1.4 {{c12::Damages}}: P must suffer {{c13::monetary loss}}.
cards.easyContent: Intentional misrepresentation (fraud) requires a knowing false statement of material fact made to induce reliance, actual and justifiable reliance, and monetary loss. Negligent misrepresentation is a careless misstatement of material fact in a business or professional setting, with duty, reliance, and monetary loss.
cards.mediumContent: Intentional misrepresentation, or fraud, requires that D knowingly or believingly falsely represent a past or present material fact, intend to induce P to act or refrain from acting on it, and that P actually and justifiably rely on the statement and suffer monetary damages. Negligent misrepresentation arises when, in a business or professional setting, D carelessly misstates a past or present material fact in breach of a duty of care to a particular P who D knows may rely, and P actually and justifiably relies and suffers monetary loss.
cards.hardContent: Intentional misrepresentation (fraud or deceit) consists of D misrepresenting a past or present material fact, knowing or believing that the representation is false, with the intent to induce P to act or refrain from acting in reliance on it. P must actually rely on the misrepresentation, that reliance must be justifiable, and P must suffer damages in the form of monetary loss. Negligent misrepresentation is similar but rests on negligence rather than intent: D misrepresents a past or present material fact in a business or professional context, breaches a duty of care owed to a particular P (because D knew P could rely on the statement), and P actually and justifiably relies on the misrepresentation and sustains monetary loss.
cards.mnemonic: Fraud FIJARD: False fact, Intent, Justifiable & Actual Reliance, Dollars lost.
cards.clozeLite: Fraud requires {{c1::knowing falsity of a material fact}}, {{c2::intent to induce reliance}}, {{c3::actual and justifiable reliance}}, and {{c4::monetary loss}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 021. Intentional Interference with Business Relationships
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Intentional interference with business relationships arises when a third party intentionally interferes with an existing contract or business expectancy. 2. Elements: 2.1 Plaintiff has a valid contractual relationship or business expectancy. 2.2 The relationship or expectancy is between plaintiff and a third party. 2.3 Defendant has knowledge of the relationship or expectancy. 2.4 Defendant intentionally interferes with that relationship or expectancy. 2.5 The interference must be intentional; negligence is insufficient. 2.6 Defendant's interference causes a breach, termination, or failure of performance in plaintiff's contract or expectancy. 2.7 Plaintiff suffers damages. 3. Privilege defenses: 3.1 Defendant's conduct may be privileged when it is a proper attempt to obtain business or protect defendant's own interests. 3.2 Example: legitimately competing for plaintiff's customers.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of intentional interference with a contractual or business relationship, and when may competition be privileged?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Intentional interference with business relationships}} arises when a {{c2::third party}} intentionally interferes with an existing {{c3::contract or business expectancy}}. 2.
