cards.easyContent: A defendant is liable for intentional interference with business relationships when they intentionally and knowingly interfere with a valid contract or business expectancy, causing its breach or termination and resulting damages.
cards.mediumContent: Intentional interference with business relationships requires: (1) a valid contract or business expectancy between plaintiff and a third party, (2) defendant's knowledge of it, (3) intentional interference by defendant, (4) resulting breach, termination, or failure of performance, and (5) damages. The interference must be intentional, not merely negligent. Defendant may be privileged if they are properly competing for business or protecting their own legitimate interests.
cards.hardContent: Intentional interference with business relationships arises when a third party intentionally interferes with an existing contract or business expectancy. The elements are: (1) plaintiff has a valid contractual relationship or business expectancy with a third party; (2) defendant knows of the relationship or expectancy; (3) defendant intentionally interferes with that relationship or expectancy; (4) the interference is intentional (negligence is insufficient); (5) defendant's interference causes a breach, termination, or failure of performance in plaintiff's contract or expectancy; and (6) plaintiff suffers damages. Defendant's conduct may be privileged when it is a proper attempt to obtain business or protect defendant's own interests, such as legitimately competing for plaintiff's customers.
cards.mnemonic: KID BD: Knowledge, Interference, Damages from Breach/Death of deal.
cards.clozeLite: Intentional interference with business relationships requires {{c1::a valid contract or business expectancy}}, {{c2::defendant's knowledge of it}}, {{c3::intentional (not negligent) interference}}, {{c4::resulting breach or termination}}, and {{c5::damages}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. Negligence basics: Negligence is analyzed under an objective standard by comparing defendant's actions to those of a reasonable person under the same or similar circumstances. 2. Elements of negligence: 2.1 Duty of care: Defendant has a duty to conform to a specific standard of care. 2.1.1 Reasonably prudent person: Defendant's duty is to behave like a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances presented. 2.1.2 Exception: In certain situations, an alternative standard of care applies. 2.2 Breach of duty. 2.3 Causation: Actual cause (cause in fact) and proximate cause (legal cause). 2.4 Damages.
cards.frontPrompt: How is negligence defined and what are the elements a plaintiff must prove?
cards.cloze: 1. Negligence basics: {{c1::Negligence}} is analyzed under an {{c2::objective standard}} by comparing defendant's actions to those of a {{c3::reasonable person under the same or similar circumstances}}. 2. Elements of negligence: 2.1 {{c4::Duty of care}}: Defendant has a duty to conform to a specific standard of care. 2.1.1 {{c5::Reasonably prudent person}}: Defendant's duty is to behave like a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances presented. 2.1.2 {{c6::Exception}}: In certain situations, an {{c7::alternative standard of care}} applies. 2.2 {{c8::Breach of duty}}. 2.3 {{c9::Causation}}: {{c10::Actual cause}} (cause in fact) and {{c11::proximate cause}} (legal cause). 2.4 {{c12::Damages}}.
cards.easyContent: Negligence uses an objective reasonable-person standard. A plaintiff must show duty, breach, causation, and damages.
cards.mediumContent: Negligence is judged by an objective standard, comparing defendant's conduct to that of a reasonably prudent person under the same or similar circumstances. The plaintiff must prove: (1) duty of care, often the reasonably prudent person standard unless a specialized standard applies; (2) breach of that duty; (3) causation, including both actual and proximate cause; and (4) damages.
cards.hardContent: Negligence is analyzed under an objective standard by comparing defendant's actions to those of a reasonable person under the same or similar circumstances. The elements are: (1) duty of care—defendant must conform to a specific standard of care, typically that of a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances, unless an alternative standard of care applies in special situations; (2) breach of duty—defendant fails to meet that standard; (3) causation—both actual cause (cause in fact) and proximate cause (legal cause) linking the breach to the injury; and (4) damages—plaintiff suffers legally cognizable harm.
cards.mnemonic: Negligence = DBCL: Duty, Breach, Causation, Loss (damages).
cards.clozeLite: Negligence uses an {{c1::objective reasonable-person standard}} and requires {{c2::duty}}, {{c3::breach}}, {{c4::causation}}, and {{c5::damages}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Defendant owes a duty of care, to behave like a reasonably prudent person, to all foreseeable plaintiffs in the zone of danger. 2. Default standard of care: 2.1 Reasonably prudent person (RPP). 2.2 Defendant's duty is to behave like a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances. 2.3 The RPP is considered to be someone with defendant's physical characteristics, but with the knowledge and mental capacity of an ordinary person. 3. Foreseeable victims: 3.1 Those within the zone of danger. 3.2 Zone of danger: the area around defendant's activities in which a plaintiff could foreseeably be injured. 3.3 Rescuer's exception: If defendant puts himself or another in danger and a third person attempts to rescue, defendant can be held liable for the rescuer's injuries, even if the rescuer was unforeseeable. 3.4 Firefighter's rule: The rescuer's exception does not apply to emergency personnel (e.g., firefighters or police) if their injury results from a risk inherent to the job. 3.5 Prenatal injury: A duty of care is owed to a viable fetus.
cards.frontPrompt: To whom does a defendant owe a duty of care in negligence, and what is the default reasonably prudent person standard, including key exceptions like rescuers and emergency personnel?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: Defendant owes a {{c1::duty of care}} to behave like a {{c2::reasonably prudent person}} to all {{c3::foreseeable plaintiffs in the zone of danger}}. 2. Default standard of care: 2.1 {{c4::Reasonably prudent person (RPP)}}. 2.2 Defendant's duty is to behave like a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances. 2.3 The RPP is considered to be someone with defendant's {{c5::physical characteristics}}, but with the {{c6::knowledge and mental capacity of an ordinary person}}. 3. Foreseeable victims: 3.1 Those within the {{c7::zone of danger}}. 3.2 Zone of danger: the area around defendant's activities in which a plaintiff could foreseeably be injured. 3.3 {{c8::Rescuer's exception}}: If defendant puts himself or another in danger and a third person attempts to rescue, defendant can be held liable for the rescuer's injuries, even if the rescuer was unforeseeable. 3.4 {{c9::Firefighter's rule}}: The rescuer's exception does not apply to emergency personnel (e.g., firefighters or police) if their injury results from a risk inherent to the job. 3.5 {{c10::Prenatal injury}}: A duty of care is owed to a {{c11::viable fetus}}.
cards.easyContent: A defendant owes a duty of reasonable care to all foreseeable plaintiffs in the zone of danger, measured by the reasonably prudent person standard.
cards.mediumContent: Duty of care in negligence requires a defendant to act as a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances toward all foreseeable plaintiffs in the zone of danger. The RPP is deemed to have the defendant's physical characteristics but the ordinary person's knowledge and mental capacity. Foreseeable victims are those within the zone of danger, plus rescuers under the rescuer's exception, though emergency personnel injured by job-related risks are barred by the firefighter's rule. A duty is also owed to a viable fetus.
cards.hardContent: The general rule is that a defendant owes a duty of care to behave like a reasonably prudent person to all foreseeable plaintiffs in the zone of danger. The default standard of care is the reasonably prudent person (RPP): a person with defendant's physical characteristics but the ordinary person's knowledge and mental capacity, acting under the circumstances. Foreseeable victims are those within the zone of danger, defined as the area around defendant's activities in which a plaintiff could foreseeably be injured. Under the rescuer's exception, if defendant puts himself or another in danger and a third person attempts a rescue, defendant can be held liable for the rescuer's injuries even if the rescuer was unforeseeable. However, under the firefighter's rule, this exception does not apply to emergency personnel such as firefighters or police when their injury results from a risk inherent to the job. Additionally, a duty of care is owed to a viable fetus for prenatal injuries.
cards.mnemonic: F-Zone & R-F: Foreseeable, Zone, Rescuers, not Firefighters, Fetus.
cards.clozeLite: Duty of care runs to {{c1::foreseeable plaintiffs in the zone of danger}}, judged by the {{c2::reasonably prudent person}} with {{c3::defendant’s physical traits}} but {{c4::ordinary knowledge and mental capacity}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Certain actors in negligence are subject to specialized standards of care beyond the ordinary reasonably prudent person standard. Key categories include: 1. Children: Generally judged by the standard of a reasonable child of similar age, education, intelligence, and experience. Very young children are typically deemed incapable of negligence, and children engaging in adult activities must meet an adult standard for that activity. 2. Common carriers and innkeepers: Owe a high standard of care to passengers and guests and may be liable even for slight negligence. 3. Custom or usage in an industry: Industry custom can be used as evidence of the applicable standard of care, but compliance or noncompliance with custom is not automatically dispositive of negligence or breach. 4. Professionals: Must act with the knowledge and skill of a reasonably competent member of the profession in similar communities, with medical professionals generally judged by a national standard of care. Other specialized standards—such as statutory standards of care and duties of owners and occupiers of land—are covered in separate cards.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main categories of specialized standards of care in negligence, and how do they differ in general from the ordinary reasonably prudent person standard?
cards.cloze: Certain actors in negligence are subject to {{c1::specialized standards of care}} beyond the ordinary reasonably prudent person standard. Key categories include: {{c2::children}}, {{c3::common carriers and innkeepers}}, {{c4::custom or usage in an industry}}, and {{c5::professionals}}. Other specialized standards—such as {{c6::statutory standards of care}} and duties of {{c7::owners and occupiers of land}}—are covered separately.
cards.easyContent: Some negligence defendants are judged by specialized standards rather than the ordinary reasonably prudent person standard, including children, common carriers and innkeepers, professionals, and cases where industry custom is relevant. Statutory standards and landowner duties are treated separately.
cards.mediumContent: Specialized standards of care in negligence include: (1) children, who are judged by a reasonable child standard and may be incapable of negligence when very young, with an adult standard applied to adult activities; (2) common carriers and innkeepers, who owe a high standard of care to passengers and guests and may be liable even for slight negligence; (3) industry custom, which is relevant evidence of the standard of care but not dispositive of negligence; and (4) professionals, who must act with the knowledge and skill of a reasonably competent professional (with medical professionals generally held to a national standard). Statutory standards and landowner duties are covered by separate rules.
cards.hardContent: In negligence, certain actors are not judged solely by the generic reasonably prudent person standard but by specialized standards tailored to their role. Children are held to a reasonable child standard, very young children are typically deemed incapable of negligence, and children engaged in adult activities must meet the adult standard for that activity. Common carriers and innkeepers owe passengers and guests a high standard of care and may be liable even for slight negligence. Industry custom can be used as evidence of what the standard of care is in a given setting, but factfinders are not bound by custom: noncompliance does not automatically establish breach, and compliance does not automatically negate negligence. Professionals must act with the knowledge and skill of a reasonably competent member of their profession in similar communities, with medical professionals generally held to a national standard of care. Other specialized standards, such as statutory standards of care and the duties of owners and occupiers of land, are addressed in separate doctrines.
cards.mnemonic: K-Cubed: Kids, Carriers, Custom, and Counsel.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) children, (2) common carriers and innkeepers, (3) custom as evidence of standard of care, and (4) professionals. Statutory standards and landowners are covered by separate cards.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Statutory Standards of Care and Negligence Per Se
cards.rawHeader: Torts 025. Statutory Standards of Care and Negligence Per Se
cards.front: Statutory Standards of Care and Negligence Per Se
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: An existing statute may establish a standard of care, in which case the statutory standard will replace the general common law standard of reasonable care. 2. Requirements: The statutory standard of care will apply if the statute satisfies three criteria: 2.1 Plaintiff must prove that the harm suffered is the type the statute was meant to prevent. 2.2 Plaintiff is in the class of victims the statute was meant to protect. 2.3 The statute imposes a specific standard of conduct—says what to do or not to do. 3. Statutory standard of care does not apply if: 3.1 Compliance is more dangerous than noncompliance; or 3.2 Compliance is impossible under the circumstances. 4. Negligence per se: 4.1 Violation of the statute means plaintiff must only prove causation and damages, not breach of duty. 4.2 Under the majority rule, violation of the statute establishes a conclusive presumption of duty and breach of duty. 4.3 Compliance does not automatically clear defendant of liability.
cards.frontPrompt: When does a statute set the standard of care in negligence (negligence per se), and what are the requirements and limitations on applying it?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: An existing {{c1::statute}} may establish a {{c2::standard of care}}, in which case the statutory standard will {{c3::replace the general common law standard of reasonable care}}. 2. Requirements: The statutory standard of care will apply if the statute satisfies three criteria: 2.1 Plaintiff must prove that the {{c4::harm suffered is the type the statute was meant to prevent}}. 2.2 Plaintiff is in the {{c5::class of victims the statute was meant to protect}}. 2.3 The statute {{c6::imposes a specific standard of conduct}}—says what to do or not to do. 3. Statutory standard of care does not apply if: 3.1 {{c7::Compliance is more dangerous than noncompliance}}; or 3.2 {{c8::Compliance is impossible}} under the circumstances. 4. {{c9::Negligence per se}}: 4.1 Violation of the statute means plaintiff must only prove {{c10::causation and damages}}, not {{c11::breach of duty}}. 4.2 Under the {{c12::majority rule}}, violation of the statute establishes a {{c13::conclusive presumption of duty and breach of duty}}. 4.3 {{c14::Compliance}} does not automatically clear defendant of liability.
cards.easyContent: A statute can set the standard of care (negligence per se) if it protects the class of persons and type of harm at issue and gives a specific conduct rule. Violation then usually conclusively establishes duty and breach, subject to excuses like impossibility or greater danger in complying.
cards.mediumContent: A statute replaces the common law reasonable-care standard when: (1) the plaintiff's harm is of the type the statute was designed to prevent; (2) plaintiff is within the class the statute seeks to protect; and (3) the statute sets a specific standard of conduct. The statutory standard does not apply if compliance is more dangerous than noncompliance or is impossible. Under negligence per se, a statutory violation generally creates a conclusive presumption of duty and breach, so plaintiff need only prove causation and damages, though compliance does not automatically defeat liability.
cards.hardContent: An existing statute may establish the standard of care in negligence, displacing the common law reasonable-care standard. The statutory standard applies when three criteria are met: (1) the harm suffered is the type the statute was intended to prevent; (2) the plaintiff is within the class of persons the statute was designed to protect; and (3) the statute imposes a specific standard of conduct, directing what must or must not be done. The statutory standard will not apply if compliance would be more dangerous than noncompliance or if compliance is impossible under the circumstances. Under the doctrine of negligence per se, violation of such a statute, in jurisdictions following the majority rule, creates a conclusive presumption of duty and breach of duty, so the plaintiff need only prove causation and damages. However, even full compliance with a statute does not automatically exonerate a defendant from negligence liability.
cards.mnemonic: Negligence per se = CHP: Class, Harm, Precise rule.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::statute replaces reasonable care}} when it protects the {{c2::type of harm}} and {{c3::class of persons}} and sets a {{c4::specific conduct rule}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Duty of Care for Owners and Occupiers of Land to Trespassers
cards.rawHeader: Torts 026. Duty of Care for Owners and Occupiers of Land to Trespassers
cards.front: Duty of Care for Owners and Occupiers of Land to Trespassers
cards.backPlain: Owners and occupiers of land owe different duties of care depending on the type of trespasser: 1. Unknown or undiscovered trespassers: No duty of care is owed. 2. Anticipated trespassers (where the owner has reason to believe trespassers will be on the land): The owner must use reasonable care in activities and must warn of or make safe certain dangerous conditions. 3. Child trespassers (attractive nuisance doctrine): The owner may have an elevated duty to protect children from dangerous conditions on the property when specific elements are met.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic duties of care landowners owe to unknown trespassers, anticipated trespassers, and child trespassers?
cards.cloze: Owners and occupiers of land owe different duties of care depending on the type of trespasser: 1. {{c1::Unknown or undiscovered trespassers}}: {{c2::No duty of care}} is owed. 2. {{c3::Anticipated trespassers}} (where the owner has reason to believe trespassers will be on the land): The owner must use {{c4::reasonable care in activities}} and address certain {{c5::dangerous conditions}}. 3. {{c6::Child trespassers}} under the {{c7::attractive nuisance doctrine}} may trigger an elevated duty when specific elements are met.
cards.easyContent: Landowners owe no duty to unknown trespassers, a limited duty of reasonable care for activities and certain dangers to anticipated trespassers, and a special attractive nuisance duty to protect child trespassers from dangerous conditions when its elements are satisfied.
cards.mediumContent: Premises liability toward trespassers depends on their status. Landowners owe no duty to unknown trespassers, but must exercise reasonable care in activities and address certain concealed, man-made dangers for anticipated trespassers. For child trespassers, the attractive nuisance doctrine can impose a duty to protect them from dangerous conditions when specific elements are met.
cards.hardContent: Owners and occupiers of land have status-based duties to trespassers. Unknown or undiscovered trespassers are owed no duty. For anticipated trespassers—where the owner has reason to believe trespassers will be present—the owner must use reasonable care in conducting activities and must warn of or make safe certain dangerous conditions. Separately, for child trespassers, the attractive nuisance doctrine can impose a duty to take reasonable steps to protect children from dangerous conditions when the doctrine’s elements are satisfied.
cards.mnemonic: U-A-Kids: Unknown none, Anticipated some, Kids special.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into two children: (1) duties to unknown vs anticipated trespassers; (2) attractive nuisance elements for child trespassers.
cards.clozeLite: To {{c1::unknown trespassers}}: {{c2::no duty}}. To {{c3::anticipated trespassers}}: {{c4::reasonable care for activities and certain dangers}}. To {{c5::child trespassers}}: {{c6::attractive nuisance duty}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: A defendant breaches his duty when his conduct falls short of the standard of care owed under the circumstances. 2. Ways to show breach of the applicable standard of care (plaintiff can argue): 2.1 Reasonably prudent person (RPP) standard. 2.2 Negligence per se. 2.3 Specialized standard of care. 2.4 Custom or usage in an industry (not an automatic breach, but may be relevant evidence). 3. Res ipsa loquitur: 3.1 The very occurrence of the accident causing plaintiff's injuries suggests negligent conduct. 3.2 It arises when the facts cannot establish breach of duty because the circumstances surrounding the event are unknown to the plaintiff. 4. Requirements for res ipsa loquitur (plaintiff must show): 4.1 Inference of negligence: The harm would not normally occur absent negligence. 4.2 Attributable to defendant: This type of harm normally results from negligence by one in defendant's position. 4.3 This is often satisfied by showing that the injury-causing instrumentality was in defendant's exclusive control. 4.4 The injury was not attributable to the plaintiff.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a plaintiff prove breach of duty in negligence, and what are the elements of res ipsa loquitur?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: A defendant {{c1::breaches his duty}} when his conduct falls short of the {{c2::standard of care owed under the circumstances}}. 2. Ways to show breach of the applicable standard of care (plaintiff can argue): 2.1 {{c3::Reasonably prudent person (RPP) standard}}. 2.2 {{c4::Negligence per se}}. 2.3 {{c5::Specialized standard of care}}. 2.4 {{c6::Custom or usage in an industry}} (not an automatic breach, but may be relevant evidence). 3. {{c7::Res ipsa loquitur}}: 3.1 The very occurrence of the accident causing plaintiff's injuries {{c8::suggests negligent conduct}}. 3.2 It arises when the facts cannot establish breach of duty because the {{c9::circumstances surrounding the event are unknown to the plaintiff}}. 4. Requirements for res ipsa loquitur (plaintiff must show): 4.1 {{c10::Inference of negligence}}: The harm would not normally occur absent negligence. 4.2 {{c11::Attributable to defendant}}: This type of harm normally results from negligence by one in defendant's position. 4.3 This is often satisfied by showing that the {{c12::injury-causing instrumentality was in defendant's exclusive control}}. 4.4 The injury was {{c13::not attributable to the plaintiff}}.
cards.easyContent: Breach occurs when the defendant’s conduct falls below the required standard of care. Breach can be shown through RPP, negligence per se, specialized standards, custom, or by inferring negligence using res ipsa loquitur.
cards.mediumContent: A defendant breaches duty when his conduct falls short of the standard of care under the circumstances. The plaintiff may prove breach by showing failure to meet the RPP standard, negligence per se, violation of a specialized standard, or deviation from relevant custom. Under res ipsa loquitur, breach may be inferred where the type of accident does not ordinarily occur without negligence, is of a kind normally attributable to someone in the defendant’s position (often via exclusive control of the instrumentality), and is not attributable to the plaintiff.
cards.hardContent: Breach of duty occurs when the defendant’s conduct falls short of the applicable standard of care under the circumstances. The plaintiff can show breach by arguing the defendant failed to meet the reasonably prudent person standard, committed negligence per se by violating a statute, failed to satisfy a specialized standard of care, or deviated from relevant industry custom (which is evidence but not automatically a breach). Under res ipsa loquitur, when the plaintiff cannot specify the exact negligent act because the circumstances are unknown, he may establish an inference of negligence by showing that the harm would not normally occur absent negligence, that this type of harm normally results from negligence by someone in the defendant’s position—often shown by the defendant’s exclusive control of the injury-causing instrumentality—and that the injury was not attributable to the plaintiff.
cards.mnemonic: RIP for res ipsa: Rare accident, In D’s control, P not at fault.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::res ipsa loquitur}}, breach may be inferred when the {{c2::type of accident doesn’t occur without negligence}}, is {{c3::normally attributable to someone in D’s position}}, and is {{c4::not attributable to P}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: Actual cause (cause in fact) establishes a causal connection between the alleged breach of duty and the resulting injury. 1.1 "But for" test: But for defendant's alleged breach of duty, plaintiff's injury would not have occurred. 2. Substantial factor test: 2.1 For multiple causes of plaintiff's injury, defendant's breach is the actual cause if it was a substantial factor in bringing about plaintiff's injury. 2.2 Application: Used when multiple causes bring about plaintiff's injury and any one of them alone would have caused the injury. 2.3 Example: Fires start on D1's land and D2's land, each of which spreads to plaintiff's land and destroys plaintiff's house. 3. Burden-shifting test (alternative causation): 3.1 For several possible causes of plaintiff's injury. 3.2 Application: Used when multiple defendants act (often simultaneously), only one causes plaintiff's injury, but it is unclear which defendant caused the injury. 3.3 Example: Plaintiff is hit by a stray bullet at a busy firing range and it is unknown which shooter hit plaintiff. 3.4 Burden of proving actual cause shifts to defendants. 3.5 If no defendant can prove another defendant was responsible, all defendants are jointly and severally liable.
cards.frontPrompt: What is actual (cause-in-fact) causation in negligence, and how do the but-for, substantial factor, and burden-shifting tests work?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: {{c1::Actual cause (cause in fact)}} establishes a causal connection between the alleged breach of duty and the resulting injury. 1.1 "{{c2::But for}}" test: But for defendant's alleged breach of duty, plaintiff's injury would not have occurred. 2. {{c3::Substantial factor test}}: 2.1 For {{c4::multiple causes}} of plaintiff's injury, defendant's breach is the actual cause if it was a {{c5::substantial factor}} in bringing about plaintiff's injury. 2.2 Application: Used when multiple causes bring about plaintiff's injury and {{c6::any one of them alone would have caused the injury}}. 2.3 Example: Fires start on D1's land and D2's land, each of which spreads to plaintiff's land and destroys plaintiff's house. 3. {{c7::Burden-shifting test}} ({{c8::alternative causation}}): 3.1 For several possible causes of plaintiff's injury. 3.2 Application: Used when {{c9::multiple defendants act (often simultaneously)}}, only one causes plaintiff's injury, but it is {{c10::unclear which defendant caused the injury}}. 3.3 Example: Plaintiff is hit by a stray bullet at a busy firing range and it is unknown which shooter hit plaintiff. 3.4 {{c11::Burden of proving actual cause shifts to defendants}}. 3.5 If no defendant can prove another defendant was responsible, {{c12::all defendants are jointly and severally liable}}.
cards.easyContent: Actual cause (cause in fact) asks whether the injury would have occurred but for the defendant’s breach, or in multiple-cause cases whether the breach was a substantial factor or triggers a burden shift among multiple defendants.
cards.mediumContent: Actual cause, or cause in fact, requires a causal connection between the defendant’s breach and the plaintiff’s injury. The basic test is the but-for test: but for the defendant’s breach, the harm would not have occurred. When multiple sufficient causes exist, courts use the substantial factor test, asking whether the defendant’s conduct was a substantial factor in bringing about the harm. In alternative causation cases with multiple negligent defendants where only one caused the injury but it is unclear which, the burden shifts to the defendants to disprove causation or face joint and several liability.
cards.hardContent: Actual cause (cause in fact) requires that the defendant’s breach be a factual cause of the plaintiff’s injury. Under the but-for test, the plaintiff must show that but for the defendant’s breach, the injury would not have occurred. When there are multiple sufficient causes such that any one alone could have caused the harm, courts apply the substantial factor test, finding cause in fact if the defendant’s conduct was a substantial factor in producing the injury, such as two separate fires that each would have destroyed plaintiff’s house. In alternative causation situations—where multiple defendants act negligently, only one actually causes the harm, and it is unclear which one—the burden of proving actual cause shifts to the defendants. If no defendant can show that another defendant was responsible, all defendants are held jointly and severally liable.
cards.mnemonic: ABC: Actual cause, But-for, Concurrent (substantial factor) and Confused shooter (burden shift).
cards.clozeLite: Actual cause asks if {{c1::but for the defendant’s breach}} the harm would occur, or if the conduct was a {{c2::substantial factor}} or triggers {{c3::burden-shifting in alternative causation cases}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: Proximate cause establishes that it is fair under the law to hold defendant responsible for plaintiff's injuries. 2. Foreseeability: 2.1 Foreseeability is the measuring stick for proximate cause. 2.2 Defendant is liable for the foreseeable outcome of his conduct. 2.3 Note: An outcome does not have to be likely to be foreseeable. On the MBE, unlikely things are often foreseeable; if it is reasonably possible, it is probably foreseeable. 3. Direct causes: 3.1 If plaintiff's injury is the direct consequence of defendant's negligent conduct, defendant is liable unless the outcome is unusually bizarre or unpredictable. 4. Indirect causes and intervening forces: 4.1 Intervening forces that occur after defendant's conduct to cause plaintiff's injuries will not cut off defendant's liability if they are foreseeable. 4.2 An intervening force is usually foreseeable if either: 4.2.1 It is a normal response or reaction to defendant's negligent act, or 4.2.2 Defendant's negligence increased the risk that an intervening force would cause harm to plaintiff. 4.3 Injuries to rescuers are usually considered foreseeable. 5. Eggshell skull rule: 5.1 Defendant takes plaintiff as he finds him and is liable for the full extent of plaintiff's injuries, regardless of whether the extent of those injuries is foreseeable. 6. Note: Proximate cause (i.e., foreseeability) is a question of fact that is usually left to the jury or fact-finder.
cards.frontPrompt: What is proximate cause in negligence, how does foreseeability limit liability, and how do intervening forces and the eggshell skull rule affect the analysis?

On the MBE, unlikely things are often foreseeable; if it is {{c6::reasonably possible}}, it is probably foreseeable. 3. {{c7::Direct causes}}: 3.1 If plaintiff's injury is the direct consequence of defendant's negligent conduct, defendant is liable unless the outcome is {{c8::unusually bizarre or unpredictable}}. 4. {{c9::Indirect causes and intervening forces}}: 4.1 Intervening forces that occur after defendant's conduct to cause plaintiff's injuries will not cut off defendant's liability if they are {{c10::foreseeable}}. 4.2 An intervening force is usually foreseeable if either: 4.2.1 It is a {{c11::normal response or reaction}} to defendant's negligent act, or 4.2.2 Defendant's negligence {{c12::increased the risk}} that an intervening force would cause harm to plaintiff. 4.3 Injuries to {{c13::rescuers}} are usually considered foreseeable. 5. {{c14::Eggshell skull rule}}: 5.1 Defendant {{c15::takes plaintiff as he finds him}} and is liable for the {{c16::full extent of plaintiff's injuries}}, regardless of whether the extent of those injuries is foreseeable. 6. cards.easyContent: Proximate cause limits negligence liability to harms that are reasonably foreseeable consequences of the defendant’s conduct, including foreseeable intervening events, and the defendant is liable for the full extent of the plaintiff’s injuries under the eggshell skull rule.
cards.mediumContent: Proximate cause asks whether it is fair to hold the defendant legally responsible, using foreseeability as the key test: a defendant is liable for foreseeable outcomes of his negligence. Direct consequences are usually within the scope unless bizarre or highly unpredictable. Foreseeable intervening forces—normal reactions or those whose risk was increased by defendant’s negligence, including injuries to rescuers—do not cut off liability. Under the eggshell skull rule, the defendant takes the plaintiff as he finds him and is liable for the full extent of injuries even if their extent was unforeseeable. Proximate cause is a fact question for the jury.
cards.hardContent: Proximate cause is the legal limitation on actual causation, asking whether it is fair to hold the defendant responsible for the plaintiff’s injuries. Foreseeability is the central test: the defendant is liable for harms that are reasonably foreseeable results of his conduct, even if the precise manner or likelihood is low, so long as the outcome is reasonably possible. When the injury flows directly from defendant’s negligence, proximate cause is usually satisfied unless the result is unusually bizarre or unpredictable. When intervening forces occur after defendant’s conduct, they do not break the chain if they are foreseeable—either because they are a normal response to defendant’s negligence or because defendant’s negligence increased the risk of that intervening harm. Injuries to rescuers are generally deemed foreseeable. Under the eggshell skull rule, the defendant takes the plaintiff as he finds him and is liable for the full extent of the injuries, even if the severity was unforeseeable. Proximate cause and foreseeability are typically questions of fact for the jury or fact-finder.
cards.mnemonic: Think “FIRE”: Fairness, Intervening forces, Rescuers, Eggshell skull—all governed by foreseeability for proximate cause.
cards.clozeLite: Proximate cause limits liability to {{c1::reasonably foreseeable harms}} and {{c2::foreseeable intervening forces}}, and {{c3::eggshell skull}} makes D liable for {{c4::full extent of injuries}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: Plaintiff must prove damages in negligence; damages are not presumed, and nominal damages are not available. 2. Types of damages: 2.1 Personal injury damages: Defendant must compensate plaintiff for all personal injury damages, including past, present, and prospective damages. Both economic and non-economic damages are recoverable. 2.2 Property damage: Plaintiff can recover the reasonable cost of repairs. If the property is irreparable, damages are the full market value at the time the accident occurred. 2.3 Punitive damages: Only recoverable if defendant's conduct is wanton and willful, reckless, or malicious. Punitive damages are usually not available in negligence cases and are more common with intentional torts. 3. Non-recoverable damages (plaintiff can never recover for): 3.1 Interest from the date of damage in personal injury cases. 3.2 Attorneys' fees. 4. Duty to mitigate: Plaintiff must take reasonable steps to mitigate damages.
cards.frontPrompt: What types of damages are available in negligence cases, which damages are never recoverable, and what is the plaintiff’s duty to mitigate?

cards.easyContent: In negligence, the plaintiff must prove actual damages; no nominal damages are allowed. Recoverable damages include full personal injury and property damage (with limited punitive damages), but not interest from the date of injury or attorneys’ fees, and the plaintiff must mitigate.
cards.mediumContent: Negligence requires proof of actual damages; they are not presumed and nominal damages are unavailable. Recoverable damages include personal injury damages (all past, present, and future economic and non-economic losses) and property damage (reasonable repair costs or full market value if destroyed). Punitive damages are available only for wanton, willful, reckless, or malicious conduct and are rare in negligence but common in intentional torts. Plaintiffs can never recover prejudgment interest on personal injury damages or attorneys’ fees, and they must take reasonable steps to mitigate losses.
cards.hardContent: In negligence actions, the plaintiff must affirmatively prove actual damages; they are not presumed and nominal damages are unavailable. Compensatory damages include personal injury damages—covering all past, present, and prospective losses, both economic (e.g., medical expenses, lost wages) and non-economic (e.g., pain and suffering)—and property damage, measured by the reasonable cost of repairs or, if the property is irreparable or destroyed, the full market value at the time of the accident. Punitive damages are only available when the defendant’s conduct is wanton and willful, reckless, or malicious; they are typically unavailable in ordinary negligence but may be awarded in intentional tort cases. Plaintiffs may never recover interest from the date of damage in personal injury cases or their attorneys’ fees. Additionally, plaintiffs have a duty to mitigate damages by taking reasonable steps to reduce or avoid further loss.
cards.mnemonic: CAP: Compensatory, Almost never Punitive, must mitigate.
cards.clozeLite: In negligence, {{c1::actual damages must be proven}}; {{c2::nominal damages are unavailable}}; {{c3::prejudgment interest and attorneys’ fees}} are never recovered, and {{c4::plaintiff must mitigate}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Comparative and Contributory Negligence, Assumption of Risk
cards.rawHeader: Torts 031. Comparative and Contributory Negligence, Assumption of Risk
cards.front: Comparative and Contributory Negligence, Assumption of Risk
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main negligence defenses of comparative negligence, contributory negligence (including last clear chance), and assumption of risk (including express assumption), and in general how do they affect a plaintiff’s recovery?
cards.backPlain: Overview of negligence defenses affecting damages or barring recovery: 1. Comparative negligence - Plaintiff’s own negligence reduces, rather than completely bars, recovery. - Fact-finder assigns percentages of fault to plaintiff and defendant and reduces plaintiff’s damages by plaintiff’s share. - Systems include partial (modified) comparative negligence, which cuts off recovery once plaintiff’s fault reaches a jurisdictional threshold, and pure comparative negligence, which allows recovery regardless of plaintiff’s percentage of fault. 2. Contributory negligence - In a few jurisdictions, any negligence by the plaintiff that contributes to her injury can bar recovery entirely. - The harshness of this rule is mitigated by the last clear chance doctrine, which lets the plaintiff recover if the defendant had the final clear opportunity to avoid the accident. 3. Assumption of risk (including express assumption) - Applies when the plaintiff knowingly and voluntarily faces a specific risk, which can bar or limit recovery. - Assumption of risk can be implied from conduct or expressly agreed to (e.g., in an exculpatory clause), though courts scrutinize such agreements, especially in adhesion contracts. - These defenses generally do not apply to intentional torts, though the plaintiff may consent to intentional tortious conduct.

cards.mediumContent: Comparative negligence reduces damages in proportion to the plaintiff’s share of fault, with systems divided into partial (modified) and pure forms. Contributory negligence, in a few jurisdictions, bars any recovery if the plaintiff’s negligence contributed to the injury, unless the defendant had the last clear chance to avoid the harm. Assumption of risk, whether implied from conduct or express by agreement, bars or limits recovery when the plaintiff knew of and voluntarily faced a specific risk; these doctrines are generally not defenses to intentional torts, although a plaintiff may consent to intentional tortious conduct.
cards.hardContent: Comparative negligence, now the majority approach, permits recovery that is reduced by the plaintiff’s percentage of fault; fact-finders apportion responsibility between plaintiff and defendant. In partial (modified) comparative systems, recovery is permitted only if the plaintiff’s negligence is below (or at most equal to) a jurisdictional cutoff (often 50%), while in pure systems, the plaintiff may recover regardless of his percentage of fault. Contributory negligence, a minority rule, bars recovery entirely if plaintiff’s negligence contributed to the injury, but the last clear chance doctrine allows recovery if, after plaintiff was in peril, the defendant had the final clear opportunity to avoid the accident and failed to do so. Assumption of risk bars or limits recovery when the defendant proves that the plaintiff knew of a specific risk and voluntarily proceeded in the face of that risk; this may be implied from circumstances or express via an agreement such as an exculpatory clause, which is less likely to be enforced when it is part of an adhesion contract. These defenses do not generally apply to intentional torts, although a plaintiff can consent to intentional tortious conduct.

cards.front: Negligent Infliction of Emotional Distress – Overview
cards.backPlain: Negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED) allows recovery for emotional harm caused by the defendant’s negligence, but most jurisdictions limit recovery to specific categories. 1. General concept 1.1. A plaintiff may recover for emotional distress resulting from the defendant’s negligence. 1.2. NIED is usually recognized in three main patterns: 1.2.1. Zone-of-danger cases (plaintiff is nearly physically harmed and suffers severe emotional distress, often with a physical manifestation requirement or split). 1.2.2. Bystander claims (plaintiff outside the zone of danger, but closely related, present, and personally perceiving the injury to another). 1.2.3. Special situations where negligence creates a great likelihood of emotional distress (e.g., erroneous report of a relative’s death; mishandling of a corpse). 2. Exam focus 2.1. Identify which NIED theory applies (zone-of-danger, bystander, or special situation). 2.2. Apply the specific elements for that category, including any jurisdictional variations on physical symptom requirements.

cards.easyContent: NIED lets plaintiffs recover for emotional harm caused by negligence, usually only in three situations: (1) zone-of-danger cases where the plaintiff is nearly physically harmed, (2) bystander claims where a closely related person sees a loved one injured, and (3) special situations like mishandling a corpse or wrongly reporting a relative’s death.
cards.mediumContent: Negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED) is a negligence-based claim for emotional harm. Courts usually confine NIED to specific patterns: (1) zone-of-danger cases, where the defendant’s negligence nearly causes bodily harm to the plaintiff and the plaintiff suffers severe distress (with many jurisdictions requiring some physical manifestation, though some allow distress alone); (2) bystander claims, in which a closely related plaintiff outside the zone of danger is present at the scene and personally perceives injury to a loved one; and (3) special situations where the negligence inherently creates a great likelihood of emotional distress, such as mishandling a corpse or erroneously reporting a relative’s death.
cards.hardContent: Negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED) permits recovery for emotional distress caused by the defendant’s negligence. Modern courts usually cabined this claim into three main categories. First, in zone-of-danger cases, the plaintiff is placed in immediate risk of bodily harm by the defendant’s negligence and suffers severe emotional distress; many jurisdictions require a resulting physical manifestation of that distress, while others permit recovery for severe emotional distress alone. Second, in bystander claims, a plaintiff outside the zone of danger may recover when the defendant negligently injures another person and the plaintiff is closely related to the victim, is present at the scene, and personally observes or perceives the event. Third, even if those elements are not satisfied, courts recognize certain special situations—such as erroneous reports of a relative’s death or mishandling of a corpse—in which the negligence creates a great likelihood of serious emotional distress and recovery is allowed.

cards.easyContent: Strict liability imposes liability without proof of negligence for certain activities—abnormally dangerous activities, some animal conduct, and products liability—when the activity’s dangerous aspect actually and proximately causes foreseeable harm to person or property. Due care is not a defense, though assumption of risk and sometimes comparative negligence may reduce or bar recovery.
cards.mediumContent: In strict liability, the defendant has an absolute duty to make certain activities safe, and the plaintiff need not prove negligence. Strict liability mainly applies to ultrahazardous or abnormally dangerous activities, certain animal conduct, and products liability. A prima facie case requires that the nature of the activity imposes an absolute duty, that the dangerous aspect of the activity is the actual and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injury, and that the plaintiff suffers harm to person or property; liability is confined to foreseeable plaintiffs. Due care does not excuse strict liability, but assumption of risk and, in some jurisdictions, comparative negligence remain available defenses.
cards.hardContent: Strict liability in tort holds a defendant liable without proof of negligence when they engage in certain activities for which the law imposes an absolute duty of safety. It is generally confined to ultrahazardous or abnormally dangerous activities or conditions, animal conduct, and products liability. To establish a prima facie strict liability claim, the plaintiff must show that the nature of the defendant’s activity creates an absolute duty to make it safe, that the dangerous aspect of that activity actually and proximately caused the plaintiff’s injury, and that the plaintiff sustained damage to person or property; the defendant is typically liable only to foreseeable plaintiffs. No amount of due care will relieve the defendant of liability, but the defendant may still assert defenses such as assumption of risk and, in some jurisdictions, comparative negligence to limit or bar recovery.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Abnormally Dangerous Conditions or Activities 1. General rule 1.1. Abnormally dangerous or ultrahazardous activities or conditions give rise to strict liability for any resulting injuries. 2. Requirements (an abnormally dangerous activity or condition exists if): 2.1. Severe risk: The condition or activity imposes a severe risk of harm to persons or property. 2.2. Cannot be made safe: It cannot be made reasonably safe and cannot be performed without a serious risk of harm, even with due care. 2.3. Uncommon: The condition or activity is uncommon in the community. 2.3.1. Note: This often arises with explosive, toxic, and/or biohazardous materials. 3. Injury must result from the abnormally dangerous aspect 3.1. The plaintiff’s injury must result from the abnormally dangerous activity or condition itself. 3.2. Watch for fact patterns where abnormally dangerous conditions exist but do not cause the plaintiff’s injury. 3.3. Example: A truck carrying toxic waste in sealed containers falls and crashes into the plaintiff’s car but the containers do not spill. 3.3.1. No strict liability because the abnormally dangerous nature of the containers did not cause the plaintiff’s injury.

cards.easyContent: Strict liability for abnormally dangerous activities applies when an activity poses a severe risk of harm, cannot be made reasonably safe even with due care, and is uncommon in the community, and the injury results from the activity’s dangerous aspect. If the danger doesn’t cause the injury, strict liability does not apply.
cards.mediumContent: Abnormally dangerous or ultrahazardous activities create strict liability for resulting injuries when three conditions are met: the activity or condition poses a severe risk of harm to people or property, it cannot be made reasonably safe even with due care, and it is uncommon in the community. Typical examples involve explosives, toxic chemicals, or biohazards. Strict liability attaches only when the injury arises from the abnormally dangerous aspect of the activity; if the hazardous feature plays no causal role, there is no strict liability.
cards.hardContent: An activity or condition is abnormally dangerous—and thus subject to strict liability—when it creates a severe risk of harm to persons or property, cannot be made reasonably safe such that the risk remains serious even with the exercise of due care, and is uncommon in the community. The doctrine frequently involves explosives, toxic substances, or biohazardous materials. However, strict liability only covers injuries that result from the abnormally dangerous aspect itself: if an injury occurs but the hazardous nature of the activity does not cause that injury (for example, a truck transporting sealed toxic waste crashes into a car without any spill), strict liability does not apply.

cards.mediumContent: Strict liability for animal conduct arises when an owner’s animal trespasses and causes reasonably foreseeable property damage, except for household pets. For personal injuries, owners of wild animals are strictly liable to licensees and invitees for unprovoked injuries. For domestic animals, strict liability applies only if the owner knows or should know of the animal’s unusually dangerous propensities—illustrated by a dog that has previously bitten someone. cards.hardContent: Strict liability in animal cases covers two main areas. First, owners are strictly liable for reasonably foreseeable damage to another’s property caused by their animals’ trespass, excluding ordinary household pets. Second, for personal injury, owners of wild animals are strictly liable to licensees and invitees for unprovoked injuries their animals inflict. Owners of domestic animals, by contrast, are strictly liable only when they know or have reason to know that the animal has unusually dangerous propensities—for example, a dog with a history of biting. Trespassers are generally outside the protection of strict liability for animal conduct, though they may still pursue negligence claims depending on the circumstances.

cards.mediumContent: Strict products liability requires: (1) D is a commercial supplier (in the stream of commerce, not a casual seller or service provider); (2) the product is defective and unreasonably dangerous; (3) the defect is the actual and proximate cause of P’s injury, without substantial alteration after leaving D; (4) P used the product in a foreseeable way, including foreseeable misuse; and (5) P is a foreseeable user or bystander who suffers physical injury or property damage, not merely economic loss.
cards.hardContent: Strict products liability attaches when all core elements are met: (1) D is a commercial supplier in the stream of commerce, rather than a casual seller or service provider; (2) the product is defective in a way that makes it unreasonably dangerous; (3) the defective condition actually and proximately causes P’s injury and the product is not substantially altered between leaving the supplier and reaching the consumer; (4) P’s use is foreseeable, including foreseeable misuse; and (5) P is a foreseeable user or bystander (such as buyers, their guests, employees, or family) who suffers physical injury or property damage, but not solely economic loss.

cards.backPlain: There are three main types of product defects in products liability: 1. Manufacturing defect: a particular product departs from its intended design so that it is more dangerous than other units, judged under a consumer-expectation standard. 2. Design defect: the product's design itself creates an unreasonable risk of danger, often evaluated by whether there was a feasible, safer alternative design. 3. Inadequate warning (warning/instruction defect): the manufacturer fails to give adequate warnings or instructions about non-obvious risks (including foreseeable misuse), with special rules for unavoidably unsafe products.

cards.hardContent: In products liability, a product may be defective in three main ways: (1) A manufacturing defect, where an individual product departs from its intended design, making it more dangerous than other units, usually assessed under a consumer-expectation standard. (2) A design defect, where the design itself creates an unreasonable risk of danger, often analyzed by whether a technologically and economically feasible safer alternative design or modification existed. (3) An inadequate warning (warning/instruction) defect, where the manufacturer fails to adequately warn of non-obvious risks, including foreseeable misuse, and must give heightened instructions and warnings for unavoidably unsafe products.

cards.backPlain: Negligence theory for products liability: 1. General rule: P may establish liability for a product defect under a negligence theory (note: a product defect is almost always easier to establish under a strict liability theory). 2. Elements: 2.1 Duty of care: Each commercial supplier in the stream of commerce owes a duty to all foreseeable product users and bystanders. 2.2 Breach of duty: D's negligence leads to the supplying of a defective product; retailers and wholesalers satisfy due care by a cursory inspection of the product, which makes it difficult to hold them negligent for product defects. 2.3 Causation: P must show actual and proximate cause. Note: an intermediary's negligent failure to discover a defect does not absolve the upstream commercial supplier of liability. 2.4 Damages: P must show physical injury or property damage; economic loss alone is not recoverable. 2.5 Defenses: all standard negligence defenses are available.

cards.easyContent: Products liability can be based on negligence by showing the usual negligence elements against a commercial supplier whose negligence led to a defective product that caused physical injury or property damage.
cards.mediumContent: Under a negligence theory, each commercial supplier in the stream of commerce owes a duty of reasonable care to foreseeable users and bystanders. Breach occurs when the supplier's negligence results in supplying a defective product; retailers and wholesalers often satisfy due care by a cursory inspection. The defect must be the actual and proximate cause of P's physical injury or property damage (not purely economic loss), and an intermediary's negligent failure to discover the defect does not cut off upstream supplier liability. All standard negligence defenses apply.
cards.hardContent: Products liability in negligence requires P to prove standard negligence elements against a commercial supplier. (1) Duty: each commercial supplier in the stream of commerce owes a duty of reasonable care to all foreseeable product users and bystanders. (2) Breach: the supplier breaches by negligent conduct that results in supplying a defective product; retailers and wholesalers typically satisfy due care with a cursory inspection, making negligence harder to prove against them. (3) Causation: P must establish actual and proximate cause, and an intermediary's negligent failure to detect the defect does not absolve upstream suppliers. (4) Damages: P must suffer physical injury or property damage—pure economic loss is not recoverable. (5) Defenses: all ordinary negligence defenses (e.g., contributory negligence, comparative negligence, assumption of risk) are available.

Types of implied warranties: 1.1 Warranty of merchantability: Goods must be of average acceptable quality and fit for their ordinary purpose. 1.2 Warranty of fitness for a particular purpose: Arises when the seller knows the buyer’s particular purpose and the buyer relies on the seller’s skill or judgment. 2. Who is protected: Implied warranty protection extends at least to the buyer and to the buyer’s family, household, and guests who suffer personal injury. 3. Implied warranty claim structure: Plaintiff must prove (a) an applicable implied warranty, (b) breach because the product failed to meet that warranty, (c) actual and proximate causation, and (d) recoverable damages (personal, property, or economic), subject to defenses such as assumption of risk and contributory or comparative negligence.

cards.easyContent: Implied warranties in products liability include merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose, protect the buyer and certain related persons, and require warranty, breach, causation, damages, and no successful defenses.
cards.mediumContent: Products liability recognizes two main implied warranties: merchantability (goods of average acceptable quality and fit for ordinary use) and fitness for a particular purpose (arising when the seller knows the buyer’s special purpose and the buyer relies on the seller’s skill or judgment). These warranties protect the buyer and extend to the buyer’s family, household, and guests for personal injury. An implied warranty claim requires an applicable warranty, breach by nonconforming goods, actual and proximate causation, and damages (personal, property, or economic), subject to defenses like assumption of risk and contributory/comparative negligence.
cards.hardContent: In products liability, every sale of goods may carry implied warranties. The two core implied warranties are merchantability (goods must be of average acceptable quality and fit for their ordinary purpose) and fitness for a particular purpose (arises when the seller knows or has reason to know the buyer’s specific purpose and the buyer relies on the seller’s skill or judgment, implying fitness for that purpose). These warranties protect the buyer and also extend to the buyer’s family, household, and guests who suffer personal injury. To recover for breach of implied warranty, a plaintiff must show: (1) an applicable implied warranty; (2) breach because the product did not conform to that warranty; (3) actual and proximate causation; and (4) damages, including personal injury, property damage, and economic loss, subject to defenses such as assumption of risk and contributory or comparative negligence.
cards.mnemonic: "MF" warranties: Merchantability & Fitness (ordinary use vs special purpose).

cards.backPlain: Liability based on representation in products cases can arise from: (1) breach of an express warranty; and (2) misrepresentation of fact. 1. Express warranty overview: 1.1 Definition: A statement of material fact or promise regarding goods sold that becomes part of the basis of the bargain. 1.2 Elements: Existence of an express warranty relied upon by the purchaser, breach when the product fails to live up to the warranty, actual and proximate causation, and personal, property, or economic damages. 1.3 Who can sue and defenses: Any consumer or bystander can sue for breach; bystanders need not have relied personally if the original purchaser did. Defenses include assumption of risk, contributory negligence, and comparative negligence. 2. Misrepresentation of fact overview: 2.1 The seller is liable for misrepresentation made in the course of a sale when the seller misrepresents a material fact about the quality or use of the goods, intends to induce reliance, and the misrepresentation induces justifiable reliance. 2.2 For strict liability based on misrepresentation, the buyer need not personally rely on the misrepresentation for the seller to be liable.

cards.easyContent: Products liability based on representation includes: (1) express warranty—material factual statements or promises that form part of the bargain, with breach, causation, and damages; and (2) misrepresentation of fact—material misstatements about quality or use that induce justifiable reliance, with a relaxed reliance requirement in strict-liability misrepresentation.
cards.mediumContent: Liability based on representation in products cases arises from express warranties and misrepresentation of fact. Express warranty liability requires a statement of material fact or promise about the goods that becomes part of the basis of the bargain, reliance by the purchaser, breach when the product fails to conform, causation, and damages. Any consumer or bystander can sue; bystanders may recover even without personal reliance as long as the purchaser relied, and defenses like assumption of risk and contributory or comparative negligence apply. Misrepresentation liability arises where the seller, in the course of a sale, misrepresents a material fact about the quality or use of the goods, intends to induce reliance, and the misrepresentation induces justifiable reliance; in strict-liability misrepresentation, the buyer need not personally rely.
cards.hardContent: Liability based on representation in products cases takes two primary forms. (1) Express warranty: A statement of material fact or promise about goods that becomes part of the basis of the bargain. Liability requires an express warranty relied on by the purchaser, breach when the product fails to live up to the warranty, actual and proximate causation, and personal, property, or economic loss. Any consumer or bystander can sue, and bystanders need not have relied personally if the original purchaser did. Traditional defenses such as assumption of risk, contributory negligence, and comparative negligence are available. (2) Misrepresentation of fact: A seller is liable when, in the course of a sale, the seller misrepresents a material fact concerning the quality or use of the goods, intends to induce reliance, and the misrepresentation induces justifiable reliance. For strict liability based on misrepresentation, the buyer need not personally rely on the misrepresentation for the seller to be liable.

cards.backPlain: Nuisance is an intentional invasion of public or private property rights that substantially and unreasonably interferes with the peaceful and quiet enjoyment of those rights. Nuisance describes a type of harm, not a standalone tort. There are two main types: • Private nuisance: substantial and unreasonable interference with an individual landowner’s use or enjoyment of land. • Public nuisance: unreasonable interference with the health, safety, or property rights of the community at large, with recovery by a private party only if she suffers unique harm. Key issues include how to assess substantial and unreasonable interference, the special‑injury requirement for public nuisance, and available remedies and defenses (including “coming to the nuisance”).

cards.easyContent: Nuisance is an intentional, substantial, and unreasonable interference with public or private property rights. It comes in two main forms: private nuisance (interference with a particular landowner’s use or enjoyment) and public nuisance (interference with the community’s health, safety, or property rights, with private recovery only for unique harm).
cards.mediumContent: Nuisance is an intentional invasion of public or private property rights that substantially and unreasonably interferes with their quiet enjoyment, and it describes a category of harm rather than a standalone tort. It divides into private nuisance (substantial, unreasonable interference with an individual’s use or enjoyment of land) and public nuisance (unreasonable interference with the health, safety, or property rights of the community at large). A private plaintiff may recover for a public nuisance only if she suffers unique damage not shared by the general public. Detailed rules govern what counts as substantial and unreasonable interference, and the main remedies and defenses (including “coming to the nuisance”).
cards.hardContent: Nuisance is an intentional invasion of public or private property rights that substantially and unreasonably interferes with peaceful and quiet enjoyment. It is best understood as a description of a type of harm caused by otherwise actionable conduct, not as a standalone tort. There are two principal forms: • Private nuisance: a substantial and unreasonable interference with an individual’s use or enjoyment of land. • Public nuisance: an unreasonable interference with the health, safety, or property rights of the community at large; a private plaintiff can recover only if she suffers unique damage not suffered by the public generally. The doctrine focuses on how substantial and unreasonable the interference is, when a private plaintiff may sue over a public nuisance, and what remedies (damages, injunctions) and defenses (such as “coming to the nuisance”) apply.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: Vicarious liability arises when a defendant commits a tort against a plaintiff and a third person is held liable because of a legal relationship with the defendant. 2. Common vicarious liability relationships: 2.1. Employers for employees under respondeat superior: liable for torts committed by employees within the scope of employment, with some intentional torts also treated as within scope. 2.2. Employers for independent contractors: generally no vicarious liability, subject to exceptions for inherently dangerous activities and non-delegable duties (including duties to keep premises safe for customers). 2.3. Partners in a partnership: each partner is vicariously liable for other partners’ torts committed within the scope of the partnership business. 2.4. Parent–child: no vicarious liability for children’s torts, but parents may be directly negligent based on knowledge of dangerous propensities or facilitation of the tort. 2.5. Tavernkeepers (dram shop-type liability): businesses serving alcohol may be liable to third parties injured by intoxicated patrons when the business is negligent in serving. 3. Exam approach: Identify the relationship between the tortfeasor and the proposed vicariously liable party, then apply the specific rule for that relationship (e.g., employee vs. independent contractor, partner vs. parent, tavernkeeper).
cards.frontPrompt: What is vicarious liability, and what are the main relationships that can give rise to or limit vicarious liability (employers, independent contractors, partners, parents, and tavernkeepers)?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: {{c1::Vicarious liability}} arises when a defendant commits a tort against a plaintiff and a {{c2::third person is held liable because of a legal relationship}} with the defendant. 2. Common vicarious liability relationships: 2.1. {{c3::Employers for employees under respondeat superior}}. 2.2. {{c4::Employers for independent contractors}} (generally no liability, subject to exceptions). 2.3. {{c5::Partners}} in a partnership. 2.4. {{c6::Parent–child}} (no true vicarious liability; only potential direct negligence). 2.5. {{c7::Tavernkeepers}} and similar alcohol vendors (often under {{c8::dram shop}} rules).
cards.easyContent: Vicarious liability makes one person liable for another’s tort because of their legal relationship. Key contexts: employers and employees (respondeat superior), limited liability for independent contractors (with exceptions), partners in partnerships, no true vicarious liability for parents (only direct negligence), and tavernkeepers’ possible liability for negligently serving intoxicated patrons.
cards.mediumContent: Vicarious liability arises when a tortfeasor’s relationship with another person makes that other person liable. The main contexts: (1) employers are liable for employees’ torts within the scope of employment under respondeat superior; (2) employers are generally not vicariously liable for independent contractors, except for inherently dangerous activities and non-delegable duties, including the duty of businesses open to the public to keep premises reasonably safe; (3) each partner is vicariously liable for other partners’ torts committed within the scope of the partnership business; (4) parents are not vicariously liable for their children’s torts, but may be directly negligent if they knew or should have known of a child’s dangerous propensity or facilitated the tort; and (5) tavernkeepers may be liable to third parties injured by intoxicated patrons when they negligently serve them, often under dram shop statutes.
cards.hardContent: Vicarious liability occurs when a defendant commits a tort and another person is held liable because of a recognized legal relationship. On exams, you must: (1) identify the relationship (e.g., employer–employee, employer–independent contractor, partners, parent–child, tavernkeeper–patron); and (2) apply the specific rule for that relationship. Under respondeat superior, employers are liable for employees’ torts committed within the scope of employment, with defined circumstances where intentional torts also fall within scope. Employers are generally not vicariously liable for independent contractors’ torts, but exceptions exist for inherently dangerous activities and non-delegable duties, including a business’s duty to keep premises safe for customers. In partnerships, each partner is vicariously liable for co-partners’ torts committed in the ordinary course of the partnership business. Parents are not vicariously liable for their children’s torts, though they may be directly liable for negligent supervision or entrustment when they knew or should have known of a child’s dangerous propensities or facilitated the tort. Tavernkeepers and similar alcohol vendors may be liable to third parties injured by intoxicated patrons where the vendor negligently serves them, often under dram shop statutes or analogous negligence principles.
cards.mnemonic: RIP PT: Respondeat, Independent contractor, Partners, Parents (direct only), Tavernkeepers.
