cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Joint and Several Liability, Contribution, and Indemnity
cards.rawHeader: Torts 043. Joint and Several Liability, Contribution, and Indemnity
cards.front: Joint and Several Liability, Contribution, and Indemnity
cards.backPlain: 1. Joint and several liability: 1.1. Arises if the acts of two or more defendants combine to produce a single, indivisible injury. 1.2. Each defendant is jointly and severally liable for the entire harm if his actions were a factor in bringing about the plaintiff's injury. 1.3. Note: Most states have replaced traditional joint and several liability with apportionment of damages among multiple defendants by percentages of fault. 1.4. Defendants acting in concert: If two or more defendants act in concert and injure the plaintiff, each is jointly and severally liable for the plaintiff's entire injury; this applies even if the injury and defendants' culpability are divisible. 1.5. Satisfaction: If the plaintiff recovers fully from one defendant, she may not recover more from another jointly liable defendant. 2. Contribution: 2.1. A defendant who pays more than her share of damages under joint and several liability can assert a claim against jointly liable parties for the excess paid. 2.2. Contribution is not applicable to intentional tort liability. 2.3. Contribution is usually imposed in proportion to relative fault. 3. Indemnity: 3.1. Involves shifting the entire loss between or among defendants. 3.2. Available by contract, in vicarious liability situations, or under strict products liability.
cards.frontPrompt: When does joint and several liability apply, and how do contribution and indemnity differ in reallocating damages among defendants?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Joint and several liability}}: 1.1. Arises if the acts of {{c2::two or more defendants combine to produce a single, indivisible injury}}. 1.2. Each defendant is jointly and severally liable for {{c3::the entire harm}} if his actions were {{c4::a factor in bringing about the plaintiff's injury}}. 1.3. Note: Most states have replaced traditional joint and several liability with {{c5::apportionment of damages by percentages of fault}}. 1.4. Defendants {{c6::acting in concert}}: If two or more defendants act in concert and injure the plaintiff, each is jointly and severally liable for the plaintiff's entire injury; this applies even if the injury and defendants' culpability are {{c7::divisible}}. 1.5. {{c8::Satisfaction}}: If the plaintiff recovers fully from one defendant, she may not recover more from another jointly liable defendant. 2. {{c9::Contribution}}: 2.1. A defendant who pays more than her share of damages under joint and several liability can assert a claim against {{c10::jointly liable parties for the excess paid}}. 2.2. Contribution is {{c11::not applicable to intentional tort liability}}. 2.3. Contribution is usually imposed in proportion to {{c12::relative fault}}. 3. {{c13::Indemnity}}: 3.1. Involves shifting {{c14::the entire loss}} between or among defendants. 3.2. Available by {{c15::contract}}, in {{c16::vicarious liability}} situations, or under {{c17::strict products liability}}.
cards.easyContent: Joint and several liability lets a plaintiff recover the full amount of damages from any defendant whose conduct contributed to an indivisible injury. Among themselves, defendants can reallocate payment through contribution (sharing based on fault) or indemnity (one shifting the entire loss to another).
cards.mediumContent: Joint and several liability applies when two or more defendants’ acts combine to cause a single, indivisible injury, making each liable for the entire harm if their conduct was a factual cause. Many states now apportion damages by fault, but traditional rules still appear on exams. When defendants act in concert, each is jointly and severally liable even if their culpability is theoretically divisible, and full satisfaction from one bars further recovery. A defendant who overpays can seek contribution from other jointly liable defendants, usually in proportion to relative fault, but contribution is not available for intentional torts. Indemnity, by contrast, shifts the entire loss from one defendant to another and arises by contract, in vicarious liability relationships, or in strict products liability chains.
cards.hardContent: Joint and several liability arises when the acts of two or more defendants combine to produce a single, indivisible injury; any defendant whose conduct was a factor in causing the harm is liable for the entire amount of damages. Many jurisdictions have modified or abolished pure joint and several liability in favor of apportioning damages among multiple tortfeasors by percentage of fault, but defendants acting in concert remain jointly and severally liable for the plaintiff’s entire injury, even if their culpability could be divided. Once the plaintiff obtains full satisfaction from one defendant, she cannot recover additional amounts from others who are jointly liable. Contribution allows a defendant who has paid more than her fair share under joint and several liability to recover the excess from other jointly liable defendants, typically in proportion to their relative fault; contribution is not available for intentional tortfeasors. Indemnity, in contrast, shifts the entire loss from one defendant to another and is available by express or implied contract, in vicarious liability situations (e.g., employer against employee), and in strict products liability (e.g., retailer against manufacturer).
cards.mnemonic: "JSC-I": Joint/Several, Share (contribution), Complete shift (indemnity).
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::joint and several liability}}, any defendant can be liable for {{c2::all damages for an indivisible injury}}; {{c3::contribution}} reallocates by {{c4::relative fault}}, while {{c5::indemnity}} {{c6::shifts the entire loss}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 001-1. Intentional Torts – Prima Facie Elements
cards.backPlain: Prima facie case for an intentional tort requires: 1. Act by D 1.1 There must be some volitional movement by D. 2. Intent 2.1 Specific intent: D intends to bring about a specific harmful or offensive result. 2.2 General intent: D knows with substantial certainty that the tortious result will occur from D's act. 3. Causation 3.1 D's conduct must be a substantial factor in bringing about the resulting harm. 4. Damages 4.1 Compensatory (monetary) damages are available for intentional torts. 4.2 Punitive damages are available when the intentional tort is committed with malice.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of a prima facie case for an intentional tort (act, intent, causation, and damages), and how are specific and general intent defined?
cards.cloze: Prima facie case for an {{c1::intentional tort}} requires: 1. {{c2::Act by D}} 1.1 There must be some {{c3::volitional movement}} by D. 2. {{c4::Intent}} 2.1 {{c5::Specific intent}}: D intends to bring about a {{c6::specific harmful or offensive result}}. 2.2 {{c7::General intent}}: D knows with {{c8::substantial certainty}} that the {{c9::tortious result}} will occur from D's act. 3. {{c10::Causation}} 3.1 D's conduct must be a {{c11::substantial factor}} in bringing about the resulting harm. 4. {{c12::Damages}} 4.1 {{c13::Compensatory (monetary) damages}} are available for intentional torts. 4.2 {{c14::Punitive damages}} are available when the intentional tort is committed with {{c15::malice}}.
cards.easyContent: A prima facie intentional tort needs a volitional act, intent (specific or general), causation, and damages (compensatory, with possible punitive damages for malice).
cards.mediumContent: To establish a prima facie intentional tort, P must show: (1) an act by D involving a volitional movement; (2) intent, either specific (D intends a particular harmful or offensive result) or general (D knows with substantial certainty that the result will occur); (3) causation, meaning D's act is a substantial factor in producing the harm; and (4) damages, with compensatory damages always potentially available and punitive damages when D acts with malice.
cards.hardContent: A prima facie case for an intentional tort consists of: (1) an act by D, requiring some volitional movement rather than a purely reflexive motion; (2) intent, which can be (a) specific intent—D's conscious objective is to bring about a specific harmful or offensive result, or (b) general intent—D knows with substantial certainty that the tortious result will follow from his conduct; (3) causation, requiring that D's conduct be a substantial factor in bringing about the resulting harm; and (4) damages, which typically include compensatory monetary damages to make P whole, and may include punitive damages where D's intentional wrongdoing is accompanied by malice or particularly egregious conduct.
cards.mnemonic: AIC-D: Act, Intent (specific or general), Causation, Damages.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 001-2. Intentional Torts – Transferred Intent Doctrine
cards.backPlain: Transferred intent doctrine for intentional torts: 1. When it arises 1.1 D acts with the intent to commit a given intentional tort but instead: 1.1.1 Commits the intended tort against a different person than intended; or 1.1.2 Commits a different tort than intended against the original person; or 1.1.3 Commits a different tort against a different person than intended. 2. Effect of transferred intent 2.1 D's original intent transfers to the tort actually committed and/or the person actually harmed. 2.2 As a result, D is liable as if D had intended the actual tort against the actual victim. 3. Torts covered 3.1 Transferred intent applies only to the classic intentional torts: 3.1.1 Assault 3.1.2 Battery 3.1.3 False imprisonment 3.1.4 Trespass (to land or chattels, depending on jurisdiction).
cards.frontPrompt: How does the transferred intent doctrine operate in intentional torts, and to which torts does it apply?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::transferred intent doctrine}} for intentional torts: 1. When it arises 1.1 D acts with the intent to commit a given {{c2::intentional tort}} but instead: 1.1.1 Commits the intended tort against a {{c3::different person}} than intended; or 1.1.2 Commits a {{c4::different tort}} than intended against the original person; or 1.1.3 Commits a {{c5::different tort}} against a {{c6::different person}} than intended. 2. Effect of transferred intent 2.1 D's original intent {{c7::transfers}} to the tort actually committed and/or the person actually harmed. 2.2 D is therefore {{c8::liable}} as if D had intended the actual tort against the actual victim. 3. Torts covered 3.1 Transferred intent applies only to the classic intentional torts: {{c9::assault}}, {{c10::battery}}, {{c11::false imprisonment}}, and {{c12::trespass}}.
cards.easyContent: Transferred intent lets D's intent to commit one classic intentional tort against one person transfer when D actually harms a different person and/or commits a different classic intentional tort (assault, battery, false imprisonment, or trespass).
cards.mediumContent: Under the transferred intent doctrine, if D intends to commit one classic intentional tort but instead injures a different person, or ends up committing a different classic intentional tort, D's original intent transfers to the actual victim and tort. This doctrine is limited to the classic intentional torts of assault, battery, false imprisonment, and trespass, and it makes D liable as though D had intended the actual outcome.
cards.hardContent: The transferred intent doctrine applies in intentional torts when D acts with the intent to commit one of the classic intentional torts but the result deviates from what D specifically intended. If D intends to commit a tort against one person but instead (a) commits that tort against a different person, (b) commits a different tort against the intended person, or (c) commits a different tort against a different person, D's original intent transfers to the actual victim and the tort actually committed. Transferred intent is limited to the classic intentional torts—assault, battery, false imprisonment, and trespass—and it imposes liability on D as though D had specifically intended the actual harmful result that occurred.
cards.mnemonic: ABFT: Assault, Battery, False imprisonment, Trespass for transferred intent.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card isolating the transferred intent doctrine: its triggering scenarios, legal effect, and covered intentional torts.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::transferred intent}}, D's intent for one {{c2::classic intentional tort}} transfers to the {{c3::actual victim}} and {{c4::tort committed}}; applies only to {{c5::assault, battery, false imprisonment, and trespass}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Protective Defenses – Common Requirements & Deadly Force
cards.rawHeader: Torts 010-1. Protective Defenses – Common Requirements & Deadly Force
cards.front: Protective Defenses – Common Requirements & Deadly Force
cards.backPlain: Common requirements for protective defenses (self-defense, defense of others, defense of property): 1. Reasonable belief: 1.1 D must reasonably believe a tort is being committed or is about to be committed. 2. Proper timing: 2.1 The tort must be in progress or imminent. 3. Reasonable force: 3.1 The force used must be proportionate to the threat of harm. 3.2 Deadly force is allowed only if D reasonably believes a life is in danger. 3.3 Deadly force is never permitted to protect property alone.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the common requirements for self-defense, defense of others, and defense of property, and when is deadly force allowed or forbidden?
cards.cloze: Common requirements for {{c1::protective defenses}} (self-defense, defense of others, defense of property): 1. {{c2::Reasonable belief}}: D must reasonably believe a {{c3::tort is being committed or is about to be committed}}. 2. {{c4::Proper timing}}: The tort must be {{c5::in progress or imminent}}. 3. {{c6::Reasonable force}}: The force used must be {{c7::proportionate to the threat of harm}}. - {{c8::Deadly force}} is allowed only if D reasonably believes a {{c9::life is in danger}}. - Deadly force is {{c10::never permitted to protect property alone}}.
cards.easyContent: All three protective defenses require: a reasonable belief in a tort, proper timing (in progress or imminent), and proportionate force. Deadly force is allowed only to protect life, never just property.
cards.mediumContent: For self-defense, defense of others, and defense of property, D must (1) reasonably believe a tort is occurring or imminent; (2) act while the tort is in progress or imminent; and (3) use force proportionate to the threat. Deadly force is permissible only where D reasonably believes a life is in danger and is never allowed solely to protect property.
cards.hardContent: Protective defenses share three core elements: (1) reasonable belief—D must reasonably believe that a tort is currently being committed or is about to be committed; (2) proper timing—the threat must be in progress or imminent; and (3) reasonable force—the level of force must be proportionate to the threatened harm. Deadly force is a special case: it is allowed only when D reasonably believes a life is in danger and is categorically unavailable for the defense of property alone.
cards.mnemonic: R-T-F: Reasonable belief, proper Timing, proportionate Force; deadly force only for lives.
cards.clozeLite: Protective defenses require {{c1::reasonable belief}}, {{c2::proper timing}}, and {{c3::proportionate force}}; {{c4::deadly force only to protect life}}, {{c5::never for property alone}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 010-2. Self-Defense – Retreat & Initial Aggressor Rules
cards.backPlain: Self-defense as a defense to intentional torts: 1. Retreat rules: 1.1 Majority rule: No duty to retreat before using force, including deadly force, if otherwise justified. 1.2 Minority rule: Some jurisdictions impose a duty to retreat, if it can be done safely, before using deadly force. 2. Initial aggressor limitations: 2.1 An initial aggressor generally cannot claim self-defense. 2.2 Self-defense becomes available to an initial aggressor only if: 2.2.1 The initial threat has terminated (the aggressor withdraws and communicates withdrawal and the other continues or renews the threat); or 2.2.2 The plaintiff (or victim) responds to the initial aggressor’s non-deadly force with deadly force, thereby escalating the confrontation.
cards.frontPrompt: How do the retreat rules and initial aggressor limitations shape when self-defense is available as a defense to intentional torts?
cards.cloze: Self-defense as a defense to intentional torts: 1. {{c1::Retreat rules}}: - {{c2::Majority rule}}: {{c3::No duty to retreat}} before using force, including deadly force, if otherwise justified. - {{c4::Minority rule}}: Some jurisdictions require {{c5::retreat, if it can be done safely, before using deadly force}}. 2. {{c6::Initial aggressor limitations}}: - An {{c7::initial aggressor}} generally {{c8::cannot claim self-defense}}. - Self-defense is available to an initial aggressor only if: • The {{c9::initial threat has terminated}}; or • The plaintiff responds to {{c10::non-deadly force with deadly force}}, escalating the confrontation.
cards.easyContent: Most jurisdictions impose no duty to retreat before using justified force in self-defense; a minority require safe retreat before deadly force. Initial aggressors generally cannot claim self-defense unless the conflict ends or the other party escalates from non-deadly to deadly force.
cards.mediumContent: In self-defense, the majority rule is that there is no duty to retreat before using even deadly force, while a minority requires safe retreat before deadly force may be used. An initial aggressor typically loses the right to self-defense, but regains it if the initial threat has ended (e.g., by withdrawal) or if the other person escalates by responding to non-deadly force with deadly force.
cards.hardContent: Self-defense is limited by both retreat doctrines and the status of the defender as an initial aggressor. Under the majority rule, an otherwise justified defender has no duty to retreat before using force, including deadly force. A minority of jurisdictions, however, require that the defender safely retreat, where possible, before resorting to deadly force. Additionally, an initial aggressor generally cannot invoke self-defense. That bar is lifted only in narrow circumstances: when the initial aggressor’s threat has truly terminated (often by withdrawal and communication of withdrawal followed by renewed aggression from the other party), or when the other party escalates the encounter by responding to the aggressor’s non-deadly force with deadly force.
cards.mnemonic: RETREAT: Regular Ender Turns Retreater; Aggressor Exits Then defends.
cards.clozeLite: Majority: {{c1::no duty to retreat}} before {{c2::deadly force}}. Minority: {{c3::safe retreat required}} before deadly force. {{c4::Initial aggressor}} regains self-defense only after {{c5::withdrawal or victim’s deadly escalation}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Defense of others as a defense to intentional torts: 1. Reasonable belief about the person aided: 1.1 D must have a reasonable belief that the person he is aiding would have the right of self-defense against the aggressor. 2. Scope of permissible force: 2.1 D may use as much force as he could have used if the injury were threatened to him—that is, as if he were acting in self-defense under the same circumstances.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a defendant use force in defense of others, and how much force may be used?
cards.cloze: Defense of others as a defense to intentional torts: 1. {{c1::Reasonable belief}} about the person aided: - D must reasonably believe that the person he is aiding {{c2::would have the right of self-defense}} against the aggressor. 2. {{c3::Scope of force}}: - D may use as much force as he could have used {{c4::if the injury were threatened to him}}, i.e., as if he were acting in {{c5::self-defense}} under the same circumstances.
cards.easyContent: Defense of others applies when D reasonably believes the person aided has a right to self-defense. D can use the same amount of force that would be allowed if the attack were on D himself.
cards.mediumContent: A defendant may claim defense of others if he reasonably believes the person he helps has a valid right to self-defense. In that case, he may use as much force as would be justified if he himself were threatened with the same harm (no more than would be allowed in self-defense).
cards.hardContent: Defense of others is available where D reasonably believes that the person he is aiding could properly invoke self-defense against the aggressor. Under this view, D “steps into the shoes” of the person aided: if that person would lack a valid self-defense claim, D cannot rely on defense of others. When the defense applies, D may use an amount and type of force that would be justified if the threat were directed at him personally, subject to the same proportionality and deadly-force limitations that govern self-defense.
cards.mnemonic: DEFEND OTHERS: Do Exactly Force ENtitled to, Not Deeper.
cards.clozeLite: Defense of others applies if D {{c1::reasonably believes}} the person aided {{c2::has a valid right to self-defense}} and D may use {{c3::no more force than self-defense allows}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Defense of Property – Force, Privilege & Mistake
cards.rawHeader: Torts 010-4. Defense of Property – Force, Privilege & Mistake
cards.front: Defense of Property – Force, Privilege & Mistake
cards.backPlain: Defense of property as a defense to intentional torts: 1. Availability: 1.1 Defense of property is available to prevent a tort against property (e.g., trespass to land or chattels). 2. Permissible force: 2.1 Only reasonable, non-deadly force may be used. 2.2 Force that is deadly or causes serious bodily harm is not allowed for defense of property alone. 3. Privileged entrants: 3.1 Defense of property is unavailable if the initial actor had a privilege to enter the land (e.g., to recapture chattel or enter out of necessity). 4. Mistake rules: 4.1 A reasonable mistake is allowed as to whether an intrusion occurred. 4.2 A mistake is not allowed as to whether a privilege existed—the defendant acts at his peril if the entrant is privileged.
cards.frontPrompt: When is defense of property available, what force may be used, how do privileges limit it, and what mistakes are allowed?
cards.cloze: Defense of property as a defense to intentional torts: 1. {{c1::Availability}}: - Available to {{c2::prevent a tort against property}}. 2. {{c3::Permissible force}}: - Only {{c4::reasonable, non-deadly force}} may be used. - Force that is {{c5::deadly or causes serious bodily harm}} is not allowed for defense of property alone. 3. {{c6::Privileged entrants}}: - Defense of property is {{c7::unavailable}} if the initial actor had a {{c8::privilege to enter}} the land (e.g., to recapture chattel). 4. {{c9::Mistake rules}}: - A {{c10::reasonable mistake}} is allowed as to whether an {{c11::intrusion occurred}}. - No mistake is allowed as to whether a {{c12::privilege existed}}.
cards.easyContent: Defense of property can be used to prevent torts against property using only reasonable, non-deadly force. It cannot be used against privileged entrants, and mistakes are allowed only about whether an intrusion occurred, not about whether the entrant was privileged.
cards.mediumContent: A defendant may use defense of property to prevent torts against property, but only with reasonable, non-deadly force; deadly or seriously harmful force is never justified for property alone. The defense does not apply against those who have a privilege to enter (such as to recapture chattel or in necessity). Reasonable mistakes about whether an intrusion occurred are allowed, but the defendant may not be mistaken about the existence of a privilege.
cards.hardContent: Defense of property is limited to preventing tortious interferences with property interests, such as trespass to land or chattels. Even then, the defendant may only use reasonable, non-deadly force; any force that is deadly or likely to cause serious bodily harm is categorically unavailable when only property is at stake. The defense is further restricted by privileges: it is not available against entrants who have a legal privilege to be on the property (for example, someone entering to recapture chattel or under necessity). With respect to mistakes, the law allows a reasonable mistake about whether an intrusion is actually occurring, but it does not excuse a mistake about whether the entrant is privileged—on that question, the defendant acts at his peril.
cards.mnemonic: D-NO-PM: Deadly? NO. Privilege? Mistake only on intrusion.
cards.clozeLite: Defense of property allows only {{c1::reasonable, non-deadly force}}; it is unavailable against {{c2::privileged entrants}}, and mistake is allowed only about {{c3::whether an intrusion occurred}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Defamation – Definition and Common Law Elements
cards.rawHeader: Torts 013-1. Defamation – Definition and Common Law Elements
cards.backPlain: 1. General Definition 1.1 Defamation is a false statement concerning the plaintiff, made by the defendant to at least one person other than the plaintiff, that is harmful to the plaintiff's reputation. 1.2 The statement must be one of fact (or implying specific facts), not mere pure opinion, and must be defamatory in that it adversely affects reputation. 2. Common Law Elements 2.1 False and defamatory statement: The statement must be false and defamatory, meaning it adversely affects the plaintiff's reputation and is based on specific facts. 2.2 Concerning the plaintiff: It must be reasonably understood that the statement concerns a living plaintiff or a very small group of plaintiffs. 2.3 Publication: The statement must be communicated to at least one person other than the plaintiff. 2.4 Harmful to reputation: The statement must be of a kind that harms the plaintiff's reputation, such that a reasonable person would think less of the plaintiff.
cards.frontPrompt: What is defamation, and what are the core common law elements (false and defamatory statement, concerning the plaintiff, publication, and harm to reputation)?

General Definition 1.1 {{c1::Defamation}} is a {{c2::false statement}} concerning the plaintiff, made by the defendant to at least {{c3::one person other than the plaintiff}}, that is {{c4::harmful to the plaintiff's reputation}}. 1.2 The statement must be one of {{c5::fact (or implying specific facts)}}, not mere pure opinion, and must be {{c6::defamatory}} in that it adversely affects reputation. 2. Common Law Elements 2.1 {{c7::False and defamatory statement}}: The statement must be false and defamatory, meaning it adversely affects the plaintiff's reputation and is based on specific facts. 2.2 {{c8::Concerning the plaintiff}}: It must be reasonably understood that the statement concerns a {{c9::living plaintiff or a very small group of plaintiffs}}. 2.3 {{c10::Publication}}: The statement must be communicated to at least {{c11::one person other than the plaintiff}}. 2.4 {{c12::Harmful to reputation}}: The statement must be of a kind that harms the plaintiff's reputation, such that a {{c13::reasonable person}} would think less of the plaintiff.
cards.easyContent: Defamation is a false, defamatory statement of fact about the plaintiff, communicated to at least one other person, that harms the plaintiff’s reputation. The elements are: false and defamatory statement, concerning the plaintiff, publication, and harm to reputation.
cards.mediumContent: At common law, defamation requires: (1) a false and defamatory statement of fact that adversely affects reputation; (2) that reasonably concerns a living plaintiff or a very small group of plaintiffs; (3) publication, meaning communication to at least one person other than the plaintiff; and (4) harm to reputation, such that a reasonable person would think less of the plaintiff.
cards.hardContent: Defamation is a false statement of fact concerning the plaintiff, made by the defendant to at least one person other than the plaintiff, that is harmful to the plaintiff's reputation. The common law elements are: (1) a false and defamatory statement of fact that adversely affects the plaintiff’s reputation and is based on specific facts (not pure opinion); (2) that is reasonably understood to concern a particular living plaintiff or a very small group of plaintiffs; (3) publication, meaning intentional or negligent communication to at least one third person; and (4) harm to reputation, meaning the statement is of a kind that would cause a reasonable person to think less of the plaintiff.
cards.mnemonic: FCPH: False statement, Concerning plaintiff, Publication, Harm.
cards.clozeLite: Defamation requires a {{c1::false and defamatory statement of fact}} {{c2::concerning a living plaintiff}}, {{c3::publication to a third person}}, and {{c4::harm to reputation}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Defamation – Publication and Republication (Including ISP Immunity)
cards.backPlain: 1. Publication 1.1 Publication means communication of the defamatory statement to at least one person other than the plaintiff. 1.2 Publication may be intentional or negligent; it is enough that the defendant either intended or should have foreseen that the statement would be heard or read by a third person. 2. Liability for Republication 2.1 A republisher of a defamatory statement is liable to the same extent as the original publisher. 2.2 Each separate publication can give rise to a separate cause of action, subject to any applicable single-publication rules. 3. Internet Service Providers (ISP) Immunity 3.1 Internet service providers (ISPs) and similar online platforms are generally not liable for defamatory statements made by others and posted on their platforms. 3.2 This immunity arises from federal statute (e.g., Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act), which protects providers and users of interactive computer services from being treated as the publisher or speaker of information provided by another content provider.
cards.frontPrompt: What constitutes publication in defamation, how is liability imposed for republication, and how does federal law protect internet service providers?
cards.cloze: 1. Publication 1.1 {{c1::Publication}} means communication of the defamatory statement to at least {{c2::one person other than the plaintiff}}. 1.2 Publication may be {{c3::intentional or negligent}}; it is enough that the defendant either intended or should have foreseen that the statement would be heard or read by a {{c4::third person}}. 2. Liability for Republication 2.1 A {{c5::republisher}} of a defamatory statement is liable to the {{c6::same extent as the original publisher}}. 2.2 Each separate publication can give rise to a {{c7::separate cause of action}}, subject to any applicable {{c8::single-publication rules}}. 3. Internet Service Providers (ISP) Immunity 3.1 {{c9::Internet service providers (ISPs)}} and similar online platforms are generally {{c10::not liable}} for defamatory statements made by others and posted on their platforms. 3.2 This immunity arises from {{c11::federal statute}} (e.g., {{c12::Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act}}), which protects providers and users of interactive computer services from being treated as the {{c13::publisher or speaker}} of information provided by another content provider.
cards.easyContent: Publication in defamation means communicating the defamatory statement to at least one person other than the plaintiff, intentionally or negligently. Anyone who republishes defamation is generally as liable as the original publisher, but federal law (like CDA § 230) shields ISPs from liability for defamatory content posted by others.
cards.mediumContent: Defamation requires publication, meaning that the defendant intentionally or negligently communicated the defamatory statement to at least one third person. A republisher is generally liable to the same extent as the original publisher, and each publication can potentially be its own wrong, subject to single-publication rules. However, federal law (e.g., Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act) grants ISPs and similar platforms immunity from being treated as the publisher or speaker of content provided by others, so they are not liable for user-posted defamation.
cards.hardContent: Publication in defamation occurs when the defendant intentionally or negligently communicates a defamatory statement to at least one person other than the plaintiff. The communication need not be widespread; a single third person is enough, as long as the defendant intended or should have foreseen that a third person would receive it. Under the republication rule, anyone who repeats or disseminates a defamatory statement is liable as a publisher to the same extent as the original publisher, and each separate publication can potentially give rise to a separate cause of action, subject to any applicable single-publication statutes or rules. By contrast, federal statute, such as Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, generally immunizes internet service providers and similar online platforms from defamation liability for content created by third-party users, by preventing them from being treated as the publisher or speaker of that information.
cards.mnemonic: Publish to one other, repeaters liable, but CDA shields ISPs.
cards.clozeLite: Defamation needs {{c1::publication}} to a {{c2::third person}}; a {{c3::republisher}} is as liable as the original, but {{c4::CDA § 230}} immunizes {{c5::ISPs}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Defamation – Damages, Falsity/Fault Framework, and Truth as a Defense
cards.rawHeader: Torts 013-3. Defamation – Damages, Falsity/Fault, and Truth
cards.backPlain: 1. Falsity and Fault Framework 1.1 Falsity and fault are always required concepts in defamation law. 1.2 At common law, there was no requirement that the plaintiff prove fault; liability could be imposed without showing negligence or intent. 1.3 Modern constitutional rules (e.g., under the First Amendment) impose fault requirements in many cases and allocate the burden of proving falsity or truth. 1.4 Depending on whether the plaintiff is a public official, public figure, or private figure, and whether the matter is of public concern, the plaintiff may need to prove falsity and a particular level of fault (e.g., negligence or actual malice), or the defendant may bear the burden of proving truth. 2. Damages (at Common Law) 2.1 The plaintiff's burden of proving damages depends on: (a) the type of plaintiff (public official/figure vs. private figure); (b) whether the statement involves a matter of public concern; and (c) whether the defamation is libel, slander, or slander per se. 2.2 Historically, some forms of libel and slander per se allowed presumed damages, while other types of slander required proof of special damages, subject to modern constitutional limits. 3. Truth as a Defense 3.1 Truth is a complete defense to defamation. 3.2 If the defendant establishes that the gist or sting of the statement is true, the plaintiff cannot recover for defamation, even if the statement is slightly inaccurate in detail.
cards.frontPrompt: How do falsity and fault operate in modern defamation law, how do damages requirements vary, and what is the role of truth as a defense?

Damages (at Common Law) 2.1 The plaintiff's burden of proving {{c17::damages}} depends on: (a) the {{c18::type of plaintiff}}; (b) whether the statement involves a {{c19::matter of public concern}}; and (c) whether the defamation is {{c20::libel, slander, or slander per se}}. 2.2 Historically, some forms of {{c21::libel}} and {{c22::slander per se}} allowed {{c23::presumed damages}}, while other types of {{c24::slander}} required proof of {{c25::special damages}}, subject to modern constitutional limits. 3. Truth as a Defense 3.1 {{c26::Truth}} is a {{c27::complete defense}} to defamation. 3.2 If the defendant establishes that the {{c28::gist or sting}} of the statement is true, the plaintiff cannot recover for defamation, even if the statement is slightly inaccurate in detail.
cards.easyContent: Defamation law always involves falsity and fault, though modern constitutional rules determine who must prove them and at what level (e.g., negligence or actual malice). The plaintiff’s need to prove damages depends on the type of plaintiff, whether the matter is of public concern, and whether the claim is libel, slander, or slander per se. Truth is a complete defense if the gist of the statement is true.
cards.mediumContent: Under common law, a plaintiff did not have to prove fault, but modern First Amendment doctrine usually requires some level of fault and often places the burden of proving falsity on the plaintiff, particularly for public officials/figures or matters of public concern. The damages framework varies with the type of plaintiff, whether the subject is of public concern, and whether the defamation is libel, slander, or slander per se; historically, libel and slander per se allowed presumed damages, while other slander required proof of special damages, all now subject to constitutional constraints. Truth is a complete defense if the defendant can show that the gist or sting of the statement is true.
cards.hardContent: Falsity and fault are always central to defamation. At common law, the plaintiff did not have to prove fault, but modern constitutional doctrine—primarily under the First Amendment—imposes fault requirements in many cases and allocates the burden of proving falsity or truth. For public officials and public figures, and often when speech involves a matter of public concern, the plaintiff typically must prove falsity and a heightened fault standard (such as actual malice), while in other contexts the defendant may bear the burden of proving truth or the plaintiff may only need to show negligence. The plaintiff’s damages burden depends on the type of plaintiff, whether the subject is of public concern, and whether the defamation is classified as libel, slander, or slander per se. Historically, libel and slander per se allowed presumed general damages, whereas other forms of slander required the plaintiff to prove special damages, though these rules are modified by constitutional limitations. Truth is a complete defense to defamation; if the defendant establishes that the gist or sting of the statement is substantially true, minor inaccuracies will not defeat the defense and the plaintiff cannot recover.

cards.clozeLite: Modern defamation usually requires {{c1::plaintiff to prove falsity}} and some {{c2::level of fault (negligence or actual malice)}}; {{c3::libel and slander per se historically allowed presumed damages}}; {{c4::truth is a complete defense if the gist is true}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 024-1. Specialized Standards of Care – Children
cards.backPlain: Children are generally not held to the ordinary reasonably prudent adult standard. Instead: 1. Basic child standard: 1.1 A child is held to the standard of care of a reasonable child of similar age, education, intelligence, and experience under like circumstances. 2. Very young children (incapacity): 2.1 Very young children—typically those under about 6–7 years old—are generally deemed to lack the capacity to be negligent at all. 3. Adult activities exception: 3.1 When a child engages in an inherently dangerous or otherwise adult activity (e.g., driving a car, operating a motorboat), the child must conform to the adult standard of care for that activity. These rules reflect that children’s abilities and judgment differ from adults’, but the law will not relax the standard when children undertake adult, hazardous activities.
cards.frontPrompt: How is the standard of care for children defined in negligence, including any age-related incapacity and the adult activities exception?
cards.cloze: Children are generally held to the standard of care of a {{c1::reasonable child of similar age, education, intelligence, and experience}} under like circumstances, rather than the reasonably prudent adult standard. Very young children—typically those under about {{c2::6–7 years old}}—are generally deemed to {{c3::lack capacity to be negligent}}. Under the {{c4::adult activities exception}}, a child who engages in an inherently dangerous or otherwise adult activity (such as {{c5::driving a car or operating a motorboat}}) must conform to the {{c6::adult standard of care}} for that activity.
cards.easyContent: Children are judged by a reasonable child standard based on age, education, intelligence, and experience. Very young children are usually incapable of negligence, but a child doing an adult, hazardous activity is held to the adult standard.
cards.mediumContent: The child standard of care is that of a reasonable child of similar age, education, intelligence, and experience. Very young children (around 6–7 and under) are generally considered incapable of negligence. If a child undertakes an adult, inherently dangerous activity (like driving), the child must meet the ordinary adult standard of care for that activity.
cards.hardContent: Negligence law adjusts the standard of care for children. Ordinarily, a child is judged not by the reasonably prudent adult standard but by what a reasonable child of similar age, education, intelligence, and experience would do under like circumstances. Very young children—commonly those under about 6–7 years old—are generally deemed incapable of negligence altogether, on the theory that they lack the capacity to appreciate and avoid unreasonable risks. However, under the adult activities exception, when a child chooses to engage in an inherently dangerous or otherwise adult activity (such as driving an automobile, using a snowmobile, or operating a motorboat), the law requires that the child conform to the adult standard of care for that activity and may hold the child liable for failing to do so.
cards.mnemonic: KIDS ACT GROWN: Kids normally child-standard, but adult acts = adult standard.
cards.clozeLite: A child is held to a {{c1::reasonable child of similar age, education, intelligence, and experience}} standard; very young children are {{c2::generally incapable of negligence}}; but for adult, inherently dangerous activities a child must meet the {{c3::ordinary adult standard of care}}.

cards.topic: Specialized Standards of Care – Common Carriers and Innkeepers
cards.rawHeader: Torts 024-2. Specialized Standards of Care – Common Carriers and Innkeepers
cards.front: Common Carriers & Innkeepers: Specialized Standard of Care
cards.backPlain: Common carriers and innkeepers owe more than just ordinary care in negligence. 1. High standard of care: 1.1 Common carriers (e.g., buses, trains, airlines) and innkeepers (e.g., hotels) are held to a high standard of care toward their passengers or guests. 2. Slight negligence: 2.1 They may be liable even for slight negligence that harms passengers or guests, given the special relationship and control they exercise over safety. This elevated standard reflects the dependence of passengers and guests on carriers and innkeepers for safe transport and lodging.
cards.frontPrompt: What standard of care do common carriers and innkeepers owe to their passengers and guests in negligence?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Common carriers}} (such as buses, trains, and airlines) and {{c2::innkeepers}} (such as hotels) are held to a {{c3::high standard of care}} toward their passengers or guests and may be liable even for {{c4::slight negligence}} that harms them.
cards.easyContent: Common carriers and innkeepers owe a high standard of care to passengers and guests and can be liable even for slight negligence.
cards.mediumContent: Because passengers and guests are highly dependent on them, common carriers and innkeepers are held to a high standard of care in tort. They may be liable to passengers or guests for even slight negligence that causes injury.
cards.hardContent: In negligence, common carriers (such as buses, railroads, and airlines) and innkeepers (such as hotels and similar establishments) are subject to an elevated standard of care because of their special relationship with passengers and guests. They are held to a high standard of care to ensure the safety of those they transport or lodge, and courts often state that they may be liable for even slight negligence that causes harm. This goes beyond the usual reasonably prudent person standard applied to ordinary defendants.

cards.clozeLite: Common {{c1::carriers}} and {{c2::innkeepers}} owe a {{c3::high standard of care}} and may be liable for {{c4::even slight negligence}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Specialized Standards of Care – Industry Custom as Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Torts 024-3. Specialized Standards of Care – Industry Custom as Evidence
cards.front: Industry Custom as Evidence of Standard of Care
cards.backPlain: Industry custom or usage can be relevant to determining the standard of care in negligence, but it is not conclusive. 1. Custom as evidence: 1.1 A well-established custom or practice in an industry may be used as evidence of what a reasonable person in that industry would do under similar circumstances. 2. Not automatically dispositive: 2.1 Failure to adhere to industry custom does not automatically establish a breach of duty. 2.2 Compliance with an industry custom does not automatically establish that the defendant was not negligent. The trier of fact may consider custom but ultimately decides whether the conduct met the legal standard of reasonable care.
cards.frontPrompt: How does industry custom or usage affect the determination of the standard of care and breach in negligence?
cards.cloze: Industry {{c1::custom or usage}} can be used as {{c2::evidence}} of the {{c3::standard of care}} in negligence. However, failure to adhere to custom does not automatically establish a {{c4::breach of duty}}, and compliance with custom does not automatically establish a {{c5::lack of negligence}}. Custom is relevant but {{c6::not dispositive}}; the trier of fact ultimately decides what is reasonable.
cards.easyContent: Industry custom is relevant evidence of what reasonable care looks like, but following or ignoring custom does not automatically decide negligence.
cards.mediumContent: Courts allow evidence of industry custom or usage as a guide to what reasonable care requires in a particular setting. But noncompliance with custom does not automatically mean breach, and compliance does not automatically negate negligence; the jury still decides whether the conduct was reasonable.
cards.hardContent: In negligence cases, parties frequently introduce evidence of industry custom or practice to inform the standard of care. A longstanding, well-accepted custom can be persuasive evidence of what a reasonable person engaged in that activity would do under similar circumstances. However, custom is not binding: a defendant’s failure to follow industry practice does not automatically establish breach of duty, because the custom itself may fall short of reasonable care. Conversely, a defendant who complies with custom can still be found negligent if the jury concludes that the custom is unreasonably lax. Thus, custom is relevant but not conclusive on whether the defendant met the standard of reasonable care.
cards.mnemonic: Custom counts as counsel, not command.
cards.clozeLite: Industry {{c1::custom or usage}} is {{c2::relevant but not conclusive}} evidence of {{c3::reasonable care and breach}} in negligence.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 024-4. Specialized Standards of Care – Professionals
cards.backPlain: Professionals are held to a specialized standard of care that reflects their training and expertise. 1. General professional standard: 1.1 A professional must act with the knowledge and skill of a reasonably competent member of the profession in good standing in similar communities under similar circumstances. 2. Medical professionals – national standard: 2.1 Physicians and other medical professionals are generally held to a national standard of care, not just a local community standard. 3. Application: 3.1 The standard is based on the profession’s norms and what a reasonably careful professional would do, not on the defendant’s own level of experience or personal best efforts. This specialized standard recognizes that professionals hold themselves out as having special skills and must meet the competence expected of the profession.
cards.frontPrompt: What standard of care applies to professionals in negligence, and how does it apply to medical professionals?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::professional}} must act with the {{c2::knowledge and skill}} of a {{c3::reasonably competent member of the profession}} in good standing in {{c4::similar communities}} under similar circumstances. {{c5::Medical professionals}} (such as physicians) are generally held to a {{c6::national standard of care}}, rather than a purely local standard.
cards.easyContent: Professionals must meet the standard of a reasonably competent member of their profession, and doctors are usually judged by a national medical standard.
cards.mediumContent: Professionals are held to the standard of care of a reasonably competent professional in good standing in similar communities, not merely to their own personal ability. Medical professionals are typically held to a national standard of care that reflects the profession’s norms across the country.
cards.hardContent: In negligence, professionals—such as lawyers, accountants, architects, and doctors—are judged by a specialized professional standard of care. They must exercise the knowledge and skill that a reasonably competent member of their profession in good standing in similar communities would exercise under comparable circumstances. The inquiry focuses on what the profession itself regards as minimally competent practice, not on the particular defendant’s experience level or subjective good faith. For medical professionals, the modern trend and the bar exam approach is to apply a national standard of care: physicians and similar providers are expected to meet the level of care, skill, and treatment that is ordinarily exercised by reasonably careful, similarly situated medical professionals nationwide.
cards.mnemonic: Pros: RPC in community; Docs: national norm.
cards.clozeLite: Professionals are held to the {{c1::reasonably competent professional}} standard in similar communities; {{c2::medical professionals}} are held to a {{c3::national}} standard of care.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Duty to Unknown and Anticipated Trespassers
cards.rawHeader: Torts 026-1. Duty to Unknown and Anticipated Trespassers
cards.front: Duty to Unknown and Anticipated Trespassers
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule on adult trespassers: 1.1 Unknown or undiscovered trespassers: - No duty of care is owed. 1.2 Anticipated trespassers (owner has reason to believe trespassers will be on the land): 1.2.1 Activities: - The owner has a duty to exercise reasonable care in carrying out activities on the property. 1.2.2 Dangerous conditions: - The owner has a duty to make safe or warn of any known, concealed, man-made hazards. - This duty is narrow and typically applies to artificial hazards. - Classic examples: spring guns, traps, and similar artificial hazards.
cards.frontPrompt: What duty of care does a landowner owe to unknown trespassers versus anticipated trespassers, including for activities and dangerous conditions?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule on adult trespassers: 1.1 {{c1::Unknown or undiscovered trespassers}}: - {{c2::No duty of care}} is owed. 1.2 {{c3::Anticipated trespassers}} (owner has reason to believe trespassers will be on the land): 1.2.1 Activities: - The owner has a duty to exercise {{c4::reasonable care}} in carrying out activities on the property. 1.2.2 Dangerous conditions: - The owner has a duty to {{c5::make safe or warn}} of any {{c6::known, concealed, man-made hazards}}. - This duty is {{c7::narrow and typically applies to artificial hazards}}. - Classic examples: {{c8::spring guns, traps, and similar artificial hazards}}.
cards.easyContent: Landowners owe no duty to unknown trespassers. For anticipated trespassers, they must use reasonable care in activities and must warn of or make safe known, concealed, man-made hazards like traps or spring guns.
cards.mediumContent: A landowner owes no duty of care to unknown or undiscovered trespassers. Once trespassers are anticipated—where the owner has reason to believe trespassers will be on the land—the landowner must exercise reasonable care in conducting activities and must warn of or make safe known, concealed, man-made dangers (e.g., spring guns or traps).
cards.hardContent: As to adult trespassers, premises liability distinguishes between unknown and anticipated trespassers. For unknown or undiscovered trespassers, the landowner owes no duty of care. For anticipated trespassers—when the owner has reason to believe trespassers will be present—the landowner must: (1) exercise reasonable care in carrying out activities on the land; and (2) warn of or make safe any known, concealed, man-made hazards. This second duty is narrow, focused on artificial, concealed dangers such as spring guns, traps, and similar man-made devices.
cards.mnemonic: U-A: Unknown = no duty; Anticipated = duty for Activities and artificial hazards.
cards.clozeLite: For {{c1::unknown trespassers}}, the landowner owes {{c2::no duty of care}}. For {{c3::anticipated trespassers}}, they must use {{c4::reasonable care in activities}} and {{c5::warn of or make safe known, concealed, man-made dangers}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Attractive nuisance doctrine (child trespassers): The landowner must take reasonable care to eliminate dangers on the property or protect children from those dangers if ALL of the following elements are met: 1. Dangerous condition: - The owner is aware or should be aware of a dangerous condition on the property. 2. Children nearby: - The owner knows or should know that children are in the vicinity. 3. Inability to appreciate risk: - The condition is likely to cause injury given a child's inability to appreciate the risk. 4. Risk outweighs utility/cost: - The magnitude of the risk outweighs the condition’s utility or the expense of remedying it.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of the attractive nuisance doctrine that create a duty to protect child trespassers?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::attractive nuisance doctrine}}, a landowner must take reasonable care to eliminate dangers or protect {{c2::child trespassers}} if ALL of the following are met: 1. {{c3::Dangerous condition}}: The owner is {{c4::aware or should be aware}} of a dangerous condition on the property. 2. {{c5::Children nearby}}: The owner {{c6::knows or should know that children are in the vicinity}}. 3. {{c7::Inability to appreciate risk}}: The condition is likely to cause injury given a child's {{c8::inability to appreciate the risk}}. 4. {{c9::Risk outweighs utility/cost}}: The {{c10::magnitude of the risk outweighs}} the condition’s {{c11::utility}} or the {{c12::expense of remedying it}}.
cards.easyContent: Attractive nuisance makes landowners protect child trespassers from dangerous conditions when: there is a dangerous condition; the owner knows children are nearby; kids can’t appreciate the risk; and the risk outweighs the condition’s utility or the cost of fixing it.
cards.mediumContent: The attractive nuisance doctrine imposes a duty on landowners toward child trespassers when four elements are met: (1) the owner knows or should know of a dangerous condition on the property; (2) the owner knows or should know that children are in the area; (3) the condition is likely to cause injury because children cannot appreciate the risk; and (4) the magnitude of the risk outweighs the condition’s utility or the cost of remedying it.
cards.hardContent: For child trespassers, the attractive nuisance doctrine creates an exception to the usual no-duty rule for trespassers. A landowner must take reasonable care to eliminate dangers or otherwise protect children if: (1) there is a dangerous condition on the property of which the owner is aware or should be aware; (2) the owner knows or should know that children are likely to be in the vicinity of that condition; (3) the condition is likely to cause injury because children, due to their youth, cannot appreciate the risk it poses; and (4) the magnitude of the risk posed by the condition outweighs either the condition’s utility or the expense of removing or remedying the danger.
cards.mnemonic: A.N. = D-K-K-R: Danger, Kids, Knowledge, Risk>Utility/Cost.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::attractive nuisance doctrine}} creates a duty when {{c2::four elements}} are met: {{c3::dangerous condition}}, {{c4::children nearby}}, {{c5::kids can’t appreciate risk}}, and {{c6::risk outweighs utility/cost}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 031-1. Comparative Negligence – Pure vs. Modified
cards.frontPrompt: What is comparative negligence, how does it affect damages, and how do pure and partial (modified) comparative negligence systems differ?
cards.backPlain: Comparative negligence 1. Basic concept 1.1. The defendant can establish that the plaintiff’s injuries are at least partially the result of the plaintiff’s own negligence. 1.2. The fact-finder apportions fault between the plaintiff and defendant by percentage and reduces the plaintiff’s recoverable damages accordingly. 2. Types of comparative negligence 2.1. Partial (modified) comparative negligence 2.1.1. The plaintiff can recover damages only if he was less than 50% at fault (or 50% or less in some states). 2.1.2. If the plaintiff’s fault exceeds the jurisdiction’s cutoff, the claim is barred (inactionable). 2.2. Pure comparative negligence 2.2.1. The plaintiff can recover damages even if he was more than 50% at fault. 2.2.2. Recovery is simply reduced by the plaintiff’s percentage of fault.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Comparative negligence}} 1. Basic concept 1.1. The defendant can establish that the plaintiff’s injuries are at least partially the result of the plaintiff’s own negligence. 1.2. The fact-finder {{c2::apportions fault between the plaintiff and defendant by percentage}} and {{c3::reduces the plaintiff’s recoverable damages accordingly}}. 2. Types of comparative negligence 2.1. {{c4::Partial (modified) comparative negligence}} 2.1.1. The plaintiff can recover damages only if he was {{c5::less than 50% at fault (or 50% or less in some states)}}. 2.1.2. If the plaintiff’s fault exceeds the jurisdiction’s cutoff, the claim is {{c6::barred (inactionable)}}. 2.2. {{c7::Pure comparative negligence}} 2.2.1. The plaintiff can recover damages even if he was {{c8::more than 50% at fault}}. 2.2.2. Recovery is reduced by the plaintiff’s {{c9::percentage of fault}}.
cards.easyContent: Comparative negligence reduces a plaintiff’s damages by their share of fault. In modified systems, recovery is cut off once the plaintiff’s fault reaches a threshold (often 50%), while in pure systems the plaintiff can recover even if mostly at fault, with damages reduced by their percentage of fault.
cards.mediumContent: Under comparative negligence, the defendant can argue that the plaintiff’s own negligence contributed to the injury. The fact-finder assigns fault percentages to each party and reduces the plaintiff’s damages by his share. In partial (modified) comparative negligence jurisdictions, the plaintiff can recover only if his fault is below a jurisdictional cutoff (commonly less than, or at most equal to, 50%); if his share exceeds that level, he recovers nothing. In pure comparative negligence jurisdictions, the plaintiff may recover regardless of his percentage of fault, but his damages are reduced in proportion to his negligence.
cards.hardContent: Comparative negligence replaces the all-or-nothing bar of contributory negligence by allowing the trier of fact to compare the plaintiff’s negligence with the defendant’s negligence. If the defendant shows that the plaintiff’s negligence contributed to his injuries, the fact-finder assigns a percentage of fault to each party and reduces the plaintiff’s recoverable damages in accordance with his share of responsibility. In partial (modified) comparative negligence jurisdictions, the plaintiff may recover only so long as his percentage of fault does not exceed a statutory threshold (often stated as less than 50%, or 50% or less). If the plaintiff’s share of fault exceeds the jurisdiction’s cutoff, his claim is barred. In pure comparative negligence jurisdictions, by contrast, the plaintiff may recover even when more than 50% at fault; his damages are simply reduced by his percentage of negligence.
cards.mnemonic: COMPARE: Modified = Cutoff; Pure = Pay, just reduced.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card for comparative negligence (pure vs modified).
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::comparative negligence}}, the plaintiff’s damages are {{c2::reduced by his percentage of fault}}; {{c3::modified}} systems bar recovery past a {{c4::fault threshold}}, while {{c5::pure}} systems {{c6::always allow reduced recovery}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Contributory Negligence and Last Clear Chance
cards.rawHeader: Torts 031-2. Contributory Negligence and Last Clear Chance
cards.front: Contributory Negligence and Last Clear Chance
cards.frontPrompt: What is contributory negligence and how does the last clear chance doctrine affect the contributory negligence defense?
cards.backPlain: Contributory negligence and last clear chance 1. Contributory negligence 1.1. In contributory negligence jurisdictions, the plaintiff is barred from recovery if the defendant establishes that the plaintiff’s negligence contributed to her injuries. 2. Last clear chance doctrine 2.1. The plaintiff can rebut the defendant’s contributory negligence defense by proving the defendant had the last clear chance to avoid the injury-causing accident. 2.2. If the defendant had such a last clear chance and failed to act reasonably to avoid the harm, the plaintiff may still recover despite her own contributory negligence.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Contributory negligence}} 1. In contributory negligence jurisdictions, the plaintiff is {{c2::barred from recovery}} if the defendant establishes that the plaintiff’s negligence {{c3::contributed to her injuries}}. 2. {{c4::Last clear chance doctrine}} 2.1. The plaintiff can rebut the defendant’s contributory negligence defense by proving the defendant had the {{c5::last clear chance to avoid the injury-causing accident}}. 2.2. If the defendant had this final clear opportunity and failed to act reasonably, the plaintiff may {{c6::still recover despite her contributory negligence}}.
cards.easyContent: In contributory negligence jurisdictions, any negligence by the plaintiff that contributes to the injury can bar recovery. The last clear chance doctrine allows the plaintiff to recover anyway if the defendant had the final clear opportunity to avoid the accident and failed to do so.
cards.mediumContent: Contributory negligence is a minority rule under which a plaintiff whose own negligence contributed to her injury is completely barred from recovery if the defendant proves that negligence. The last clear chance doctrine softens this harsh result by allowing the plaintiff to recover if, after the plaintiff was in peril, the defendant had the last clear chance to avoid the injury-causing accident but failed to exercise reasonable care.
cards.hardContent: Under contributory negligence, if the defendant shows that the plaintiff’s own negligence played any causal role in producing her injuries, the plaintiff is barred from recovery in jurisdictions that still follow this rule. To mitigate its severity, the last clear chance doctrine provides that, even if the plaintiff was negligent, she may nonetheless recover if she proves that the defendant, after becoming aware (or when he should have become aware) of the plaintiff’s peril, had the last clear chance or final clear opportunity to avoid the accident by exercising reasonable care, but failed to do so. In such circumstances, the defendant’s failure to use the last clear chance can override the contributory negligence bar and allow the plaintiff to recover.
cards.mnemonic: Contributory Completely Cuts; Last Clear Chance Lets recover.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card for contributory negligence and last clear chance.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::contributory negligence}}, any plaintiff fault {{c2::completely bars recovery}}. {{c3::Last clear chance}} lets P recover if D {{c4::had and failed to use a final clear opportunity}} to avoid harm.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Assumption of Risk – Implied and Express; Intentional Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 031-3. Assumption of Risk – Implied and Express; Intentional Torts
cards.front: Assumption of Risk – Implied and Express; Intentional Torts
cards.frontPrompt: What is assumption of risk, what must a defendant show to establish it, how does express assumption of risk operate, and how does this doctrine relate to intentional torts?
cards.backPlain: Assumption of risk and express assumption of risk 1. Assumption of risk (generally) 1.1. The defendant can deny the plaintiff’s recovery by establishing that the plaintiff assumed the risk of damage caused by the defendant’s act. 2. Requirements (defendant’s burden) 2.1. The plaintiff knew of the risk (subjective standard; knowledge can be inferred from the facts); and 2.2. The plaintiff voluntarily proceeded in the face of that risk. 3. Express assumption of risk 3.1. A plaintiff can expressly assume the risk by agreement (e.g., an exculpatory clause). 3.2. Such clauses are less likely to be enforced if they are part of an adhesion contract or otherwise unconscionable or against public policy. 4. Relationship to intentional torts 4.1. None of these negligence defenses (comparative fault, contributory negligence, or assumption of risk) applies as a defense to intentional torts. 4.2. However, a plaintiff can consent to intentional torts, which may provide a separate defense for the defendant.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Assumption of risk}} 1. The defendant can deny the plaintiff’s recovery by establishing that the plaintiff assumed the risk of damage caused by the defendant’s act. 2. Requirements (defendant’s burden) 2.1. The plaintiff {{c2::knew of the risk}} ({{c3::subjective standard; knowledge can be inferred from the facts}}); and 2.2. The plaintiff {{c4::voluntarily proceeded in the face of that risk}}. 3. {{c5::Express assumption of risk}} 3.1. A plaintiff can expressly assume the risk by {{c6::agreement}} (e.g., an {{c7::exculpatory clause}}). 3.2. Such clauses are less likely to be enforced if they are part of an {{c8::adhesion contract}} or otherwise against public policy. 4. Relationship to intentional torts 4.1. {{c9::None of these negligence defenses (comparative negligence, contributory negligence, or assumption of risk) applies to intentional torts}}. 4.2. However, a plaintiff can {{c10::consent to intentional torts}}, which may provide a separate defense.
cards.easyContent: Assumption of risk applies when the defendant shows the plaintiff knew of a risk and voluntarily faced it, which can bar or limit recovery. Express assumption of risk arises from agreements like exculpatory clauses, which courts scrutinize, especially in adhesion contracts. These negligence defenses don’t apply to intentional torts, though a plaintiff can consent to intentional tortious conduct.
cards.mediumContent: To establish assumption of risk, the defendant must show that the plaintiff subjectively knew of a particular risk (knowledge may be inferred from circumstances) and voluntarily proceeded in the face of that risk. This may be implied from the plaintiff’s conduct or be express, as where the plaintiff signs an agreement (such as an exculpatory clause) purporting to waive claims; such provisions are less likely to be enforced when they are part of adhesion contracts or violate public policy. Comparative negligence, contributory negligence, and assumption of risk are generally not defenses to intentional torts, but a plaintiff’s consent can nonetheless serve as a defense to intentional tort liability.
cards.hardContent: Assumption of risk is a negligence defense that permits the defendant to deny or limit the plaintiff’s recovery by proving that the plaintiff voluntarily encountered a known danger. The defendant must satisfy a subjective standard: the plaintiff actually knew of the specific risk at issue, although such knowledge may be inferred from the facts, and the plaintiff chose to proceed in the face of that risk. Assumption of risk may be implied from the plaintiff’s conduct or be express. Express assumption of risk typically arises through an agreement, such as an exculpatory clause in a waiver; courts are reluctant to enforce such provisions when they are contained in adhesion contracts, are unconscionable, or contravene public policy. Additionally, the negligence defenses of comparative negligence, contributory negligence, and assumption of risk do not operate as defenses to intentional torts. Nonetheless, a plaintiff can consent to intentional tortious conduct (for example, in contact sports or medical procedures), and such consent may supply a distinct defense to intentional tort liability.
cards.mnemonic: Know + Go, but not for blows (intentional torts).
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card for assumption of risk (implied and express) and its relationship to intentional torts.
cards.clozeLite: Assumption of risk requires {{c1::subjective knowledge of a specific risk}} and {{c2::voluntary encounter with that risk}}; it {{c3::does not defend intentional torts, where consent applies instead}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Negligent Infliction of Emotional Distress – Zone-of-Danger NIED
cards.rawHeader: Torts 032-1. Negligent Infliction of Emotional Distress – Zone-of-Danger NIED
cards.backPlain: Zone-of-danger negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED): 1. In general 1.1. A plaintiff may recover for emotional distress resulting from the defendant’s negligence. 1.2. In zone-of-danger cases, the plaintiff is herself put at immediate risk of bodily harm. 2. Elements of zone-of-danger NIED 2.1. The defendant’s negligence results in a close risk of bodily harm to the plaintiff (plaintiff is within the zone of danger of physical impact). 2.2. The defendant’s act must have nearly caused physical harm to the plaintiff. 2.3. The plaintiff suffers severe emotional distress. 2.4. Physical manifestation requirement: 2.4.1. Traditionally, the plaintiff had to exhibit some physical manifestation attributable to the emotional distress. 2.4.2. Symptoms can be instantaneous or appear days later. 2.4.3. Jurisdictional split: many modern jurisdictions allow recovery for severe emotional distress alone without physical symptoms. 3. Exam notes 3.1. On essays, identify that the plaintiff was nearly physically harmed (inside the zone of danger) and then analyze severe distress and any physical symptoms. 3.2. Given the jurisdictional split, an MBE question is unlikely to turn solely on the need for physical symptoms.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of zone-of-danger negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED), and how do jurisdictions treat the physical manifestation requirement?
cards.cloze: In {{c1::zone-of-danger}} negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED): 1. The defendant’s {{c2::negligence}} must place the plaintiff in a {{c3::close risk of bodily harm}} (within the {{c4::zone of danger}} of physical impact), such that the act nearly causes physical harm. 2. The plaintiff must suffer {{c5::severe emotional distress}}. 3. Traditionally, the plaintiff had to show a {{c6::physical manifestation}} of that distress, which could appear immediately or days later. 4. There is a {{c7::jurisdictional split}}: many modern jurisdictions now allow recovery for {{c8::severe emotional distress alone without physical symptoms}}.
cards.easyContent: In zone-of-danger NIED, the defendant’s negligence nearly physically injures the plaintiff, putting the plaintiff in immediate risk of bodily harm. The plaintiff must suffer severe emotional distress, and many jurisdictions also require physical symptoms of that distress, though some now allow recovery for severe distress alone.
cards.mediumContent: Zone-of-danger NIED applies when the defendant’s negligence puts the plaintiff herself in immediate risk of physical harm. The defendant’s conduct must place the plaintiff within the zone of danger—i.e., the act nearly causes bodily impact. The plaintiff must suffer severe emotional distress. Traditionally, courts required some physical manifestation of that distress, which could appear immediately or later. Many modern jurisdictions, however, permit recovery for severe emotional distress without physical symptoms, creating a jurisdictional split.
cards.hardContent: Zone-of-danger negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED) allows recovery when the defendant’s negligence puts the plaintiff personally at immediate risk of bodily harm. The defendant’s conduct must create a close risk of physical impact, so that the act nearly causes physical harm to the plaintiff. The plaintiff must experience severe emotional distress as a result. Historically, most jurisdictions also required a physical manifestation of that distress—such as physical symptoms developing immediately or some time after the incident. Today, there is a recognized split: many jurisdictions still demand physical manifestation, while others permit recovery based on severe emotional distress alone, without physical symptoms. On exams, emphasize that the plaintiff was inside the zone of danger and then discuss the physical-symptom requirement as a jurisdictional variation.
cards.mnemonic: Zone NIED: "Near Hit, Neuro Hit, Maybe Physical"
cards.atomizationNotes: Zone-of-danger variant of NIED with emphasis on physical manifestation split.
cards.clozeLite: Zone-of-danger NIED applies when {{c1::defendant’s negligence puts plaintiff in immediate risk of physical harm}} and {{c2::plaintiff suffers severe emotional distress}}; {{c3::many jurisdictions require physical manifestation, others don’t}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Negligent Infliction of Emotional Distress – Bystander NIED
cards.rawHeader: Torts 032-2. Negligent Infliction of Emotional Distress – Bystander NIED
cards.backPlain: Bystander negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED): 1. In general 1.1. Bystander NIED applies when the plaintiff is outside the zone of danger but suffers emotional distress from negligently inflicted injury to another person. 2. Elements of bystander NIED 2.1. Plaintiffs outside the zone of danger may recover for emotional distress resulting from the defendant’s negligence if: 2.1.1. The plaintiff and the injured person are closely related. 2.1.2. The plaintiff was present at the scene of the injury. 2.1.3. The plaintiff personally observed or perceived the event. 3. Exam notes 3.1. Emphasize that the plaintiff is not herself in immediate physical danger (outside the zone of danger), but meets the relationship, presence, and perception requirements. 3.2. Pay attention to how closely related the plaintiff is to the victim and whether the facts support actual contemporaneous perception of the injury.
cards.frontPrompt: When can a plaintiff outside the zone of danger recover for negligent infliction of emotional distress (bystander NIED), and what are the required elements?
cards.cloze: In {{c1::bystander}} negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED), a plaintiff {{c2::outside the zone of danger}} may recover for emotional distress from injury to another if: 1. The plaintiff and the injured person are {{c3::closely related}}. 2. The plaintiff is {{c4::present at the scene}} of the injury. 3. The plaintiff {{c5::personally observes or perceives}} the event as it happens.
cards.easyContent: Bystander NIED lets someone outside the zone of danger recover for emotional distress when a loved one is negligently injured, but only if they are closely related, at the scene, and personally see or perceive the event.
cards.mediumContent: Bystander negligent infliction of emotional distress applies when the plaintiff is not personally endangered but suffers emotional harm from seeing a loved one injured by the defendant’s negligence. A typical modern test requires that: (1) the plaintiff and the victim are closely related, (2) the plaintiff is present at the scene of the injury, and (3) the plaintiff personally observes or perceives the event. If these elements are met, the plaintiff may recover for emotional distress even though she was outside the zone of danger.
cards.hardContent: Bystander NIED addresses emotional harm suffered by a plaintiff who witnesses negligent injury to another person while not personally in the zone of danger. Most courts allow such a plaintiff to recover only if certain limiting elements are satisfied to prevent indeterminate liability. Commonly, the plaintiff must be closely related to the injured victim (such as a spouse, parent, or child), must be present at the scene of the injury when it occurs, and must personally observe or contemporaneously perceive the event rather than learning of it later. If these conditions are met, the plaintiff may recover for the resulting emotional distress even though she was not herself at immediate risk of bodily harm.
cards.mnemonic: CP3: Closely related, Present, Personally Perceives.
cards.atomizationNotes: Bystander variant of NIED; plaintiff is outside zone of danger but meets CP3 elements.
cards.clozeLite: Bystander NIED lets a {{c1::plaintiff outside the zone of danger}} recover if {{c2::closely related}}, {{c3::present at the scene}}, and {{c4::personally observes or perceives}} the injury.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Negligent Infliction of Emotional Distress – Special Situations
cards.rawHeader: Torts 032-3. Negligent Infliction of Emotional Distress – Special Situations
cards.front: NIED – Special Situations (Corpse, Erroneous Death Report)
cards.backPlain: Special-situation negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED): 1. General rule 1.1. Even if zone-of-danger or bystander elements are not met, a plaintiff may still recover for NIED where the defendant’s negligence creates a great likelihood of serious emotional distress. 2. Common special situations 2.1. Erroneous report of a relative’s death. 2.2. Mishandling of a corpse (e.g., losing, damaging, or desecrating a loved one’s body). 3. Rationale and exam use 3.1. These situations are treated as inherently likely to cause severe emotional distress. 3.2. Courts are more willing to allow NIED recovery without requiring the plaintiff to be in the zone of danger or to satisfy strict bystander elements. 3.3. On exams, recognize these facts as classic exceptions that support NIED even when traditional elements might otherwise be lacking.
cards.frontPrompt: What special situations allow recovery for negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED) even when zone-of-danger or bystander elements are not satisfied?
