cards.cloze: Certain {{c1::special situations}} support negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED) even without zone-of-danger or bystander elements, because the negligence creates a {{c2::great likelihood of serious emotional distress}}. Classic examples include: 1. {{c3::Erroneous report of a relative’s death}}. 2. {{c4::Mishandling of a corpse}} (e.g., losing, damaging, or desecrating a loved one’s body).
cards.easyContent: Even if normal NIED rules aren’t met, courts often allow recovery when negligence is inherently likely to cause serious emotional distress—most famously when a corpse is mishandled or when someone is wrongly told that a close relative has died.
cards.mediumContent: Apart from zone-of-danger and bystander theories, courts recognize special NIED situations where negligence predictably causes severe emotional harm. Two classic examples are (1) erroneous reports of a relative’s death and (2) mishandling of a corpse. In these cases, courts typically allow recovery for emotional distress even if the plaintiff was not in the zone of danger and did not meet strict bystander requirements, because the risk of serious emotional harm is so clear.
cards.hardContent: Some negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED) claims succeed even when neither the zone-of-danger nor bystander frameworks are technically satisfied. Courts have carved out special categories where negligent conduct is inherently and foreseeably likely to cause grave emotional suffering. The most frequently tested examples are: (1) erroneous communication that a close relative has died, and (2) mishandling of a corpse, such as losing, mutilating, or otherwise desecrating the body of a loved one. Because these scenarios so obviously implicate a high likelihood of serious emotional distress, many courts permit recovery without demanding that the plaintiff show personal physical endangerment or the full set of bystander elements.
cards.mnemonic: Special NIED is "Dead Wrong": Dead body, Wrong death report.
cards.atomizationNotes: Special NIED exceptions where courts allow recovery due to inherently high risk of emotional distress.
cards.clozeLite: Special NIED: courts allow recovery for {{c1::erroneous reports of a relative’s death}} and {{c2::mishandling of a corpse}} even without {{c3::zone-of-danger or bystander}} elements.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.front: Strict Products Liability – Commercial Supplier Requirement
cards.backPlain: Element 1: D is a commercial supplier. 1. Commercial supplier status: 1.1 A commercial supplier has a strict duty to supply safe goods. 1.2 A commercial supplier is one who routinely deals in the product sold and is in the stream of commerce. 1.3 Examples of commercial suppliers: 1.3.1 Manufacturer. 1.3.2 Distributor. 1.3.3 Supplier or retailer. 1.4 Non-commercial actors (no strict products liability): 1.4.1 Casual or occasional sellers. 1.4.2 Service providers (whose primary role is providing a service, not selling products).
cards.frontPrompt: In strict products liability, who qualifies as a commercial supplier, and who is excluded from strict liability?
cards.cloze: Element 1: D is a {{c1::commercial supplier}}. 1. Commercial supplier status: 1.1 A commercial supplier has a strict duty to supply {{c2::safe goods}}. 1.2 A commercial supplier is one who {{c3::routinely deals in the product sold}} and is in the {{c4::stream of commerce}}. 1.3 Examples of commercial suppliers: 1.3.1 {{c5::Manufacturer}}. 1.3.2 {{c6::Distributor}}. 1.3.3 {{c7::Supplier or retailer}}. 1.4 Non-commercial actors (no strict products liability): 1.4.1 {{c8::Casual or occasional sellers}}. 1.4.2 {{c9::Service providers}} (primary role is service, not product sale).
cards.easyContent: Strict products liability applies only to commercial suppliers—those in the business of selling the product in the stream of commerce (like manufacturers and distributors), not to casual sellers or pure service providers.
cards.mediumContent: The first element of strict products liability is that D is a commercial supplier: someone who routinely deals in the product and is in the stream of commerce (e.g., manufacturer, distributor, supplier or retailer). Casual or occasional sellers and service providers are not commercial suppliers and are not strictly liable.
cards.hardContent: To satisfy the commercial supplier requirement, D must be in the business of selling or distributing the type of product that injured P and be part of the stream of commerce—such as a manufacturer, distributor, or retailer. These actors have a strict duty to supply safe goods. In contrast, casual sellers (e.g., a one-time garage sale) and service providers whose primary role is providing services rather than selling products do not face strict products liability, even if they incidentally supply products.
cards.mnemonic: MDS: Manufacturer, Distributor, Supplier—not casual sellers or services.
cards.clozeLite: Strict products liability requires {{c1::a commercial supplier}}—in the {{c2::stream of commerce}}—not {{c3::casual sellers}} or {{c4::service providers}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Strict Products Liability – Defective and Unreasonably Dangerous Product
cards.front: Strict Products Liability – Defective, Unreasonably Dangerous Product
cards.backPlain: Element 2: Product is defective and unreasonably dangerous. 1. Defective product: 1.1 The product must contain a defect. 1.2 The defect may be in manufacture, design, or warnings (details covered in separate cards). 2. Unreasonably dangerous: 2.1 The defect must make the product unreasonably dangerous to the user or consumer. 2.2 "Unreasonably dangerous" means the product poses a danger beyond what an ordinary consumer would expect or that outweighs its utility (depending on the applicable test).
cards.frontPrompt: For strict products liability, what is required regarding the product’s condition?
cards.cloze: Element 2: Product is {{c1::defective}} and {{c2::unreasonably dangerous}}. 1. Defective product: 1.1 The product must contain a {{c3::defect}}. 1.2 The defect may be in {{c4::manufacture}}, {{c5::design}}, or {{c6::warnings}} (details covered elsewhere). 2. Unreasonably dangerous: 2.1 The defect must make the product {{c7::unreasonably dangerous}} to the user or consumer. 2.2 "Unreasonably dangerous" means the product poses a danger beyond what an {{c8::ordinary consumer would expect}} or that {{c9::outweighs its utility}} (depending on the test).
cards.easyContent: Strict products liability requires that the product have a defect that makes it unreasonably dangerous to users or consumers.
cards.mediumContent: The second element of strict products liability is that the product is defective in a way that makes it unreasonably dangerous. The defect can be in manufacture, design, or failure to warn, and it must create a danger beyond ordinary consumer expectations or one that outweighs the product’s utility.
cards.hardContent: For strict products liability, P must show that the product was defective and that this defect rendered the product unreasonably dangerous. The defect may arise from a manufacturing error, a defective design, or inadequate warnings or instructions. Regardless of type, the defect must expose users or consumers to unreasonable danger—either because the product is more dangerous than an ordinary consumer would anticipate or because, under a risk-utility analysis, the product’s risks outweigh its benefits.
cards.mnemonic: DU: Defective and Unreasonably dangerous product.
cards.clozeLite: Strict products liability requires a {{c1::defect}} that makes the product {{c2::unreasonably dangerous}} to {{c3::users or consumers}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Strict Products Liability – Causation and No Substantial Alteration
cards.front: Strict Products Liability – Causation and No Substantial Alteration
cards.backPlain: Element 3: Causation and no substantial alteration. 1. Causation: 1.1 The defective product must be the actual cause of P’s injury. 1.1.1 But-for the defect, P would not have been injured. 1.2 The defective product must also be the proximate cause of P’s injury. 1.2.1 The type of harm must be a foreseeable result of the defect. 2. No substantial alteration: 2.1 The product must not be substantially altered between the time it leaves the commercial supplier and the time it reaches the consumer. 2.2 A substantial alteration that introduces or changes the defect can break the causal chain and defeat strict liability.
cards.frontPrompt: In strict products liability, what must be shown about causation and any alteration of the product?
cards.cloze: Element 3: {{c1::Causation}} and no {{c2::substantial alteration}}. 1. Causation: 1.1 The defective product must be the {{c3::actual cause}} of P’s injury (but-for the defect, no injury). 1.2 The defective product must also be the {{c4::proximate cause}} of P’s injury (the type of harm is a {{c5::foreseeable result}} of the defect). 2. No substantial alteration: 2.1 The product must not be {{c6::substantially altered}} between leaving the commercial supplier and reaching the consumer. 2.2 A {{c7::substantial alteration}} that introduces or changes the defect can {{c8::break the causal chain}} and defeat strict liability.
cards.easyContent: Strict products liability requires that the product’s defect actually and proximately cause P’s injury, and that the product was not substantially altered after it left the commercial supplier.
cards.mediumContent: For strict products liability, P must prove causation: the defect is both the actual and proximate cause of the injury. Additionally, the product must reach the consumer without substantial alteration; a major change that introduces or modifies the defect can cut off the supplier’s strict liability.
cards.hardContent: Causation in strict products liability has two components. First, actual cause: but-for the product’s defect, P’s injury would not have occurred. Second, proximate cause: the injury must be a foreseeable consequence of the defect, not an extraordinary, superseding event. Moreover, strict liability generally applies only if the product is not substantially altered between the time it leaves the commercial supplier and the time it reaches the consumer. A substantial alteration that introduces or significantly modifies the defect may break the causal chain and relieve the supplier of strict liability.
cards.mnemonic: CAN: Causation And No substantial alteration.
cards.clozeLite: Strict products liability requires {{c1::actual and proximate causation}} and that the product {{c2::reaches the consumer without substantial alteration}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Strict Products Liability – Foreseeable Use and Misuse
cards.front: Strict Products Liability – Foreseeable Use and Misuse
cards.backPlain: Element 4: Foreseeable use (including foreseeable misuse). 1. Foreseeable use: 1.1 P must use the product in a foreseeable manner. 1.2 Foreseeable use includes normal and reasonably anticipated ways of using the product. 2. Foreseeable misuse: 2.1 P’s misuse of the product can still satisfy this element if the misuse is foreseeable. 2.2 If the misuse is unforeseeable or highly abnormal, it may break causation or serve as a defense to strict liability.
cards.frontPrompt: How does foreseeable use (and misuse) factor into strict products liability?
cards.cloze: Element 4: {{c1::Foreseeable use}} (including foreseeable misuse). 1. Foreseeable use: 1.1 P must use the product in a {{c2::foreseeable}} manner. 1.2 Foreseeable use includes {{c3::normal}} and {{c4::reasonably anticipated}} ways of using the product. 2. Foreseeable misuse: 2.1 P’s {{c5::misuse}} of the product can still satisfy this element if the misuse is {{c6::foreseeable}}. 2.2 If the misuse is {{c7::unforeseeable or highly abnormal}}, it may {{c8::break causation}} or serve as a {{c9::defense}} to strict liability.
cards.easyContent: Strict products liability requires that P’s use of the product be foreseeable. Foreseeable misuse still counts; only unforeseeable, highly abnormal misuse may defeat liability.
cards.mediumContent: The fourth element of strict products liability is that P used the product in a foreseeable way. This includes ordinary uses and uses that the seller should reasonably anticipate. Even if P misuses the product, strict liability may still apply if the misuse was foreseeable; only unforeseeable or highly abnormal misuse is likely to break causation or provide a defense.
cards.hardContent: Foreseeable use is required for strict products liability. P must be using the product in a manner that is either its intended use or a use that is reasonably foreseeable to a commercial supplier. Importantly, P’s misuse of the product does not automatically bar recovery. If the misuse is one that a supplier should reasonably anticipate (e.g., standing on a chair), it is treated as foreseeable use. By contrast, highly abnormal or unforeseeable misuse (e.g., using a toaster as a bathtub heater) may break the chain of causation or serve as a defense to strict liability.
cards.mnemonic: Use must be "FAM": Foreseeable, including Anticipated Misuse.
cards.clozeLite: Strict products liability requires {{c1::foreseeable use}}; even {{c2::foreseeable misuse}} counts, but {{c3::unforeseeable, highly abnormal misuse}} can defeat liability.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Strict Products Liability – Who Can Sue and Recoverable Damages
cards.front: Strict Products Liability – Plaintiffs and Damages
cards.backPlain: Elements 5 & 6: Who can sue and what damages are recoverable. 1. Who can sue: 1.1 Any foreseeable user or bystander. 1.2 Examples of foreseeable plaintiffs: 1.2.1 Buyers. 1.2.2 Their guests. 1.2.3 Employees. 1.2.4 Family members. 2. Recoverable damages: 2.1 P can recover for: 2.1.1 Physical injury (personal injury). 2.1.2 Property damage. 2.2 P cannot recover in strict products liability for solely economic losses (pure economic loss must be pursued under contract/warranty or other theories).
cards.frontPrompt: In strict products liability, who can sue, and what types of damages are recoverable?
cards.cloze: Elements 5 & 6: {{c1::Who can sue}} and {{c2::recoverable damages}}. 1. Who can sue: 1.1 Any {{c3::foreseeable user or bystander}}. 1.2 Examples of foreseeable plaintiffs: 1.2.1 {{c4::Buyers}}. 1.2.2 Their {{c5::guests}}. 1.2.3 {{c6::Employees}}. 1.2.4 {{c7::Family members}}. 2. Recoverable damages: 2.1 P can recover for: 2.1.1 {{c8::Physical injury}} (personal injury). 2.1.2 {{c9::Property damage}}. 2.2 P cannot recover for solely {{c10::economic losses}} in strict products liability.
cards.easyContent: Any foreseeable user or bystander (like buyers, their guests, employees, or family) can bring a strict products liability claim for physical injury or property damage, but not for purely economic loss.
cards.mediumContent: Strict products liability extends to all foreseeable users and bystanders, including buyers and those close to them such as guests, employees, and family members. These plaintiffs can recover for physical injury and property damage caused by the defective product, but purely economic losses must be pursued under other theories like warranty or contract.
cards.hardContent: The class of potential plaintiffs in strict products liability includes any foreseeable user or bystander. This covers not only the direct purchaser but also foreseeable third parties such as guests, employees, and family members who might be exposed to the product. As to damages, strict products liability allows recovery for physical injuries and property damage proximately caused by the defect. However, purely economic losses (e.g., lost profits, the cost to replace a defective product that has not caused injury or property damage) are not recoverable under strict products liability and must instead be addressed via contract or warranty doctrines.
cards.mnemonic: FIPP: Foreseeable users; Injury & Property, not Purely economic.
cards.clozeLite: Strict products liability lets {{c1::foreseeable users and bystanders}} recover {{c2::physical injury}} and {{c3::property damage}}, but not {{c4::purely economic loss}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Product Defects – Manufacturing Defect & Consumer-Expectation Test
cards.rawHeader: Torts 037-1. Product Defects – Manufacturing Defect & Consumer-Expectation Test
cards.backPlain: Manufacturing defect: 1. Definition: 1.1 A manufacturing defect exists when a particular product {{unit}} departs from its intended design, causing it to be more dangerous than all of the manufacturer's other products of the same kind. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – consumer-expectation test: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that the product failed to perform as safely as an ordinary consumer would expect when used in an intended or reasonably foreseeable way.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a manufacturing defect in products liability, and what must a plaintiff show under the consumer-expectation test?
cards.cloze: Manufacturing defect: 1. Definition: 1.1 A {{c1::manufacturing defect}} exists when a particular product {{c2::departs from its intended design}}, causing it to be {{c3::more dangerous than all of the manufacturer's other products of the same kind}}. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – {{c4::consumer-expectation test}}: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that the product {{c5::failed to perform as safely as an ordinary consumer would expect}} when used in an intended or reasonably foreseeable way.
cards.easyContent: A manufacturing defect exists when an individual product comes out different from and more dangerous than the intended design. The plaintiff shows this by proving the product failed to perform as safely as an ordinary consumer would expect.
cards.mediumContent: A manufacturing defect occurs when a particular unit departs from the manufacturer’s intended design, making it more dangerous than other units of the same product. The plaintiff must prove that the product failed to perform as safely as an ordinary consumer would expect in its intended or foreseeable use (the consumer-expectation test).
cards.hardContent: A manufacturing defect is present when a specific product unit departs from its intended design so that it is more dangerous than the manufacturer's other products of the same kind. To establish liability, the plaintiff invokes the consumer-expectation test and must show that, in its intended or reasonably foreseeable use, the product failed to perform as safely as an ordinary consumer would expect.
cards.mnemonic: "M" in MAD: Manufacturing = Mistake in one unit; judged by consumer expectations.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::manufacturing defect}} occurs when a unit {{c2::departs from the intended design}} and is more dangerous, and the plaintiff must show it {{c3::failed to perform as safely as an ordinary consumer would expect}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Product Defects – Design Defect & Feasible Alternative Design
cards.rawHeader: Torts 037-2. Product Defects – Design Defect & Feasible Alternative Design
cards.front: Design Defect – Definition & Feasible Alternative Design
cards.backPlain: Design defect: 1. Definition: 1.1 A design defect exists when the product's design itself creates an unreasonable risk of danger to users or bystanders. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – feasible alternative design: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that there was a technologically and economically feasible alternative design or modification; and 2.2 The alternative design would be safer as to the risk at issue (i.e., would have reduced or avoided the harm without unduly impairing the product's utility or making it prohibitively expensive).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a design defect in products liability, and what must a plaintiff show regarding a feasible alternative design?
cards.cloze: Design defect: 1. Definition: 1.1 A {{c1::design defect}} exists when the product's {{c2::design itself}} creates an {{c3::unreasonable risk of danger}} to users or bystanders. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – {{c4::feasible alternative design}}: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that there was a {{c5::technologically and economically feasible alternative design or modification}}; and 2.2 The alternative design would be {{c6::safer as to the risk at issue}} (i.e., would have reduced or avoided the harm without unduly impairing the product's utility or making it prohibitively expensive).
cards.easyContent: A design defect exists when the product's design itself is unreasonably dangerous. The plaintiff must show a technologically and economically feasible alternative design that would be safer with respect to the risk at issue.
cards.mediumContent: A design defect arises when the product's overall design creates an unreasonable risk of danger. To recover, the plaintiff must prove that a technologically and economically feasible alternative design or modification existed that would have made the product safer as to the risk at issue without unduly reducing its utility or making it prohibitively costly.
cards.hardContent: A design defect occurs when the product's intended design is itself unreasonably dangerous to users or bystanders. The plaintiff must establish that a technologically and economically feasible alternative design or modification was available that would have reduced or avoided the specific risk at issue while preserving the product's utility and keeping costs within a reasonable range. This feasible alternative design requirement is central to modern design-defect analysis.
cards.mnemonic: "A" in MAD: Alternative design controls design defects.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::design defect}} exists when the design is {{c2::unreasonably dangerous}} and a {{c3::technologically and economically feasible alternative design}} would {{c4::reduce the risk without undue cost or loss of utility}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Product Defects – Inadequate Warning & Unavoidably Unsafe Products
cards.rawHeader: Torts 037-3. Product Defects – Inadequate Warning & Unavoidably Unsafe Products
cards.front: Inadequate Warning – Requirements & Unavoidably Unsafe Products
cards.backPlain: Inadequate warning (warning/instruction defect): 1. Basic duty to warn: 1.1 A manufacturer must adequately warn of non-obvious risks associated with a product's use. 1.2 The duty includes warning of foreseeable dangers from misuse of the product. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – adequacy of warnings: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that the product failed to have clear and complete warnings of any dangers that would not have been ordinarily apparent to consumers. 3. Unavoidably unsafe products: 3.1 Some products cannot be made safe for their ordinary use (e.g., chain saws, firearms). 3.2 For such unavoidably unsafe products, the manufacturer must give: 3.2.1 Proper instructions for use; and 3.2.2 Adequate warnings of known dangers. 4. Foreseeability limit on duty to warn: 4.1 The manufacturer is not liable for risks that were unforeseeable at the time the product was marketed.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a product defective for inadequate warning, what must a plaintiff show, and what special rules apply to unavoidably unsafe products and unforeseeable risks?
cards.cloze: Inadequate warning (warning/instruction defect): 1. Basic duty to warn: 1.1 A manufacturer must adequately warn of {{c1::non-obvious risks}} associated with a product's use. 1.2 The duty includes warning of {{c2::foreseeable dangers from misuse}} of the product. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – adequacy of warnings: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that the product failed to have {{c3::clear and complete warnings}} of any dangers that would not have been {{c4::ordinarily apparent to consumers}}. 3. Unavoidably unsafe products: 3.1 Some products cannot be made safe for their ordinary use (e.g., chain saws, firearms). 3.2 For such {{c5::unavoidably unsafe products}}, the manufacturer must give: 3.2.1 {{c6::Proper instructions for use}}; and 3.2.2 {{c7::Adequate warnings of known dangers}}. 4. Foreseeability limit on duty to warn: 4.1 The manufacturer is not liable for risks that were {{c8::unforeseeable at the time the product was marketed}}.
cards.easyContent: An inadequate warning defect occurs when the manufacturer fails to clearly warn about non-obvious risks, including foreseeable misuse. For unavoidably unsafe products (like chain saws or firearms), the manufacturer must give proper instructions and adequate warnings of known dangers, but is not liable for risks that were unforeseeable when the product was marketed.
cards.mediumContent: A product is defective for inadequate warning when the manufacturer fails to adequately warn of non-obvious risks associated with the product's use, including foreseeable dangers from misuse. The plaintiff must show that the warnings were not clear and complete as to dangers not ordinarily apparent to consumers. For unavoidably unsafe products, such as chain saws or firearms, the manufacturer must provide proper instructions and adequate warnings of known dangers. The duty to warn is limited to risks that were foreseeable at the time the product was marketed.
cards.hardContent: An inadequate warning (or warning/instruction) defect arises when the manufacturer fails to adequately warn of non-obvious risks related to the product's intended or foreseeable use, including foreseeable dangers from misuse. The plaintiff must demonstrate that the product lacked clear and complete warnings about dangers that would not have been ordinarily apparent to consumers. For unavoidably unsafe products—those that cannot be made safe for their ordinary use, such as chain saws and firearms—the manufacturer discharges its duty by providing proper instructions for use and adequate warnings of known dangers. However, the manufacturer is not liable for risks that were not reasonably foreseeable at the time the product was marketed, placing a temporal foreseeability limit on the duty to warn.
cards.mnemonic: "WARN": Nonobvious, Foreseeable, Directions for Dangerous products.
cards.clozeLite: A product has a {{c1::warning defect}} when the maker fails to warn of {{c2::non-obvious risks}} including {{c3::foreseeable misuse}}; duty covers only {{c4::foreseeable risks when marketed}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: Implied warranty of merchantability in products liability: 1. General rule: In every sale of goods by a merchant who deals in goods of that kind, there is an implied warranty of merchantability. 2. Content of the warranty: 2.1 The seller warrants that the goods are of average acceptable quality (i.e., without significant defects). 2.2 The goods must be generally fit for their ordinary purpose. 3. Application: If the goods are not of average acceptable quality or not fit for their ordinary purpose, the implied warranty of merchantability is breached.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the implied warranty of merchantability in products liability, and what does it require about the quality and use of the goods?
cards.cloze: Implied warranty of {{c1::merchantability}} in products liability: 1. General rule: In every {{c2::sale of goods}} by a {{c3::merchant who deals in goods of that kind}}, there is an implied warranty of merchantability. 2. Content of the warranty: 2.1 The seller warrants that the goods are of {{c4::average acceptable quality}} (i.e., without significant defects). 2.2 The goods must be generally {{c5::fit for their ordinary purpose}}. 3. Breach: If the goods are not of average acceptable quality or not fit for their ordinary purpose, the implied warranty of merchantability is {{c6::breached}}.
cards.easyContent: The implied warranty of merchantability requires that goods sold by a merchant be of average acceptable quality and fit for their ordinary purpose; otherwise, the warranty is breached.
cards.mediumContent: Whenever a merchant sells goods of the kind, the law implies a warranty of merchantability. This means the goods must be of average acceptable quality, free of significant defects, and generally fit for their ordinary use; failure in these respects is a breach of the warranty.
cards.hardContent: In products liability, a merchant seller automatically gives an implied warranty of merchantability. This warranty guarantees that the goods are of average acceptable quality—meaning they are free from significant defects—and that they are reasonably fit for their ordinary, intended purpose. If the goods fall below this standard or cannot perform their usual function, the implied warranty of merchantability is breached, potentially giving rise to liability.
cards.mnemonic: "M" for Merchantability: Merchant sells Medium-quality goods for their usual use.
cards.clozeLite: An implied {{c1::warranty of merchantability}} arises when a {{c2::merchant}} sells goods, requiring {{c3::average acceptable quality}} and {{c4::fitness for ordinary use}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Implied Warranty of Fitness for a Particular Purpose
cards.rawHeader: Torts 039-2. Implied Warranty of Fitness for a Particular Purpose
cards.front: Implied Warranty of Fitness for a Particular Purpose
cards.backPlain: Implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose in products liability: 1. When it arises: 1.1 The seller knows or has reason to know the particular purpose for which the buyer is purchasing the goods, and 1.2 The buyer relies on the seller's skill or judgment to select suitable goods. 2. Content of the warranty: 2.1 When these conditions are met, the seller impliedly warrants that the goods are fit for that particular purpose. 3. Example: 3.1 A shoe store salesperson recommends specific shoes to a buyer after being told the buyer needs shoes for running on trails; the seller impliedly warrants that the shoes are fit for trail running. 4. Breach: 4.1 If the goods are not fit for the particular purpose for which they were purchased under these conditions, the implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose is breached.
cards.frontPrompt: When does an implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arise in products liability, and what does it guarantee?
cards.cloze: Implied warranty of {{c1::fitness for a particular purpose}} in products liability: 1. Arises when: 1.1 The {{c2::seller knows or has reason to know the buyer's particular purpose}} for purchasing the goods, and 1.2 The {{c3::buyer relies on the seller's skill or judgment}} to select suitable goods. 2. Content: The seller impliedly warrants that the goods are {{c4::fit for that particular purpose}}. 3. Example: A {{c5::shoe store salesperson}} selecting shoes for a buyer who needs them for {{c6::running on trails}}. 4. Breach: If the goods are not fit for the particular purpose in these circumstances, the implied warranty of fitness is {{c7::breached}}.
cards.easyContent: The implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when the seller knows the buyer’s special purpose and the buyer relies on the seller’s skill or judgment, and it guarantees the goods are fit for that specific purpose.
cards.mediumContent: In products liability, an implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises if the seller knows or has reason to know the specific purpose for which the buyer needs the goods and knows that the buyer is relying on the seller’s skill or judgment to choose suitable goods. In that situation, the seller impliedly warrants that the goods will be fit for that particular purpose; failure to meet that purpose is a breach.
cards.hardContent: The implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose is triggered when a seller is aware, or should be aware, of the buyer’s special, non-ordinary purpose for the goods and also understands that the buyer is relying on the seller’s expertise or recommendation in selecting them. Once these conditions are satisfied, the law implies a warranty that the goods are suitable for that specific purpose—for example, recommending trail-running shoes to someone who explains they will run on rough trails. If the goods then prove unfit for that purpose, the implied warranty of fitness is breached, supporting products liability recovery.
cards.mnemonic: "F" for Fitness: Fits buyer’s special purpose when seller Knows & buyer Relies (K+R).
cards.clozeLite: An implied warranty of {{c1::fitness for a particular purpose}} arises when the {{c2::seller knows the buyer’s special purpose}} and {{c3::buyer relies on seller’s skill or judgment}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Implied Warranty – Who Can Sue, Elements, and Defenses
cards.rawHeader: Torts 039-3. Implied Warranty – Who Can Sue, Elements, and Defenses
cards.front: Implied Warranty – Who Can Sue, Elements, and Defenses
cards.backPlain: Implied warranty claims in products liability: who can sue, elements, and defenses. 1. Who can sue: 1.1 Implied warranty protection extends to the buyer. 1.2 It also extends to the buyer's family, household, and guests who suffer personal injury. 2. Elements of an implied warranty claim: 2.1 Warranty: Existence of an applicable implied warranty (merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose). 2.2 Breach: The product fails to live up to the applicable warranty (e.g., not of average acceptable quality, not fit for ordinary or particular purpose). 2.3 Causation: Actual and proximate causation between the breach and the plaintiff's injury. 2.4 Damages: Personal injury, property damage, and economic loss are all recoverable under implied warranty. 3. Defenses to implied warranty claims: 3.1 Assumption of risk. 3.2 Contributory negligence (in contributory-negligence jurisdictions). 3.3 Comparative negligence (in comparative-negligence jurisdictions).
cards.frontPrompt: In an implied warranty products liability claim, who can sue, what are the elements, and what defenses are available?
cards.cloze: Implied warranty claims in products liability: 1. Who can sue: 1.1 The {{c1::buyer}}. 1.2 The buyer's {{c2::family, household, and guests}} who suffer personal injury. 2. Elements: 2.1 {{c3::Warranty}}: Existence of an applicable implied warranty (merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose). 2.2 {{c4::Breach}}: The product fails to live up to the applicable warranty. 2.3 {{c5::Causation}}: {{c6::actual and proximate}} causation between breach and injury. 2.4 {{c7::Damages}}: {{c8::personal injury, property damage, and economic loss}} are all recoverable. 3. Defenses: 3.1 {{c9::Assumption of risk}}. 3.2 {{c10::Contributory negligence}} (where applicable). 3.3 {{c11::Comparative negligence}} (where applicable).
cards.easyContent: Implied warranty claims can be brought by the buyer and by the buyer’s family, household, and guests for personal injury, and require warranty, breach, causation, and damages, subject to defenses like assumption of risk and contributory or comparative negligence.
cards.mediumContent: An implied warranty products liability claim may be brought by the buyer and by members of the buyer’s family, household, and guests who suffer personal injury. The plaintiff must prove an applicable implied warranty (merchantability or fitness), breach because the product did not conform to that warranty, actual and proximate causation, and recoverable damages, which may include personal, property, and economic harm. Defenses include assumption of risk and the plaintiff’s fault under contributory or comparative negligence regimes.
cards.hardContent: In products liability, implied warranty protection covers not only the buyer but also the buyer’s family, household members, and guests who suffer personal injury from defective goods. To recover, a plaintiff must establish: (1) an applicable implied warranty—either merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose; (2) breach, shown by the product’s failure to meet the warranted standard (such as not being of average acceptable quality or not being fit for its ordinary or special purpose); (3) actual and proximate causation linking the breach to the plaintiff’s injury; and (4) damages, including personal injury, property damage, and economic loss. Defendants may raise defenses such as assumption of risk and plaintiff fault, including contributory negligence or comparative negligence depending on the jurisdiction.
cards.mnemonic: Implied warranty: WBCD + AR & CN/CPN (buyer’s circle can sue).
cards.clozeLite: Implied warranty plaintiffs include {{c1::the buyer, family, household, and guests}} and must prove {{c2::implied warranty}}, {{c3::breach}}, {{c4::causation}}, {{c5::damages}}; defenses: {{c6::assumption of risk and plaintiff fault}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Liability Based on Representation – Express Warranty
cards.rawHeader: Torts 040-1. Liability Based on Representation – Express Warranty
cards.front: Liability Based on Representation – Express Warranty
cards.backPlain: Express warranty liability in products cases: 1. Definition: 1.1 An express warranty is a statement of material fact or promise regarding goods sold that becomes part of the basis of the bargain. 2. Who can sue and reliance: 2.1 Any consumer or bystander can sue for breach of express warranty. 2.2 Bystanders need not have relied personally on the express warranty, so long as the original purchaser did. 3. Elements (same as for implied warranties): 3.1 Existence of an express warranty relied upon by the purchaser. 3.2 Breach: the product fails to live up to the warranty (nonconformity). 3.3 Causation: actual and proximate. 3.4 Damages: personal injury, property damage, and economic loss. 4. Defenses: 4.1 Assumption of risk. 4.2 Contributory negligence. 4.3 Comparative negligence.
cards.frontPrompt: In products liability, what is an express warranty, who can sue for its breach, what are the required elements, and what defenses are available?
cards.cloze: Express warranty liability in products cases: 1. Definition: 1.1 An {{c1::express warranty}} is a {{c2::statement of material fact or promise}} regarding goods sold that becomes part of the {{c3::basis of the bargain}}. 2. Who can sue and reliance: 2.1 Any {{c4::consumer or bystander}} can sue for breach of express warranty. 2.2 {{c5::Bystanders}} need not have relied personally on the express warranty, so long as the {{c6::original purchaser}} did. 3. Elements (same as for implied warranties): 3.1 Existence of an express warranty {{c7::relied upon by the purchaser}}. 3.2 {{c8::Breach}}: the product fails to live up to the warranty ({{c9::nonconformity}}). 3.3 {{c10::Causation}}: actual and proximate. 3.4 {{c11::Damages}}: {{c12::personal injury, property damage, and economic loss}}. 4. Defenses: 4.1 {{c13::Assumption of risk}}. 4.2 {{c14::Contributory negligence}}. 4.3 {{c15::Comparative negligence}}.
cards.easyContent: An express warranty is a material factual statement or promise about goods that becomes part of the bargain. Any consumer or bystander can sue if the product does not conform, causing harm, and typical negligence-style defenses apply.
cards.mediumContent: An express warranty is any statement of material fact or promise about the goods that becomes part of the basis of the bargain. Any consumer or bystander can sue for breach; bystanders need not personally rely as long as the original purchaser relied. Liability requires: (1) an express warranty relied on by the purchaser; (2) breach when the product fails to live up to the warranty; (3) actual and proximate causation; and (4) damages, including personal, property, and economic loss. Defenses include assumption of risk and contributory or comparative negligence.
cards.hardContent: Express warranty liability in products cases arises when a seller makes a statement of material fact or promise regarding the goods that becomes part of the basis of the bargain. Any consumer or bystander may sue for breach; bystanders need not have relied personally so long as the original purchaser relied on the warranty. The elements mirror those for implied warranties: (1) the existence of an express warranty relied upon by the purchaser; (2) breach, meaning the product fails to conform to or live up to the warranty; (3) actual and proximate causation linking the breach to the harm; and (4) damages, including personal injury, property damage, and economic loss. Defenses such as assumption of risk, contributory negligence, and comparative negligence are available to the defendant.
cards.mnemonic: EXPRESS: EXPressed PROMISE that buyer RELIES on.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card for express warranty definition, elements, who can sue, reliance, and defenses.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::express warranty}} is a {{c2::statement of material fact or promise}} about goods that {{c3::becomes part of the basis of the bargain}} and {{c4::any consumer or bystander can sue}} for its breach.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Liability Based on Representation – Misrepresentation of Fact
cards.rawHeader: Torts 040-2. Liability Based on Representation – Misrepresentation of Fact
cards.front: Liability Based on Representation – Misrepresentation of Fact
cards.backPlain: Misrepresentation-based products liability: 1. Misrepresentation of fact elements: 1.1 In the course of a sale, the seller makes a misrepresentation regarding a material fact concerning the quality or use of the goods. 1.2 The seller intends to induce reliance by the buyer (or class of buyers). 1.3 The misrepresentation induces justifiable reliance. 2. Strict liability based on misrepresentation: 2.1 For strict liability based on misrepresentation, the buyer need not personally rely on the misrepresentation for the seller to be liable; it is enough that the misrepresentation reaches and induces reliance by the purchasing public in a way that causes the plaintiff's harm.
cards.frontPrompt: In products liability, when is a seller liable for misrepresentation of fact, and how does the reliance requirement differ in strict liability based on misrepresentation?
cards.cloze: Misrepresentation-based products liability: 1. Misrepresentation of fact elements: 1.1 In the course of a sale, the seller makes a {{c1::misrepresentation}} regarding a {{c2::material fact}} concerning the {{c3::quality or use}} of the goods. 1.2 The seller {{c4::intends to induce reliance}} by the buyer (or class of buyers). 1.3 The misrepresentation induces {{c5::justifiable reliance}}. 2. Strict liability based on misrepresentation: 2.1 For {{c6::strict liability based on misrepresentation}}, the buyer need not {{c7::personally rely}} on the misrepresentation for the seller to be liable; it is enough that the misrepresentation reaches and induces reliance by the purchasing public in a way that causes the plaintiff's harm.
cards.easyContent: A seller is liable for products liability based on misrepresentation when, in selling the product, they misstate a material fact about its quality or use, intend to induce reliance, and that misstatement causes harm through justifiable reliance. In strict-liability misrepresentation, the individual buyer need not personally have relied.
cards.mediumContent: Misrepresentation liability in products cases arises when, in the course of a sale, the seller misrepresents a material fact about the product’s quality or use, intending to induce reliance, and that misrepresentation induces justifiable reliance and causes harm. In strict-liability misrepresentation, the plaintiff need not show that they personally relied; it suffices that the misrepresentation was directed to and relied on by the purchasing public in a way that led to the injury.
cards.hardContent: In products liability, a seller is liable for misrepresentation of fact where, in the course of a sale, the seller makes a misrepresentation regarding a material fact concerning the quality or use of the goods, intends to induce reliance by the buyer (or a class of buyers), and the misrepresentation induces justifiable reliance that results in the plaintiff’s harm. For strict liability based on misrepresentation, the traditional reliance requirement is relaxed: the buyer need not personally rely on the misrepresentation. Instead, liability can arise where the misrepresentation is disseminated to and relied upon by the purchasing public or class of consumers in a way that causally links the misrepresentation to the plaintiff’s injury.
cards.mnemonic: MIRRORS: Material fact, Induce, Reliance Relaxed On Strict-liability.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card for misrepresentation-based products liability and strict liability reliance rule.
cards.clozeLite: Seller is liable for {{c1::misrepresentation of a material fact}} about product {{c2::quality or use}} made {{c3::to induce reliance}} that {{c4::causes harm through justifiable reliance}}. In {{c5::strict-liability misrepresentation}}, buyer {{c6::need not personally rely}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.rawHeader: Torts 041. Nuisance – General Definition and Nature
cards.backPlain: General definition and nature of nuisance: 1. Nuisance is an intentional invasion of either public or private property rights that substantially and unreasonably interferes with the peaceful and quiet enjoyment of those rights. 2. Nuisance is a harm, not a standalone tort: • Nuisance refers to a type of harm caused by underlying tortious conduct (e.g., negligence, intentional conduct). • The focus is on interference with the use and enjoyment of property, typically by nontrespassory invasions (e.g., noise, odors, smoke), rather than direct physical entry.
cards.frontPrompt: What is nuisance in general, and how is it best characterized in tort law?
cards.cloze: General definition and nature of nuisance: 1. {{c1::Nuisance}} is an {{c2::intentional invasion}} of either {{c3::public or private property rights}} that {{c4::substantially and unreasonably interferes}} with the peaceful and quiet enjoyment of those rights. 2. Nuisance is a {{c5::harm, not a standalone tort}}: • It describes a {{c6::type of harm caused by underlying tortious conduct}}, focusing on {{c7::interference with use and enjoyment of property}}, often via {{c8::nontrespassory invasions}} like noise, odors, or smoke.
cards.easyContent: Nuisance is an intentional, substantial, and unreasonable interference with public or private property rights, harming the peaceful use and enjoyment of property. It describes a type of harm rather than a separate tort claim.
cards.mediumContent: Nuisance is an intentional invasion of public or private property rights that substantially and unreasonably interferes with the peaceful and quiet enjoyment of those rights. It is best understood as a category of harm caused by other tortious conduct (e.g., negligence, intentional acts), typically involving nontrespassory invasions such as noise, odors, or smoke.
cards.hardContent: Nuisance is an intentional invasion of public or private property rights that substantially and unreasonably interferes with peaceful and quiet enjoyment. It is not a standalone tort but a description of a type of harm that results from underlying tortious conduct. The key focus is on interference with the use and enjoyment of land, often through nontrespassory invasions (like noise, fumes, vibrations, or odors) rather than direct physical entry onto the property.
cards.mnemonic: Nuisance = N-U-I: Nontrespassory, Unreasonable, Interference with use/enjoyment.
cards.clozeLite: Nuisance is an {{c1::intentional}} {{c2::nontrespassory}} invasion that {{c3::substantially and unreasonably interferes}} with {{c4::use and enjoyment of property}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Private Nuisance – Elements and Substantial vs. Unreasonable Interference
cards.rawHeader: Torts 041. Private Nuisance – Elements and Interference
cards.backPlain: Private nuisance – definition and elements: 1. Definition: Private nuisance is a substantial, unreasonable interference with another individual’s use or enjoyment of her property. 2. Substantial interference: • The interference must be offensive, annoying, or inconvenient to the average person in the community. • The interference is not substantial if the plaintiff is hypersensitive or is using the property for a specialized, abnormal purpose. 3. Unreasonable interference: • The severity of the plaintiff’s injury must outweigh the utility of the defendant’s conduct. • An interference can be substantial but not unreasonable—for example, trains passing through the center of a city that are required by safety regulations to blow their horns at crossings.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of private nuisance, and how do courts distinguish between substantial and unreasonable interference with land use?
cards.cloze: Private nuisance – definition and elements: 1. Definition: {{c1::Private nuisance}} is a {{c2::substantial, unreasonable interference}} with another individual’s {{c3::use or enjoyment of her property}}. 2. {{c4::Substantial interference}}: • Must be {{c5::offensive, annoying, or inconvenient}} to the {{c6::average person in the community}}. • Not substantial if the plaintiff is {{c7::hypersensitive}} or using the property for a {{c8::specialized, abnormal purpose}}. 3. {{c9::Unreasonable interference}}: • The {{c10::severity of the plaintiff’s injury}} must {{c11::outweigh the utility}} of the defendant’s conduct. • An interference can be {{c12::substantial but not unreasonable}} (e.g., {{c13::required train horns in a city center}}).
cards.easyContent: Private nuisance is a substantial and unreasonable interference with another’s use or enjoyment of land. It must bother an average person, not just a hypersensitive user, and the harm must outweigh the utility of the defendant’s conduct.
cards.mediumContent: Private nuisance requires (1) a substantial interference with another’s use or enjoyment of land—meaning the interference would be offensive, annoying, or inconvenient to an average person, not just a hypersensitive or abnormally using plaintiff—and (2) an unreasonable interference, where the severity of the plaintiff’s harm outweighs the utility of the defendant’s conduct. An interference may be substantial but still reasonable, such as mandated train horns.
cards.hardContent: Private nuisance is a substantial, unreasonable interference with another’s use or enjoyment of land. Interference is substantial when it would be offensive, annoying, or inconvenient to an average person in the community; it is not substantial where the complaint results from a hypersensitive plaintiff or a specialized, abnormal use of the land. Interference is unreasonable when the severity of the plaintiff’s injury outweighs the social utility, benefit, or necessity of the defendant’s conduct. An interference may be substantial yet reasonable, as where trains pass through the center of a city and must blow their horns under safety regulations, so no private nuisance lies.
cards.mnemonic: Private nuisance is S-U: Substantial to average person + Unreasonable (harm over utility).
cards.clozeLite: Private nuisance requires {{c1::substantial interference}} with land use to an {{c2::average person}} and {{c3::unreasonable interference}} where {{c4::harm outweighs utility}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Public Nuisance – Definition and Private Recovery
cards.rawHeader: Torts 041. Public Nuisance – Definition and Private Recovery
cards.front: Public Nuisance – Definition and Private Recovery
cards.backPlain: Public nuisance – definition and private plaintiff standing: 1. Definition: Public nuisance is an unreasonable interference with the health, safety, or property rights of the community at large. 2. Who may sue and when: • Typically, a public authority (e.g., a city, state, or other governmental body) brings a public nuisance action on behalf of the public. • A private party may recover for a public nuisance only if she suffered unique damage not suffered by the public at large (a special injury beyond the general public harm).
cards.frontPrompt: What is public nuisance, and under what circumstances may a private plaintiff recover for a public nuisance?
cards.cloze: Public nuisance – definition and private recovery: 1. Definition: {{c1::Public nuisance}} is an {{c2::unreasonable interference}} with the {{c3::health, safety, or property rights}} of the {{c4::community at large}}. 2. Who may sue: • Usually brought by a {{c5::public authority}} on behalf of the public. • A {{c6::private party}} may recover only if she suffered {{c7::unique damage not suffered by the public at large}} (a {{c8::special injury}}).
cards.easyContent: Public nuisance is an unreasonable interference with the community’s health, safety, or property rights. A private person can sue for a public nuisance only if she suffers special, unique harm beyond what the general public suffers.
cards.mediumContent: Public nuisance is an unreasonable interference with the health, safety, or property rights of the community at large. Such actions are usually brought by public authorities. A private plaintiff may recover only if she suffers unique damage—special injury distinct from the general harm suffered by the public.
cards.hardContent: Public nuisance is an unreasonable interference with the public’s collective interests in health, safety, or property rights—harm directed at the community at large rather than a single landowner. Government or public authorities usually bring such suits on behalf of the public. A private plaintiff may sue for public nuisance only if she can show unique damage not suffered by the public generally; this ‘special injury’ requirement limits standing to those who bear a distinct, individualized harm beyond the diffuse public impact.
cards.mnemonic: Public nuisance: PUBLIC harm, PRIVATE needs SPECIAL injury.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::public nuisance}} is an {{c2::unreasonable interference}} with {{c3::community-wide health, safety, or property rights}}; a private plaintiff needs {{c4::special, unique injury}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Nuisance – Remedies and Defenses (Coming to the Nuisance)
cards.backPlain: Nuisance – remedies and key defense: 1. Remedies for nuisance: • Money damages: to compensate for harm to the use or enjoyment of property. • Injunctive relief: to abate, limit, or prevent the nuisance where damages are inadequate or continuing harm is likely. 2. Defense – “coming to the nuisance”: • A plaintiff generally cannot recover if he “came to the nuisance,” such as by buying property next door to a long‑existing copper smelting plant that creates the complained‑of interference. • This doctrine reflects the idea that a person who voluntarily moves next to an obvious, established activity may have diminished grounds to complain of it as a nuisance.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main remedies for nuisance, and how does the “coming to the nuisance” doctrine operate as a defense?
cards.cloze: Nuisance – remedies and defense: 1. Remedies: • {{c1::Money damages}} to compensate for interference with use or enjoyment. • {{c2::Injunctive relief}} to abate, limit, or prevent the nuisance, especially where harm is ongoing or damages are inadequate. 2. Defense – {{c3::"coming to the nuisance"}}: • A plaintiff generally cannot recover if he {{c4::came to the nuisance}}, e.g., by {{c5::purchasing property next to a long‑existing smelting plant}} that creates the complained‑of interference.
cards.easyContent: Nuisance remedies include money damages and injunctions to stop or limit the interference. A key defense is that the plaintiff “came to the nuisance,” such as by moving next to an already existing, obviously interfering activity.
cards.mediumContent: For nuisance, courts commonly award money damages to compensate for harm to the use and enjoyment of property and may grant injunctive relief to abate or prevent ongoing or future interference. A significant defense is “coming to the nuisance”: a plaintiff who voluntarily moves near a long‑existing, obvious source of interference (like a copper smelting plant) generally has a weaker claim and may be denied recovery.
cards.hardContent: Nuisance may be remedied by monetary damages, compensating the plaintiff for diminished use, enjoyment, or value of her property, and by injunctive relief, especially where the interference is ongoing or damages would be inadequate. Courts may balance the hardship of an injunction against the harm from the nuisance. A classic defense is that the plaintiff “came to the nuisance”: if the challenged activity predates the plaintiff’s occupation or purchase of the land—such as buying property next to a long‑existing copper smelting plant—courts often deny or limit relief on the theory that the plaintiff assumed the risk of that established land use.
cards.mnemonic: Remedies: D&I (Damages & Injunction); Defense: Came to the Nuisance.
cards.clozeLite: Nuisance remedies include {{c1::money damages}} and {{c2::injunctive relief}}; a key defense is {{c3::coming to the nuisance}} when plaintiff moves near a long‑existing use.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Vicarious Liability – General Rule & Respondeat Superior
cards.rawHeader: Torts 042-1. Vicarious Liability – General Rule & Respondeat Superior
cards.front: Vicarious Liability – General Rule & Respondeat Superior
cards.backPlain: 1. General definition of vicarious liability: 1.1. Vicarious liability arises when a defendant commits a tort against a plaintiff and a third person is held liable due to his legal relationship with the defendant. 2. Respondeat superior – employer liability for employees: 2.1. Basic rule: Employers are liable for torts committed by employees within the scope of their employment. 2.2. “Scope of employment” generally includes acts: 2.2.1. Of the kind the employee is employed to perform. 2.2.2. Substantially within the authorized time and space limits. 2.2.3. Motivated, at least in part, by a purpose to serve the employer. 3. Exam framing: 3.1. Confirm there is an employer–employee (not independent contractor) relationship. 3.2. Ask whether the tort occurred within the scope of employment under the above criteria.
cards.frontPrompt: What is vicarious liability, and when is an employer vicariously liable for an employee’s tort under respondeat superior?
cards.cloze: 1. General definition of vicarious liability: 1.1. {{c1::Vicarious liability}} arises when a defendant commits a tort and a {{c2::third person is held liable due to his legal relationship with the defendant}}. 2. {{c3::Respondeat superior}} – employer liability for employees: 2.1. Basic rule: {{c4::Employers are liable}} for torts committed by {{c5::employees within the scope of their employment}}. 2.2. “Scope of employment” generally includes acts: 2.2.1. Of the kind the employee is {{c6::employed to perform}}. 2.2.2. Substantially within the {{c7::authorized time and space}} limits. 2.2.3. {{c8::Motivated, at least in part, by a purpose to serve the employer}}.
cards.easyContent: Vicarious liability makes one person liable for another’s tort because of their relationship. Under respondeat superior, an employer is vicariously liable for an employee’s torts that are within the scope of employment.
cards.mediumContent: Vicarious liability arises when a tortfeasor’s legal relationship with another person makes that other person liable. Under respondeat superior, an employer is vicariously liable for an employee’s torts committed within the scope of employment—acts of the kind the employee is hired to perform, within authorized time and place, and at least partly intended to serve the employer.
cards.hardContent: Vicarious liability occurs when a defendant commits a tort and a third party is held liable solely because of a recognized legal relationship. The most common doctrine is respondeat superior: an employer is vicariously liable for an employee’s torts committed within the scope of employment. Scope typically means conduct of the kind the employee is hired to perform, occurring within authorized time and space limits, and at least partly motivated by a purpose to serve the employer. The key exam moves are to distinguish employees from independent contractors and analyze whether the tortious conduct fits within this scope test.
cards.mnemonic: "RS" for Respondeat Superior: Responsibility Shifts from employee to employer when acting within the job’s scope.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::vicarious liability}}, an {{c2::employer}} is liable for an {{c3::employee}}’s torts {{c4::within the scope of employment}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Vicarious Liability – Intentional Torts Within Scope of Employment
cards.rawHeader: Torts 042-2. Vicarious Liability – Intentional Torts Within Scope of Employment
cards.front: Vicarious Liability – Intentional Torts Within Scope of Employment
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule for intentional torts: 1.1. Intentional torts (e.g., assault, battery, false imprisonment) are usually outside the scope of employment and do not trigger respondeat superior. 2. Exceptions – when intentional torts are within the scope: 2.1. Job requires use of force: 2.1.1. If the employee’s job inherently requires the use of force, intentional torts committed in the course of that job may be within the scope of employment. 2.1.2. Example: A bouncer or security guard who commits a battery while ejecting a patron. 2.2. Job entails creating friction: 2.2.1. Where the nature of the job is likely to generate conflict or friction with others, related intentional torts can be within the scope. 2.2.2. Example: A bail bondsman confronting a fugitive or debtor. 2.3. Intentional tort done to further employer’s goals: 2.3.1. If the employee commits an intentional tort in order to further the employer’s business or purposes, it can fall within the scope of employment. 2.3.2. Example: An employee physically breaking up a fight in a store to protect customers or property.
cards.frontPrompt: When can an employer be vicariously liable for an employee’s intentional tort, even though intentional torts are usually outside the scope of employment?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule for intentional torts: 1.1. {{c1::Intentional torts}} are usually {{c2::outside the scope of employment}} and do not trigger respondeat superior. 2. Exceptions – when intentional torts are within the scope: 2.1. {{c3::Job requires use of force}} (e.g., bouncer or security guard using force while doing the job). 2.2. {{c4::Job entails creating friction}} (e.g., bail bondsman whose confrontational role leads to intentional torts). 2.3. Intentional tort is done to {{c5::further the employer’s goals}} (e.g., employee physically breaking up a fight in a store to protect business interests).
cards.easyContent: Intentional torts are usually outside the scope of employment, but an employer can be vicariously liable if the job requires force, the job naturally creates friction with others, or the intentional tort is done to further the employer’s business.
cards.mediumContent: Although intentional torts typically fall outside the scope of employment, they are treated as within scope for respondeat superior when: (1) the job requires the use of force (like a bouncer or security guard); (2) the job naturally creates friction or conflict with others (such as a bail bondsman); or (3) the employee commits the intentional tort to further the employer’s goals, like breaking up a fight in a store to protect customers or property.
cards.hardContent: Under respondeat superior, employers are generally not liable for employees’ intentional torts because they are considered outside the scope of employment. However, three major exceptions bring intentional torts within scope: (1) where the job inherently requires the use of force, so intentional batteries or assaults in carrying out that role may be expected (e.g., bouncers, security personnel); (2) where the job is one that naturally engenders friction, antagonism, or confrontation (e.g., bail bondsmen or certain collections roles); and (3) where the employee’s intentional tort is committed in an effort to further the employer’s business or protect its interests, such as an employee physically intervening to stop a fight in the store. In these scenarios, the employer can be vicariously liable for the intentional tort.
cards.mnemonic: FFF: Force job, Friction job, Furthering employer.
cards.clozeLite: Intentional torts are within scope when the {{c1::job requires force}}, {{c2::naturally creates friction}}, or {{c3::furthers the employer’s goals}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Vicarious Liability – Independent Contractors & Non-Delegable Duties
cards.rawHeader: Torts 042-3. Vicarious Liability – Independent Contractors & Non-Delegable Duties
cards.front: Vicarious Liability – Independent Contractors & Non-Delegable Duties
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule for independent contractors: 1.1. Employers are generally not vicariously liable for torts committed by independent contractors. 2. Major exceptions – when the hiring party may be liable: 2.1. Inherently dangerous activities: 2.1.1. If the independent contractor is performing an inherently dangerous or unusually risky activity, the hiring party may be vicariously (or strictly) liable for resulting harm. 2.2. Non-delegable duties: 2.2.1. Certain duties cannot be delegated to an independent contractor to avoid liability. 2.2.2. A common example: Businesses that hold property open to the public have a non-delegable duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for customers. 2.2.3. Even if a business hires an independent contractor (e.g., for maintenance or security), it may still be liable to customers injured due to unsafe conditions. 3. Exam approach: 3.1. Determine whether the tortfeasor is an employee or an independent contractor. 3.2. If an independent contractor, check for inherently dangerous work or a non-delegable duty (especially premises safety for customers).
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule for vicarious liability for independent contractors, and what are the key exceptions such as inherently dangerous work and non-delegable duties?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule for independent contractors: 1.1. Employers are generally {{c1::not vicariously liable}} for torts committed by {{c2::independent contractors}}. 2. Major exceptions – when the hiring party may be liable: 2.1. {{c3::Inherently dangerous activities}}. 2.2. {{c4::Non-delegable duties}}. 2.2.1. Example: Businesses that hold property open to the public have a {{c5::non-delegable duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for customers}}. 2.2.2. Liability may still attach even if {{c6::maintenance or safety is entrusted to an independent contractor}}.
cards.easyContent: A business is usually not vicariously liable for an independent contractor’s torts. But it can be liable when the contractor is doing inherently dangerous work or when the business has a non-delegable duty, like keeping premises safe for customers.
cards.mediumContent: The default rule is that a hiring party is not vicariously liable for the torts of independent contractors. However, important exceptions apply: (1) where the contractor performs inherently dangerous or unusually risky activities; and (2) where the law treats a duty as non-delegable, such as a business’s duty to keep premises reasonably safe for customers. In these situations, the hiring party cannot escape liability by labeling the actor an independent contractor.
cards.hardContent: Vicarious liability generally does not extend to the acts of independent contractors: a person who hires an independent contractor is typically not liable for the contractor’s torts. Two key exceptions are tested on the bar: (1) inherently dangerous activities, where the nature of the work itself poses special risks (e.g., blasting, high-risk construction), and the hiring party may be liable for resulting harm; and (2) non-delegable duties, where the law deems certain obligations too important to delegate. A classic non-delegable duty is a business’s duty, when holding its property open to the public, to keep the premises reasonably safe for customers. Even if the business hires an independent contractor to maintain or secure the property, it may still be liable to injured patrons for unsafe conditions arising from the contractor’s negligence.
cards.mnemonic: Independent contractors: ID = Inherently Dangerous, non-Delegable.
cards.clozeLite: Default: no {{c1::vicarious liability}} for {{c2::independent contractors}}. Key exceptions: {{c3::inherently dangerous activities}} and {{c4::non-delegable duties}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.backPlain: 1. General partnership rule: 1.1. In a partnership, each partner is vicariously liable for torts committed by any other partner in the ordinary course of the partnership business. 2. Scope of partnership business: 2.1. The tort must be committed within the scope of the partnership or in the ordinary course of its business activities. 2.2. If the partner acts purely for personal reasons, outside partnership business, other partners are generally not vicariously liable. 3. Relationship to bar exam fact patterns: 3.1. Look for co-owners of a business sharing profits who are acting in furtherance of the business. 3.2. If one partner negligently injures a third party while acting for the partnership, all partners can be held liable.
cards.frontPrompt: When are partners vicariously liable for other partners’ torts in a partnership?
cards.cloze: 1. General partnership rule: 1.1. In a {{c1::partnership}}, each {{c2::partner}} is vicariously liable for torts committed by {{c3::any other partner}} in the {{c4::ordinary course of the partnership business}}. 2. Scope of partnership business: 2.1. The tort must be committed {{c5::within the scope of the partnership}} or in the {{c6::ordinary course of its business}}. 2.2. Purely personal acts {{c7::outside partnership business}} generally do not create vicarious liability for other partners.
cards.easyContent: Each partner in a partnership is vicariously liable for other partners’ torts committed in the ordinary course of the partnership’s business.
cards.mediumContent: Partnership vicarious liability means that each partner is liable for the torts of co-partners committed in the ordinary course of the partnership business. If a partner injures a third party while carrying out normal partnership activities, all partners can be held liable, but not when the partner acts purely for personal reasons outside the partnership.
cards.hardContent: In a partnership, every partner is an agent of the partnership for carrying on its business. Each partner is vicariously liable for torts committed by any other partner in the ordinary course of the partnership business or with authority of the partnership. If the tort occurs while a partner is acting in furtherance of partnership purposes—such as meeting clients, delivering goods, or operating partnership equipment—the other partners may be jointly and severally liable. However, if the tortious conduct is entirely outside partnership activities and undertaken for strictly personal reasons, the other partners are not vicariously liable.
cards.mnemonic: Partnership: "One acts, all answer"—torts in ordinary course bind all.
cards.clozeLite: Each partner is vicariously liable for co-partners’ torts committed {{c1::in the ordinary course of partnership business}} and not for acts {{c2::purely for personal reasons outside the partnership}}.

cards.subject: Torts
cards.topic: Liability Related to Children’s Torts & Tavernkeepers
cards.rawHeader: Torts 042-5. Liability Related to Children’s Torts & Tavernkeepers
cards.front: Liability for Children’s Torts & Tavernkeepers’ Liability
cards.backPlain: 1. Parent–child relationship: 1.1. No vicarious liability: 1.1.1. Parents are not vicariously liable for their children’s torts solely by virtue of the parent–child relationship. 1.2. Possible direct (independent) negligence: 1.2.1. Parents may be held liable for their own negligence where: 1.2.1.1. They had reason to know of the child’s dangerous or violent propensities; or 1.2.1.2. They facilitated or failed to supervise, enabling the tort (e.g., giving a dangerous weapon to a child known to be reckless). 2. Tavernkeepers and alcohol vendors: 2.1. General principle: 2.1.1. Businesses serving alcohol may be held liable to a plaintiff injured by an intoxicated patron if the business was negligent in serving the patron. 2.1.2. This liability often arises under "dram shop" statutes or similar negligence-based rules. 2.2. Typical scenarios: 2.2.1. Serving a visibly intoxicated patron who then injures a third party. 2.2.2. Serving a minor in violation of law who then causes injury. 3. Exam focus: 3.1. Distinguish true vicarious liability (e.g., employer–employee) from direct negligence liability (parental negligence; negligent serving by tavernkeepers).
cards.frontPrompt: Are parents vicariously liable for their children’s torts, and when can parents or tavernkeepers nevertheless be liable for harms caused by children or intoxicated patrons?
cards.cloze: 1. Parent–child relationship: 1.1. {{c1::Parents are not vicariously liable}} for their children’s torts solely because of the parent–child relationship. 1.2. Parents may be {{c2::directly (independently) negligent}} if they: 1.2.1. Had reason to know of the child’s {{c3::dangerous propensities}}; or 1.2.2. {{c4::Facilitated or failed to supervise}}, enabling the tort. 2. Tavernkeepers and alcohol vendors: 2.1. cards.easyContent: Parents are not automatically vicariously liable for their children’s torts. They can be directly liable if they negligently supervise or arm a child they know is dangerous. Tavernkeepers and similar alcohol vendors can be liable to third parties if they negligently serve an intoxicated person (often under dram shop laws).
cards.mediumContent: The parent–child relationship does not create vicarious liability: parents are not automatically liable for their children’s torts. However, parents may be independently negligent if they knew or should have known of a child’s dangerous propensities or if they facilitated or failed to supervise the child, enabling the tort. Separately, tavernkeepers and alcohol vendors may be liable to third parties injured by intoxicated patrons when the vendor negligently serves them, such as serving a visibly intoxicated adult or a minor, often under dram shop statutes.
cards.hardContent: Parent–child relationships do not generate traditional vicarious liability: parents are not liable merely because their child commits a tort. Liability instead arises for parents’ own negligence—for example, negligent supervision or negligent entrustment—where they knew or had reason to know of the child’s propensity to injure or when they facilitated the tort (such as providing a dangerous instrumentality to a known reckless child). In contrast, tavernkeepers and similar businesses serving alcohol may incur liability to third parties injured by intoxicated patrons if the business is negligent in serving them, commonly under dram shop statutes. These statutes or related negligence rules often impose liability for serving visibly intoxicated persons or minors who subsequently cause injury. On exams, treat parental and tavernkeeper liability as direct negligence rather than pure vicarious liability.
